QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CLOSURE OF NEW SOUTH WALES HOSPITALS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact, as claimed by the New South Wales Labor Government, that the Federal Government is responsible for the closure of some New South Wales hospitals because of lack of funding? I ask: Could the Minister inform the Senate what financial grants are available to New South Wales for hospitals from the Federal Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true that New South Wales hospitals had to close because of lack of Federal funding. The facts are that New South Wales will have additional funds available to it this year from the Commonwealth, when compared with previous years. It will have more money this year than in previous years. I remind honourable senators that the basis of this year's Commonwealth funding is as follows: It is the 1980-81 funding levels, plus a 10 per cent amount for escalation to take account of changes in prices during the year, together with an estimate of 40 per cent of the increased revenue flowing from the new charging arrangements. On that basis, New South Wales will have extra money. In dollar terms this should mean that New South Wales will have available to it this financial year an additional $51m in real terms in revenue potential. In the light of that extra revenue potential, it is quite fanciful for New South Wales to claim that, if it is closing hospitals, that is in any way related to the funding coming from the Federal Government. It will have $51m in extra revenue potential.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health in New South Wales, Mr Stewart, has previously announced a plan to rationalise hospital services. He announced this plan well ahead of any funding arrangements. He is on record as saying that the rationalisation in New South Wales which he has initiated and which he is planning will not result in any lowering of standards of hospital services. The New South Wales Government has to face the fact that if it wants to carry out a rationalisation of hospital services, that is all very well, but it has got extra revenue potential available and it cannot try to put the blame for what it is doing on the Commonwealth Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Is it a fact, as reported in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, that horse meat had been discovered by Victorian Department of Agriculture inspectors in cartons of Profreeze labelled export beef? Is it also a fact that this horse meat carries traces of methyl violet, a dye used to indicate that this meat originated from a knackery and is thus unfit for human consumption? Is it a fact that there is no full time inspection service at knackeries to ensure that all the products of these works are comprehensibly dyed with methyl violet to prevent possible substitution as a product for human consumption? Finally, does the Minister agree that this particular incident of dyed pet food appearing in beef cartons highlights a serious threat to public health posed by a lack of a uniform and strong meat inspection service throughout Australia?

—I did not see the Sydney Morning Herald referred to by the honourable senator in his question but I understand that there was such a report. My advice, of course, is consistent with the statement which was made yesterday in this place and in the House of Representatives on the meat issue, that of course horse meat has been found in a product exported to the United States from two Australian establishments and that kangaroo meat has been found in shipments from one. As far as any allegation is concerned that traces of methyl violet have been found in cartons, the information that is available to the Government is that that is not correct, that traces of methyl violet have not been found in cartons examined so far. As a result that particular matter has not been referred to the police or to the Department of Agriculture because it is simply not a matter which is a fact as far as we know.

I will refer the general question to the Minister for Primary Industry for consideration, but I would not see the Federal Government as seeing itself responsible for wages lost in these circumstances.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, concerns the failure of some colleges of advanced education to meet the deadline for amalgamation. The first part of the question is about the Institute of Early Childhood Development and the Hawthorn State College in Victoria. Is the Minister aware that both of these colleges are specialist bodies and that amalgamation is probably not possible because there is not a body with which to amalgamate? In these circumstances can the Minister give us an assurance that funding for these two bodies will continue? The other part of my question concerns colleges of advanced education which could amalgamate but have not met the deadline. Can the Minister say what will be the approach towards those bodies?

—As honourable senators will know, the Tertiary Education Commission recommended some time ago that there ought to be some rationalisation on a fairly large scale of the number of colleges in Australia. That happened primarily because colleges had proliferated. Many were single purpose teachers colleges. The general educational belief was that since the growth of teacher training and the wave of population had abated there was a need for rationalisation. So, some 30 colleges were under consideration. I am not specifically aware of the present situation with respect to the two institutions mentioned by the honourable senator, particularly the Institute of Early Childhood Development. I am aware of this body as an institute and I acknowledge that such an institute is in fact a specialist body with specialist problems. I will talk to the Minister for Education and obtain his thinking on the time program that is to be allowed. It is desirable that where the amalgamations or rationalisations can occur readily they should do so. Therefore, a timetable was set. But in case there is any change in the particular development in those two areas I will refer those sections of Senators Lewis's question to the Minister in another place and seek his advice.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services inform the Senate whether the Commonwealth Government bookshops which the Government is planning to lease to private operators are currently making a profit? Secondly, will the leasing arrangements which the Government proposes include profit sharing with the Commonwealth? Thirdly, will the terms of the lease ensure the continuation of a retail shop front point of sale for all Commonwealth publications? Fourthly, will the Government ensure that all public servants employed in the bookshops have the opportunity to continue in the Public Service with the status and promotional opportunities that they currently enjoy?

—Although I will have to check, it is my belief that the bookshops were generally operating at a profit. Clearly I will have to seek for the honourable senator some of the other specific information which he wants in relation to profit sharing and conditions of service for public servants. It is my understanding, and again I will check this to be quite certain, that it is the intention that the bookshops should be retained as retail shop front outlets to provide for the public the greatest possible benefit and the greatest possible access. I assure the honourable senator and the Senate that, mindful of the useful role that the bookshops play in making information available to the public, the Government will do what it can to ensure that the valuable service continues.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry will recall the public outcry last year at the cruelty meted out to live horses destined for export to Japan and the subsequent tabling in the Parliament of guidelines governing future exports. I ask the Minister: Why was Dr Wirth, President of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and six RSPCA inspectors refused permission to inspect a consignment of 60 horses being loaded at Tullamarine Airport last night aboard a DC8 aircraft operated by the American Flying Tigers company and destined for Japan? As Dr Wirth has been reported as saying that the aircraft was unfit for the transport of horses and that the stringent regulations gazetted after the previous sorry episode do not extend to air travel of horses, I further ask: Will the Government take urgent action to gazette regulations to cover all forms of transport of live animals from Australia?

—I recall the very widespread concern about a year ago regarding the question of live animal exports. The Government gave attention to the matters of concern which were raised. As the honourable senator pointed out in his question tighter rules were introduced governing the export of live animals. The further matter which he raised has not come to my attention before. I will certainly refer it as a matter of urgency to the Minister for Primary Industry for consideration. I think all honourable senators would share the view that where animals are exported live there should be proper policing of the conditions of export to ensure that no intentional or unintentional cruelty is inflicted on those animals.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEES FOR SECOND AND HIGHER DEGREES

TALK.START.PARA: —Before asking my question I wish to inform the Senate of perhaps an indirect interest in the charging of second degrees because of the planning of a university course for my son. My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Can he inform the Senate of the net benefit of setting fees for second and higher degrees and of the student loan scheme, that is, the amount of fees raised less the cost of raising the revenue? Further, what effect will the introduction of fees have in the way of being a disincentive for Australians in getting higher education and thus gaining in skills which will make them more productive citizens?

—There is a degree of detail in that question and I do not have information with me relating to it. I suggest that the honourable senator place his question on the Notice Paper and we will get a full answer for him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BLIND DIABETICS: CHECKING OF SUGAR LEVELS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In the United Kingdom blind diabetics can check their own sugar levels with the aid of a battery-powered meter with a buzzer which emits a different tone according to the glucose level of the sample. I ask: Is this instrument available in Australia? If it is, is it classified for financial help as a health aid?

—In reading the Medical Journal of Australia last week I noticed an article in a recent issue in which several apparatus for testing blood sugar levels were compared for their simplicity and accuracy. I do not believe that the battery-powered meter which would be suitable for blind people and referred to by the honourable senator was included. I indicate to the Senate that what I understood from that study was that some of those instruments were really unsuitable. Some are quite accurate but some lack accuracy. I would like to get more information from the honourable senator as to the brand of the instrument. We can try to get information for her. Only at that stage will I be able to give her information about the conditions under which it is available and whether it has been considered for any financial assistance.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Information now available has indicated that about 60 per cent of the clothing quota is now held by major retailers. Is this estimate in line with departmental advice? Does this follow the pattern that was anticipated and is it expected that the trend will continue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that under the new program of assistance for the textile, clothing and footwear industries commencing on 1 January next year there will be approximately 2,000 quota holders. The information that is available to me and the Department indicates that the assumption which is implicit in Senator Archer's question is not strictly true. However, I have some information in relation to this matter which I think ought to be incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave to have the document incorporated.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Under the new program of assistance to the textile clothing and footwear industries to commence on 1 January 1982 there will be approximately 2,000 quota holders.

Quota holders are not asked to indicate when applying for quota the type of business they transact i.e. whether they are manufacturers, retailers wholesalers etc. and some no doubt combine various activities.

It is true that since the new seven year program of assistance was announced there has been some rationalisation of quota holdings through the transfer arrangements which have been in operation since 1977.
Some larger retailers have figured prominently in these transfers.

The proportion of clothing quota held by various groups does vary from category to category in the 25 base quota categories which cover machine made and handicraft clothing. Because I am not familiar with the business activities of each quota holder, I am not in a position to confirm the actual proportion of quota held by retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers etc.

In the case of what might be termed the 'major' retailer specialist I can confirm that persons who could be classified as such hold the following percentage of quota in the 25 categories which cover machine made and handicraft clothing:
less than 10%-two categories
11%-20%-five categories
21%-30%-five categories
31%-40%-six categories
41%-50%-5 categories
51%-60%-one category
over 60%-one category.
As you can see on average this would have left these firms with an average considerably less than the 60% of quota suggested.
Also these base quota categories represent less than 85% of the total quota issued in each category. The balance of the quota is allocated by public tender.

The results of the public tender allocations are almost finalised and from the preliminary results published it would appear that the major retailing specialists did not dominate the tender scheme. The preliminary analysis indicates that these retailers' percentage of the quota allocated in the fourteen tender categories is as follows:
less than 10%-four categories
11%-20%-six categories
21%-30%-2 categories
over 30%-two categories.

On the whole the tender scheme seems to be achieving the objectives of the Government and rather than concentrating quota in the hands of larger quota holders it appears to be allowing others to achieve access to tariff quota. When base and tender allocations are combined the major retailers average holdings are reduced even further.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to an answer he gave to a question from Senator Elstob yesterday, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is extremely difficult to trace money that comes into this country . . .

Is it a fact that his Government has ceased the collection of statistical information relating to the level of foreign investment in Australia, and on foreign ownership and control of Australian industry, in areas inclusive of life insurance, finance companies, mining, manufacturing industry, advertising agencies and the tourist industry, to name only a few? Does the Minister agree that this action by his Government has accentuated the difficulties involved in tracing foreign investment and has opened the way for a massive, covert takeover of Australian enterprises and resources, as well as land? In view of this, why will the Government not take action to have the compilation of such statistics reintroduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware that the statistics were not available. The Government is very keen to ascertain and to make known the basis of the direction of investment capital coming into Australia. In the last year, it was shown upon analysis that of some $6 billion of foreign investment capital a substantial amount was for basic industrial development purposes and that a very large part-almost half or more-went out of Australia again to buy imports in order to establish industries and to develop employment in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The question asked yesterday concerned land. What I said yesterday was that, first of all, land is under the sovereignty of State governments and that knowledge of the purchase of land-that is, the existing title and the name of the proposed purchaser-is a matter for the direct information of and action by State governments, except in any territory in which the Commonwealth is involved. Therefore, the control of foreign ownership of land falls wholly within the capacity of the States. I also said that, apart from its primary purpose, some money that comes in can have, after a time lag, secondary or tertiary purposes, and be directed towards the purchase of land without the knowledge of the Commonwealth Government. It is within the capacity of the States of Australia to ensure the ownership of land within their sovereignty.

As to the ownership of industries in Australia, the Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines have been laid down and are well known. The Government has been able to achieve a majority Australian equity. We aim to try to continue that in the future. Our aim is that there should be not only a majority equity, but also a managerial input, by Australians. As to the first part of the question regarding the statistics, I will seek further information and let the honourable senator know.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and is on the matter that was raised by Senator Reid in her question today. Has it been drawn to the Minister's attention that Mr Krumins, the Chairman of the Ethnic Affairs Commission in South Australia, in his keynote speech to the Federation of Ethnic Communities meeting in Adelaide at the weekend, asked that Channel 0-28 multicultural television be brought to South Australia as soon as practicable? I have personally supported that call for many months and I ask the Minister, along the same lines as did Senator Reid, in respect of Canberra: How soon is it practicable for South Australians to expect in Adelaide the multicultural television services that are provided in Melbourne and Sydney? Can the Minister further confirm that the cost of setting up a transmitting base in any capital city would be of the order of $1m and the recurrent costs of the programs would be small because they would be those transmitted presently by Channel 0-28 in the other two capital cities?

—It is quite clear from the question asked by Senator Teague that there is widespread support among many communities, not only the ethnic communities, for the programs shown by Channels 0 and 28. The extra support which he has revealed in his question is pleasing to hear. I will pass it on to the Minister for Communications. It is the best evidence of the acceptability of the stations and of the programming. The question of how soon it will be practicable to extend the programs to Adelaide will require reference to the Minister in view of the policy and budgetary implications. I will undertake to do so. I will, at the same time, draw to the attention of the Minister the concern of Senator Teague in the interests of his own constituents of South Australia in this extra access to ethnic television programs.

—My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate follows the question asked earlier by Senator Bolkus. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that at a recent meeting of agricultural Ministers from all the States concern was expressed at Federal Government policies relating to foreign investment in Australian rural land? Will the Minister investigate the nature of the concern expressed by the State agricultural Ministers? What constructive suggestions were made by those Ministers in relation to changes in Federal Government policies?

—I was not, of course, present at such a meeting and therefore I have no direct knowledge of it at all. Therefore, I am not aware whether agricultural Ministers expressed concern regarding the Federal Government's responsibilities. I know that there is an interest and a concern amongst all Australians-and this Government shares it-that agricultural land and its ownership should be constantly kept under review so there is not any distortion of ownership. I am quite sure that the Treasurer, as the responsible Minister, and the Federal Government itself would welcome any suggestions which, in conjunction with the sovereignty of the States, could be assisted by the Commonwealth in its role in the inflow of funds. I will draw the attention of the Minister for Primary Industry to this question and ask him, if there is specific information arising out of that conference, to direct it to the Treasurer for his study.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Transport say whether any decision has been reached on the landbridge concept proposed by the Bureau of Transport Economics as an alternative to Tasmania's freight equalisation scheme?

—I understand that over the last few weeks the Minister has met several people from Tasmania representing a wide cross section of industry in that State. The Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme has been of immense value to the economy of Tasmania, as we all know. Although the Government has indicated that it will review the scheme it has no intention either of abolishing or changing it in a manner which would undermine its value to industry in or the people of Tasmania. The Minister has received a number of submissions with regard to the landbridge concept but there would be a need to review that scheme further and make adjustments to compensate industry for increased freight rates which might result from the implementation of such a scheme. However, the honourable senator can rest assured that the views of the Tasmanians in every respect will be taken into account in assessing the subject before the Government decides to take any decision in regard to it.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to the delay being experienced by the Hobart community frequency modulation radio station 7CAE.FM in obtaining approval to set up a translator to improve the appalling reception in a significant part of its listening area. I refer to the Minister's statement that the delay is due to the fact that about 500 proposals relating to broadcasting and television services are under consideration by his Department. Will the Minister find out how many of the 500 proposals relate to making essential improvements to existing services and to equipment already bought and ready for installation as does the 7CAE.FM proposal? Will the Minister ask the Department to select such proposals for speedy consideration to ensure that existing services can be viable and do not discriminate amongst people in the relevant listening areas?
—Because a considerable amount of detail is required to answer that question appropriately, if the senator places it on the Notice Paper I will try to get it to the Minister as quickly as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications or the Minister representing the Minister for Health. My question relates to the recent decision by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, FACTS, to ban television commercials for an anti-smoking game called Smokers Wild because they are allegedly disparaging to tobacco products. Given that Smokers Wild has been on the market for almost three months and no one, not even members of the tobacco companies, has complained to the distributors about their product, will the Minister inform the Senate of the reasons which underlie the Federation's rejection of the commercials? Does the Minister agree that the anti-smoking message promoted to young people by Smokers Wild is most commendable and completely in line with previous statements made in the Parliament by this Government? If so, will he assure the Senate that a full investigation will be made by the Government into the decision by FACTS to ban the commercials and that every effort will be made to allow them to be screened?

—I have not seen the game Smokers Wild. I can say to Senator Missen that I remember that when the game Poleconomy-a rather refined form of Monopoly-appeared before the last Federal election, I was able to take part in the introduction of that game. Three Labor candidates played against three Government candidates. The Labor candidate who was the Prime Minister in that introductory game sent the country bankrupt. I do not know of Smokers Wild. I am aware that the Government has, as a stated policy, an acknowledgment that smoking is dangerous to health.
—Who says?

—I inform Senator Elstob that, in response to a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, the Government has adopted a goal of reduced tobacco consumption. The honourable senator is correct in alluding to previous statements made in the chamber. I cannot comment on matters relating to Smokers Wild. I would hope that any policy used by FACTS is one that depends solely on the merits of the advertisements. I would not like to see any policy applied for other commercial reasons which might have to do with a desire to advantage any particular products which were being advertised. As to the specific matters relating to Smokers Wild, I will have to refer them to the Minister for Communications for a detailed answer.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that he has been quoted by name in advertisements by insurance companies, such as AC Insurances in South Australia, which are urging pensioners to invest their money in what are described as safe tax free and income test free investments to avoid the legislation which the Minister is said to be introducing on 1 November? Will such legislation be introduced by 1 November? Does the company to which I referred, or any other company, have any details that we do not have regarding the contents of the legislation? Can the Minister give any assistance to pensioners who may be tempted to put their money into such organisations for investment?

—I am not aware that I have been quoted by name in these or any other advertisements. I do not particularly like the sound of what has been put to me by the honourable senator. I will follow up the matter very quickly and see what is going on. With respect to the precise legislation which is to be introduced during this session, pursuant to the announcements in the Budget, I would expect it to be within the Parliament well before 1 November. Certainly there has been no communication through my office with insurance companies or anyone else as to the precise form of that legislation. I am almost certain that there has been no communication through my Department. I will examine the matter raised by the honourable senator, give it very careful consideration and provide a further reply as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I preface the question by saying that no doubt the Minister is well aware of the excellent work being carried out in the community by the Apex, Lion and Rotary clubs in Australia. Is the Minister aware that the three associations post periodical newsletters to their members and that the cost of that postage is money which is, therefore, not available for their very many worthwhile community projects? Will the Minister have the Minister for Communications examine the possibility of lowering the cost of postage for these groups and for similar groups by reclassifying the periodicals in a lower rate category.

—The honourable senator asks a question about service organisations. He makes the point that there are other community serving organisations to which he also wants his question to apply. The question involves a matter of policy and I will have to refer it to the Minister for Communications. I undertake to do that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the changes to the supplementary benefit mentioned in the Budget. The present arrangements result in a beneficiary losing part of the supplementary benefit-or rent allowance, as it is still often termed-when his or her income exceeds $1 a week. Will the new arrangements, which are to come into effect next February, mean that assistance will be reduced even for the first $1 of extra income? If this will not be the case, at what level of other income will a beneficiary's supplementary assistance be affected?

—One of the features of the system of supplementary assistance which has been in place for some time is that a dollar of assistance is lost for each dollar of income. So, if a pensioner has a relatively small amount of savings and receives $1 or $2 a week in interest, that pensioner will lose the same amount from the supplementary assistance.
—After $1.

—After $1. Following the changes announced in the Budget, the position will be that the withdrawal rate will be reduced to 50c in the dollar. The situation will be that a pensioner with $4 additional income will lose $2 in supplementary assistance. Of course, other changes were brought in with the Budget. For example, the maximum amount of supplementary assistance was raised from $5 to $8. Its availability, in respect of new claimants, is restricted to pensioners who are paying rent in excess of $10 a week. So, there are other alterations as well. I believe one of the significant improvements in the system we have announced is that the withdrawal rate is reduced from a dollar for dollar rate to a 50c in the dollar rate.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Budget Papers mention that there will be a loss of $1 for every $2 of other income, which I suppose is the same as saying it is a rate of 50c in the dollar. At the moment a person who has $1 of extra income does not lose any part of the supplementary assistance. Does it actually mean that from February next year a person who has $1 of extra income will lose 50c out of that first dollar?
—Yes.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services advise what stage the Northern Territory Supreme Court challenge to the acquisition of the Mudginberri and Munmalary pastoral leases has reached and what compensation will be paid for the acquisition? Recently the abattoir at Mudginberri station, which employed a large number of people, closed. Can the Government indicate its intentions in regard to Mudginberri and what future, if any, the abattoir is likely to have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asks about a court challenge. Before I refer to the Mudginberri matter, I will take a moment to inform the Senate that there are now court challenges in relation to the Finniss River land claim as well, and some time will elapse before those challenges are heard. Coming back to the Mudginberri and Munmalary leases, in June 1978 the Commonwealth acquired those two pastoral leases mainly for inclusion in the Kakadu National Park and partly for uranium mining purposes. The acquisition has been challenged by the former lessees, Northern Pastoral Services Ltd, in the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory. There is to be a preliminary hearing next Monday, 14 September. At that time, the court will be asked to set a date for the hearing of certain questions of law. That is the stage the challenge has reached.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator will be aware that in order to ensure that we had adequate Commonwealth title to the lands, the Parliament, at its last sitting, passed the Lands Acquisition (Northern Territory Pastoral Leases) Act 1981. I might add that this Act has not yet been proclaimed because negotiations are continuing with Northern Pastoral Services Ltd in order to settle the matter of compensation for the acquisition without further recourse to litigation. Negotiations with the company are expected to take place shortly and will include discussions on the future operations of the abattoir which is on Mudginberri property. In the meantime, the company has closed the abattoir on Mudginberri station and has transferred the operation, I think, to the Point Stuart abattoir. I think that pretty well covers the current situation at Mudginberri and Munmalary.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns passport control. By way of preface, I refer to a positive answer which I received from Senator Carrick 18 months ago in which he told me that as a result of an internal examination, the Department of Foreign Affairs felt that it had a perfect passport system. I ask Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to reconcile that boast or pledge with the evidence which has come out before the current Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking which shows extreme laxity in this area. I conclude my question by asking the Minister whether she will ensure that when that highly talented Estimates Committee D meets next week, the senior officers of the Department will not indulge in giving superficial answers but will give us an in-depth report on passport control and tell us how we can control some of the abuses which have manifested themselves in evidence at recent drug trials.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some remarks on malpractice in the issuing of passports in my file. I think what has been outlined by Senator Mulvihill could well be dealt with at the Senate estimates committee hearings. I will see that appropriate officers have information in order to deal with the many questions which I am sure will come from the honourable senator at that time.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, concerns the Victorian State College at Hawthorn, which I was able to visit this morning. My question is along similar lines to that asked by Senator Lewis earlier today, and concerns the decision of the razor gang-the Review of Commonwealth Functions-to include Hawthorn State College amongst those 30 colleges which were to be subject to amalgamation in order to become more cost effective. Given the already strong achievement in cost effectiveness by Hawthorn State College, its unique nature as a place for training trade teachers, its technical and vocational and industrial arts and design courses, its now geographic isolation, and the pattern of other amalgamations flowing from the review of Commonwealth Functions, will the Minister give careful consideration to this College being able to remain as a separate college of advanced education?

—I have knowledge of the Victorian State College at Hawthorn and its achievements over the years. It has some very well merited achievements. I am not equipped with particular information on the rationalisation of particular colleges. Therefore, I cannot answer as to what is the present status of the Hawthorn College in the rationalisation process. I think the best approach to this would be for me to bring the comments of Senator Teague to the attention of the Minister in the other place and ask him to give them consideration and also, if he so desires, to comment on the latter part of Senator Teague's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. It refers to the statement in the national development section of the razor gang report that:

QUESTION.PARA: Expenditure under Ord River Irrigation Act to be terminated after existing commitments have been met.
What are these existing commitments? In particular, do they include the $20m provided in the Western Australia Agreement (Ord River Irrigation) Act of 1968 which has not yet been spent?

TALK.START.PARA: —Discussions have been taking place between the Western Australian Government and the Commonwealth Government on outstanding matters relating to the Ord River. Just so that I do not escape any particular detail, I will seek the full information and let Senator Walsh have it within the next day or two.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it the case that the Government is planning as one of its highest category legislative priorities this session the passage of a defence call-out Bill to clarify the position of the military when called in aid of the civil power, as notoriously happened in the aftermath of the Hilton bombing? Is it the case that the Government will attempt to introduce and pass such legislation prior to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting later this month, notwithstanding the now very few parliamentary days available for consideration of what will obviously be a very sensitive matter?

—I do not have any knowledge of any plans for the urgent passage of legislation of this kind. I will make inquiries about it and find out whether there is some information which I do not have but which Senator Evans may have.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister refresh himself from the confidential Cabinet paper describing the legislative priorities for this session and, in particular, category one of that paper?
—I will do better than that. I will refresh myself from up to date matters and not some stuff that has been leaked to newspapers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Under the new health scheme a health care card is available for six months. I have been informed by the Department of Social Security that the qualifying income will be calculated on the amount earned in the four weeks prior to an application. I ask the Minister: What special arrangements have been made for casual workers who may have a large income for the four weeks prior to an application but little or no income for the following months and whose average earnings for the year would be less than the specified qualifying amounts?

—The honourable senator correctly indicates in his question that when an application is made for a health care card on the basis of low income the assessment will be made on the basis of the income in the four preceding weeks. If somebody applied and their income in the four preceding weeks was higher than the limits, a card would not be issued. The exception to that is the case of people who are self-employed where a different procedure is adopted and the income over a longer period-I think a full year-can be taken into account. So, there is an attempt to deal with people who may have quite cyclical income because of their self-employment. But in the case of somebody who is in the sort of factual situation indicated by the honourable senator there would be no problem if the person needed medical attention during a period in which there had been a lowering of income because, of course, there is an entitlement to apply after one has sought medical attention. In any four-week period where there is a qualification a person can apply for a health care card. So, if a person applied after a period of high income and was told that he could not have a card but subsequently in a period of low income sought medical attention he would be able to apply even if he did so after he had sought medical attention.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. No doubt the Minister's attention has been drawn to the many reports that an outbreak of food poisoning had occurred in the State of Victoria and that the State Health Commission had warned people not to eat any salami produced by Tibaldi Small Goods (Australia) Pty Ltd as well as to further reports that three other companies which produce salami had found bacteria in the salami produced. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether any steps have been taken to identify meat used in the production of these or other smallgoods and whether any species test has been taken from meat or meat by-products sold on the Australian home market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the reports of difficulties with salmonella food poisoning that resulted from the consumption of certain smallgoods in Victoria. The Victorian health authorities took action in that regard and traced the problems experienced with food poisoning to the contamination of salami sausages prepared by Tibaldi. Appropriate measures have been taken to correct that situation.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of any action being taken and I have no information with me as to whether action was taken to identify the specific meat which was involved and whether there was any species testing. No doubt that question arises out of the subsequent problems which have arisen with respect to export meats. It may be a matter more within the province of my colleague the Minister for Health, but I will make inquiries of the Minister for Primary Industry and get a response for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO MEAT SUBSTITUTION

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware that a senior Minister of the Queensland Government has said publicly that the Government of that State will refuse to participate in the royal commission to be set up to investigate the various scandals associated with the meat industry? Is the Minister aware that there are more than strong rumours that most of the kangaroo meat and possibly some of the donkey meat that has been exported came from Queensland? Is the Minister also aware that the owner of one of the larger kangaroo meat treatment facilities in Queensland recently disappeared in very mysterious circumstances? In view of the above facts, will the Australian Government take appropriate steps to persuade the Queensland Government to co-operate with the royal commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

By this Bill the Government seeks to provide for the confidentiality of personal information collected during the conduct of the epidemiological study of Vietnam veterans and when necessary other Government sponsored epidemiological studies.

Honourable senators will recall that last year my predecessor as Minister for Veterans' Affairs the Honourable Evan Adermann announced the Government's intention to conduct a scientific study of the possible effects of exposure to herbicides on Vietnam veterans and their children. A pilot study is well under way. Its purpose is not to yield findings relating to possible effects of herbicides but to test a number of possible ways of carrying out a major survey. It is being carried out on a small sample of veterans living in Sydney and their families.

Some of the questions being tested in the pilot study and which might also be asked in a later major survey are on personal subjects such as drug abuse and interpersonal relations. Some of the answers given by the veterans or members of their families might bear on any claims a veteran might have for compensation or for repatriation benefits. Still other answers if disclosed might affect their opportunity for employment in particular occupations, or could be used to their detriment in courts.
A number of veterans have expressed reservations about participation in any study where absolute confidentiality of information cannot be guaranteed.

The Government accepts the fact that for epidemiological studies to have scientific validity, response rates must be high. The concerns over the confidentiality of the pilot study indicate that unless confidentiality is guaranteed, the Vietnam veterans study will meet with a significant degree of non-response.

The Bill therefore would provide for the confidentiality of all information collected in the course of a study that is identifiable with particular persons. Clause 4 of the Bill would create an offence with a maximum penalty of $1,000 or imprisonment for 6 months for the unauthorized disclosure of personal information. This restriction on the divulgence of personal information would extend to the disclosure of the existence or non-existence of a document concerning the affairs of a person and to the disclosure of the whereabouts of such a document.

In addition, clause 8 of the Bill provides that a person who has assisted or is assisting in a study shall not be required to produce in a court documents concerning the affairs of another person acquired during the study. Similarly, there can be no compulsion to divulge to a court personal information acquired during the study.

This prohibition would not however extend to the production of documents to the Ombudsman. I think that it is proper to allow access by the Ombudsman for the purposes of an investigation which he might make following a complaint.

I draw honourable senators' attention to clause 7 of the Bill. That clause would provide that in a few limited circumstances it would not be an offence to divulge information. Under that provision information might be divulged
To the person who provided the information in the first place, or
To the person to whom the information relates provided that where the information deals with more than one person, the permission of all the persons involved has been obtained.

Clause 7 would not give a right to the information. It will simply provide that it will not be an offence to provide the information in those circumstances. A person's rights to information would be provided under the proposed Freedom of Information Act. That Act would of course protect the information if it would be a breach of confidence to make it available.
Although all personal information is protected from disclosure in a court, clause 11 would permit the publication or disclosure to a court of conclusions, statistics or procedures used in a study.
Clause 12 would provide that in the case of the Vietnam veterans study, the new Act would extend to information acquired, and documents prepared or obtained, before the commencement of the Act.

Although expressed to apply to the Vietnam veterans study the confidentiality ensured by this legislation will be a valuable tool in the conduct of other Government sponsored epidemiological studies. The legislation has therefore been drafted to allow other studies conducted by or on behalf of the Commonwealth to be declared by regulation as studies to which the confidentiality provisions apply. The provisions would also apply to information acquired and documents prepared or obtained before the commencement of the relevant regulation.
Mr President, this Bill is an important measure and essential to the success of the Vietnam veterans study and similar epidemiological studies. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the adjournment of the debate last evening, I was pointing out that the Government's intention in introducing this sales tax legislation was to broaden the taxation base and to take the emphasis away from personal income tax and place further emphasis on indirect taxation. I indicated also the percentage of tax revenue that Australia and other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries derived from indirect taxation. I pointed out that Australia derived 6.7 per cent of its tax revenue from this source compared with France, for example, which had the highest rate at 23.7 per cent. I endorse the principle of sales tax as a legitimate way in which the Government should raise revenue. However, I pointed to some problems associated with the way the sales tax had been introduced and the confusion and disruption created, particularly in South Australia, as well as other parts of the country. I illustrated by way of example a pharmaceutical wholesaler who attempted, by telephoning the Australian Taxation Office in Adelaide, to find a list of goods to which this 2 1/2 per cent increase would apply, only to learn the office did not have a list available. He was placed in a rather awkward position. His position was not isolated by any means as I have had a number of letters through my office, telephone calls and personal representations demonstrating that other people have been caused the same confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: I also indicated that it was unrealistic to expect businesses to cope immediately with decisions first announced the night before. For example businesses had to have invoices reprinted at considerable expense and they faced long delays in having computers reprogrammed and so on. I highlighted this confusion through individual examples and from the advice given to me by the Sydney Sales Tax Discussion Group. The South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry also made comment on this matter in the Press soon after the Budget was announced. I will quote from the article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 22 August. It stated:
The SA Chamber of Commerce and Industry yesterday urged the Federal Government to delay the introduction of the increases sales tax announced in the Budget until January 1.
The chamber's general manager Mr A. C. Schrape said if the Government could not delay the tax introduction, it should consider introducing the tax progressively.
The decision to introduce a sales tax of 17 1/2 per cent on 20 previously exempt items, and to increase the rate from zero to 30 per cent on one item, was causing confusion in the business community.

Also a number of manufacturers, faced with what in effect was a 17 1/2 per cent price rise, were finding substantial cancellations of orders, which was disrupting production and causing economic losses.
Mr Schrape said the chamber agreed the sales tax increases on the 21 items were justifiable on equity grounds, but it condemned the heavy-handed manner in which they had been introduced.

As a result of this widespread confusion the Treasury introduced a number of fact sheets designed to clarify many of the matters. However, in my opinion it failed in that task. In South Australia a special Press release was issued by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) at the request of myself and others in an attempt to improve the situation. It set out details of when the taxes applied. In part it reads:
The Sales Tax on goods previously exempt from tax will be applied from midnight, December 31, 1981-that is, they will apply from the first day of January 1982.

As a result of this release articles appeared in the Adelaide newspapers. However, far from having the placating and clarifying effect, they raised more questions. When looking at a list prepared by the sales tax office of previously exempt goods now taxable, glace fruit appeared. In the light of the Treasurer's release just quoted we would assume that this item was not to be subject to tax until 1 January 1982. Yet this was not the case. This exempt item became taxable from Wednesday 19 August.

I believe also that the changes to the legislation have thrown up more anomalous situations of the type they were intended to overcome. Another anomalous area relates to manufactured pet food. One letter I received within the last fortnight from a pet shop owner highlights this point. He related how manufactured pet foods such as boned kangaroo meat is to be taxed at 17 1/2 per cent. Yet the same meat, unpackaged and sold either by butchers or supermarkets over the counter, will not be subject to the tax. Again, he related how plain bird seed will be subject to 2 1/2 per cent tax but if it is mixed in parrot or canary seed it will be liable to a 17 1/2 per cent tax. Clearly, these situations appear anomalous and discriminatory against the small pet shop owner and manufacturers of pet foods. Of course, what he must keep in mind is that these areas are employers of people.

Another area that I believe should receive urgent consideration relates to the circumstances of farmers using grain carting vehicles. Under the changes, as I understand it, a 17 1/2 per cent tax has been imposed upon, 'motor vehicles of the kinds ordinarily used on public roads when used in grain carting'. The reasoning behind this move was that in many circumstances exemptions were claimed for vehicles-including the so-called ordinary vehicles only used in grain carting part of the time. Yet the implementation of the measure will burden a farmer in pursuit of his livelihood. A York Peninsula farmer was written to me explaining how after 23 years his old truck had irreparably broken down during last years harvest. Having failed in an attempt to purchase a suitable second hand replacement he is now faced with a 17 1/2 per cent tax on any new vehicle he buys. In his letter he stated:
As you know, in all cases, increased costs are passed onto the consumers, but in the case of primary producers there is no one to pass these costs onto.

I think that decision to increase sales tax on such equipment appears unjust on the face of that complaint. Perhaps the most crucial consequence for South Australia is in regard to the decision to impose a 17 1/2 per cent sales tax on glace fruit. This particular item has not been the subject of sales tax up to now. It has been classified, and I think should remain classified, as a food rather than a confectionary. I have written to the Treasurer pointing this out and making the point that it is a significant industry in South Australia. There are three main producers of glace fruits in Adelaide. They purchase Riverland products and until now have competed successfully against overseas imports. I think the Budget decision will jeopardise the industry. Many of the concerns of the glace fruit industry were set out in a submission sent to the Treasurer after the announcement of the increase. Last night I showed the submission to Senator Button. He agreed with my proposition that that submission and a table indicating the fruit purchased from these three companies should be incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate these documents.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
SUBMISSION OF A CASE FOR REPLACING 'GLACE FRUIT' ON THE LIST OF EXEMPT FOODSTUFFS FOR SALES TAX PURPOSES

Under the proposed amendments to the Sales Tax Act set out in the Federal Budget Glace Fruits has been placed in the schedule of items attracting 17 1/2 per cent tax to correct ''anomalies/inconsistencies''. We submit:
(1) That putting it on this list is creating an anomaly or inconsistency, not correcting an existing one.

(2) As Foodstuffs in general are exempt from tax and as Glace Fruit, as manufactured by the South Australian industry, is basically fruit,-it consists of 50 per cent fresh fruit and natural sugars, with 50 per cent of added cane sugars and glucose-it must be exempt.

The fact that the finished product is predominantly fruit is the reason that exemption was granted, pursuant to the submission to the Sales Tax authorities when commercial productions commenced in the 1945/1946 season.

The wage bills associated with those three organisations are $552,337 a year at Berri, $296,834 at Adelaide and $300,829 at Angaston. I noted last week in the Adelaide Advertiser an announcement that one order worth $12,000 had already been cancelled and that others were sure to follow. The increases have placed in jeopardy this industry which last year had domestic and overseas sales of $7.5m and which, as I have already said, collectively paid in labour costs $1.15m a year to a work force of 300 workers.

SPEECH.PARA: The indiscriminate application of these rates will have disproportionate effects upon some sections of the population. I refer particularly to home buyers, whom they will severely affect. It is estimated that the 2 1/2 per cent increase in the sales tax on building materials could add between $1,000 and $3,000 to the cost of an average house. That would be on top of the recent increases in home loan interest rates. It will obviously affect also the building industry. One interested party stated in a letter:

The one major exception to the investment stimulus which will be provided by increased sales tax may be the housing industry, and this may have been specifically intended by the framers of the Budget.
I do not agree with that; I think the party concerned feels somewhat cross about it. The letter continued:
The Housing Industry Association estimates that sales tax on building materials will add between $1,000 and $3,000 to the cost of a new home.
The Master Builders' Federation of Australia claims that the increases:
are specifically intended to hit an industry that does not enjoy the incentives or bounties or other protections given to manufacturing and primary producers.
Again, that criticism is perhaps a little severe but one genuinely put forward in the emotional situation that the increased sales tax has created. The Master Builders' Federation also states:

it must result in a further fall in the number of houses built . . . it will increase the cost of houses, hospitals, schools as the costs cannot be absorbed and will have to be passed on to consumers.

Much of the reasoning for the move has not been spelt out and claims such as the ones I have mentioned require explanation. The increases will particularly affect young married couples with children, and single parent families. Apart from suffering the effects of increased housing costs, they will have to cope with the increased tax on shoes and clothing. We all know the high cost of clothing growing children. This latest increase will add to the financial burden of parents. This is especially true of those who have children attending school. Parents will be faced with not only an additional cost for school uniforms but also a tax on stationery, books and magazines.

I said earlier that I would refer again to the letter to me from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on the sales tax issue. I incorporated that letter in Hansard last evening. In the second paragraph Mr Howard wrote:
I feel that I must emphasise that the sales tax legislation has been, in much the same basic format as it is today, in operation for more than 50 years.
He went on to state:
Increases in rates of sales tax have never operated retrospectively.
The Treasurer then detailed changes in sales tax rates since 1961. In mentioning the 2 1/2 per cent increase contained in the 1964 Budget, he wrote:
The new rate operated on and after 12 August 1964. The relevant Bills received the Royal Assent on 5 November 1964.
Obviously, that is in effect retrospective legislation. Further, the explanatory memorandum to the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1-9) 1981 states, in relation to clause 2 of the Bills:

By this clause of each Bill, the amending Acts will come into operation on 19 August 1981. This accords with normal practice for changes in the rates of sales tax. But for clause 2, the amending Act would-by reason of sub-section 5 (1A) of the Acts Interpretation Act-come into operation on the twenty-eighth day after the date of Assent.

It would thus appear that special provision is being made in the sales tax Bills to permit retrospective application. Further, it should be recognised that certain sales tax charges are not to be put into practice until 1 January 1982. According to the Treasurer, this is being done, so that Government administrative arrangements can be organised and so that business can gear up to cope with the changes. Yet, at the same time, the Treasurer says that this could not be done for all sales tax increases because there would be a massive buying up of goods. On the one hand, he states one thing but in respect of other goods, seems to be contradicting himself. Perhaps mass purchasing of goods will occur up to 1 January 1982. The Treasurer should extend this principle and allow industry and his Department time to come to grips with all sales tax increases. It seems to me that the whole thing was hastily conceived and that proper regard was not paid to the flow-on effects throughout the community.

I suggest that, just because we have been making bad mistakes for 50 years in this particular matter, that sort of practice should not continue. I have said before that I am supportive of sales tax as an alternative to increasing personal income tax. I think that is a wise move so far as the Government is concerned. However, I felt it was imperative that I point out the difficulties associated with an indiscriminate approach to this matter, and the need to research fully the implications for the community at large-particularly, as I have already mentioned, the plight of young families and those people in the categories to which I referred earlier.

I hope that the Government in future will have regard to what I have had to say and to what a lot of people have had to say, through the media, on this matter. They include supporters of the Government, chambers of commerce and industry and others who have been loyal to us for a long time. They have expressed their concern. I would like to think that in future the disruption and disorganisation amongst industry which can occur when these sorts of measures are contemplated will be avoided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These sales tax Bills have to be justified by the Government on their own merits, a task which was clearly not embarked upon with very much enthusiasm by Senator Jessop. The situation may have been otherwise if the Government could reasonably have been able to claim some kind of mandate from the electorate for the significant new burdens being imposed on the community by these taxes. Of course, by that I do not mean-nor does the Australian Labor Party mean-when talking of mandates-that every last detail of this kind of Bill should have been foreshadowed. What I do mean is that if the Government wants to claim immunity from parliamentary scrutiny of these Bills, if it wants to claim immunity from amendment for them, if it wants to claim immunity from rejection for them, it should have given, at or before the last general election, some broad indication of its intention to rely more on indirect taxes. Of course, the Government did nothing of the kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Early in 1979, after the major internal investigation then carried out, it expressly ruled out as too inflationary any increase in indirect taxes. It remained quite silent on the whole question in the run up to the 1980 Federal elections. It explicitly ruled out again any increase in indirect taxes or change in the indirect tax base prior to the Queensland election which followed last year's Federal election. For good measure in March of this year it ruled out yet again, as too inflationary, any across-the-board increase in indirect tax. Far from obtaining any kind of endorsement for the approach involved in this package of legislation, the Government rather has embarked upon what looks in retrospect to be nothing more or less than a systematic campaign of deception.

If we look at the merits of these Bills, as we should, it is apparent that they leave very much to be desired. Senator Jessop, in his speech just concluded, made a very effective critique of one aspect of the legislation, namely, the hopelessly disorganised, confused and dislocating mode of implementation of the changes to the tax law involved in these Bills. Yesterday Senator Walsh in his contribution looked at the macroeconomic and fiscal management implications of these legislative proposals and indicated against that general perspective, just how disastrous and unfair they in fact are. What I want to do quite briefly, because the task has been done very ably elsewhere particularly in the contributions to the debate from Labor spokesmen in the other place, is to focus on the regressive implications for the community of this package of legislation. Like any package of indirect taxes this package, of course, does have a regressive impact, a point that Senator Jessop in his evaluation of the merits of the legislation chose either to ignore or overlook. He certainly did not regard it as anything of any consequence.

It is evident that these sales tax Bills are no exception to the notorious general rule of regressivity so far as indirect taxes are concerned to the extent that no attempt has been made to confine the impact of the legislation to luxuries rather than necessities. Rather, the provisions of the taxing clauses in these Bills bite equally in their operation right across the whole of the community. The kinds of goods that are the subject of these Bills are, with few exceptions, those goods that have to be purchased by people at all levels in the community. People right across the community will pay exactly the same dollar sum-whatever their income level. Whether they are unemployed school leavers on $36 a week or the Prime Minister on $2,000 a week they will make exactly the same dollar and cents contribution to the revenue in respect of the goods that they purchase.

The provisions of this package of legislation operate at several different levels. The first element of the package are the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9). The effect of these is to impose an all-round increase of 2 1/2 per cent on the existing sales tax categories. That means in the first place a doubling of sales tax on such everyday items as furniture, crockery, glassware, cutlery, washing machines, vacuum cleaners, radiators, toasters, kettles, brooms, garbage cans, floor coverings, blinds, bedding, light fittings and candles-goods which clearly are items in every household in the nation and which are important in people's daily expenditure patterns. They are the kinds of expenditures that simply cannot be avoided.

Moving to the second level of taxation that is accomplished by this group of Bills, we see that the sales tax on cars is to increase from 15 per cent to 17 1/2 per cent which will add something like $150 to the price of an average four-cylinder car and around $180 to the price of an average six-cylinder car. Again, even at the top level of taxation of 27 1/2 per cent, which is now to be increased to 30 per cent-the so-called luxury category-we find subsumed such everyday items as shaving goods, combs and brushes which I think hardly come within the description, except perhaps for you, Mr Acting Deputy President, of luxuries. To the extent that things like radio and television are encompassed by this highest level of taxation, it reflects a rather outmoded view in this community as to what in fact are luxuries as distinct from necessities for households right around the nation.

The second grouping of Bills in this very large package before us are the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981. These Bills are especially iniquitous to the extent that they impose for the first time sales tax on a whole group of items hitherto exempt. This is the notorious group of provisions which is to impose a tax at 2 1/2 per cent now, but of course it is wholly plausible that this is but the thin edge of what will become a very large fiscal wedge indeed. This package of provisions taxes for the first time such crucially ordinary articles as clothing and shoes. There is also the whole category of building materials, as large and diverse as that is, with the result taking into account what I had said previously about the increase in sales tax on furniture, that it has been reliably estimated by the building industry that the additional cost for building and furnishing a new house will be something like $1,000.

This group of Bills taxes for the first time packaging and wrapping papers which are of course relevant to foodstuffs. Even though foodstuffs remain exempt on the face of it from the operation of these Bills, the packaging with which they are surrounded will not be so exempt. That will have a small but cumulative effect on the price of groceries and other foodstuffs.

There is also the particularly iniquitous taxation of books, newspapers and magazines for the very first time in the country and what appears to be for the very first time in any Anglo-Saxon country. Hitherto it had been thought absolutely unconscionable to embark upon anything that could be described as taxation of knowledge or information. That inhibition is not one that has in any way overcome this Government, perhaps inevitably given the kind of insensitive crew it has in these matters. The result is that the book publishing industry, which is already in some difficulties, will be placed under additional strain. A further result is the prospect of the disappearance literally of a very large number of small magazines, particularly small literary magazines, which are always struggling for survival in the market-place. Most of these, having already set their subscription rates for the next 12 months or so, cannot adjust at this late stage to take account of the extra costs that will be involved and certainly they cannot carry them. This whole question of the tax on books, newspapers and magazines is one that will be taken up later in this debate by the shadow minister for the arts, Senator Ryan, and deservedly so because it needs an enormous deal of attention brought to it because of the extraordinary, unprecedented and insensitive character of this imposition.

The third and final category of taxes imposed by this package of legislation relates to the redress, so called, of anomalies that have previously existed. A pretty one-sided form of redress has been adopted with some 34 different items being covered by the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill. Some 29 of the items involve increases in taxation and only five in fact redress anomalies by way of a decrease in taxation. The overall result is that something like $142m in new revenue will be fed into the Government coffers in the next financial year. Among the categories of items of goods, many of them again satisfying this description of goods which are purchased by people right across the community spectrum including those at the lowest income level, that are now to be taxed for the first time at a rate of 17 1/2 per cent going up to 30 per cent are pet foods, insecticides, confectionery of various kinds including, as Senator Jessop and others have already pointed out, glace fruits which only rather implausibly satisfy the description of a confectionery rather than a foodstuff. Also oil for the car is now to be taxed for the very first time at 17 1/2 per cent. Even in this category we find things like picture tubes for television sets are going to be taxed for the first time. Perhaps it is arguable whether television sets can be described as a luxury or a necessity these days, but what is clear is that picture tubes are to be taxed, and taxed at a rate of 30 per cent which will result in the cost of an average television set increasing by some $80.

In looking at the impact of this legislation it can be seen that it operates in a way that is thoroughly iniquitous, thoroughly inhumane and thoroughly insensitive to the real financial needs and the real financial pressures that are already on a very large segment of the community. The only categories of goods that now escape the sales tax net altogether are food, medicine and wine. It is a real question, given the attitude of this Government, as to how much longer they will escape the net.

There are other inequities associated with the operation of the system, one of which deserves a brief mention; that is, the differential burden that is being borne in the operation of this kind of legislation by those living in rural and regional communities around this country. That differential or additional burden follows from the fact that there is a very large freight component in most of the goods that are purchased by such people. To the extent that sales tax is determined on the price at which goods pass from wholesale to retail and that the freight component is for the most part built into the wholesale price of goods, certainly when goods are delivered for distribution to major regional centres, the tax is payable not only on the good itself but also on the percentage price of that good which is attributable to the freight cost. That represents, as I say, a differential additional slug to a group of Australian taxpayers who are all too long-suffering in so many other respects. It is a slug which becomes particularly significant in quantitative terms when one talks about things such as building materials, and the operation of the building industry and house prices in regional centres, such as Townsville.

Many speakers in the course of this debate in the other House and no doubt in this chamber, not to mention commentators outside the Parliament, have drawn and will continue to draw attention to the inequities, inequalities, iniquities and anomalies which are involved in this package of sales tax legislation. With such voice as remains to me, I want to say a few words on a question other than the merits of the legislation with which I have been dealing; that is, the canard that opponents of the Australian Labor Party have insisted on perpetrating during the whole course of this debate-and a canard perpetrated, so far as I was concerned, in a particularly offensive and inaccurate way by Senator Missen in his contribution to the Budget debate a couple of weeks ago. I am referring, of course, to the description of the Labor Party as being hypocritical, inconsistent and acting in breach of its own long articulated principles in opposing this legislation, given the attitudes that it has so visibly espoused in the past-from 1972 to 1975-when it has been on the receiving end of legislative obstruction of its own program, particularly when it was on the receiving end of the blockage of Supply by the then Opposition in 1974 and 1975.

Like Senator Walsh, I believe that our position on this needs reiterating-in fact, it cannot be reiterated too often-to get what is really a fairly simple message into the heads of those who will not accept that we are behaving and acting as members of a party of principle. Let me state again why I think that is so by putting forward a succinct, I hope, series of propositions. Firstly, there is a clear distinction in principle between Bills on which the survival of a government depends and those on which it does not. In the former category are crucial money Bills, such as the Supply Bills which were blocked in 1974 and the Appropriation Bills which were blocked in 1975. In the latter category are not only all non-money Bills but also lesser money Bills, such as those imposing particular fees or taxes or appropriating moneys for particular limited purposes.

The second proposition is that although most Labor spokesmen, including myself, have used the expressions 'Supply Bills', 'money Bills' and 'Budget Bills' more or less interchangeably in speaking in the past of the need to limit the Senate's power, what we have always been talking about was the way in which that power was exercised in 1974 and 1975, when the money Bills in question were ones of life or death importance for the Government. The real distinction is not between 'money' and 'non-money' Bills, between 'Budget' and 'non-Budget' Bills or between 'appropriation' and 'non-appropriation' Bills. Rather it is between 'survival' and 'non-survival' Bills. I do not believe that those distinctions will be taken or treated in a merely semantic manner, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle put it yesterday, by any reasonably objective or fair-minded observer.

The third proposition relates to the language of the Constitution itself. Despite the Australian Democrats' apparent fascination with it, it is quite irrelevant to resolving the issue of principle which underlies this controversy. Nothing turns in principle on whether anything is or is not a money Bill. Section 53 of the Constitution does spell out which kinds of money Bills the Senate can initiate and which it cannot. It also identifies those money Bills which can be amended and those-for example, taxing Bills-which can merely be the subject of requests for amendment, a distinction which is important perhaps in theory but which tends to be fairly meaningless in practice. The Constitution also makes clear, as we discovered to our cost in 1975, that there is no legal barrier to the Senate delaying or rejecting outright any Bill at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the point, I suggest to you.

—I fully acknowledge that. I prefaced my remarks on this point by saying that the language of the Constitution is quite irrelevant. What matters is the moral question-the question of principle. As to that question, the Constitution is absolutely silent. If Senator Mason's intervention in this debate means that we will cease to hear from him and his colleagues this absurd preoccupation with the precise language of section 53 and this agonising as to whether some provision is within the category of money Bill referred to there, I for one will be absolutely delighted.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the fourth proposition. There is no doubt that the present sales tax Bills are in the non-survival category. The revenue that they will generate amounts to just $500m this financial year and $892m in a full financial year out of the total planned Budget receipts of $40,000m; in other words, just one-eightieth of the total this financial year. The Government, as we know, has budgeted for a surplus this year of substantially more than $500m-indeed, more than $892m. This financial year the Government has budgeted for a surplus of over $1,100m. So there is no question of government services not being paid for if these Bills are rejected, as we ask the Senate to join us in doing. For all those reasons, they cannot be described, however important they might be for the Government's financial strategy or for the brand of politics that the Government wants to communicate to the populace, as survival Bills. They are unquestionably utterly irrelevant to the question of the Government's capacity to survive.

The fifth proposition is most important. I think it is very important that the Labor Party's attitude be absolutely clearly understood. The fact that the sales tax Bills are, as I have described them, non-survival Bills is not necessarily the be-all and end-all of the matter.
