If we voted against Government legislation of this kind just because we did not like it, because we thought it was obnoxious, without having any regard to the total context of that legislation, we would not be in any more secure or attractive a moral position than was the then Opposition between 1972 and 1975 in dealing, as it did, cavalierly with all those elements in the Labor Government's legislative program which it did not like, which it found obnoxious to its own principles. The critical question for these non-survival Bills is whether the Government can reasonably claim some kind of electoral mandate-explicit or implicit; direct or indirect-for them. If it can, I believe we should, as a responsible Senate and as a responsible Opposition in the Senate, let that legislation through, however much it hurts our own perception of what is in the best interests of the community.

The sixth point I want to make is that there can be no question of a mandate of any kind for these particular sales tax Bills-direct or indirect, specific or general, or implicit or explicit. As I have said already, the possibility of more indirect taxes either as a supplement or as an alternative to income tax simply was not floated at the time of the last election, and to the extent that it has been the subject of Government statements over the last two years that concept has been specifically repudiated. The final point I make, although it is by no means the least important, is that there is a whole series of precedents in regard to revenue measures in recent Budgets which the Australian Labor Party has voted against in both Houses, without anyone raising cries of inconsistency, hypocrisy or constitutional impropriety. For example, to take just the 1978-79 Budget, the ALP opposed the income tax surcharge, the increased tax on long service leave, the abolition of the tax deduction for home loan interest, the removal of tax exemption from Commonwealth post-graduate awards and the increased excise on beer, spirits and cigarettes. As well as all those items in that Budget, we have voted against other items in other Budgets. As Senator Walsh says, during Senator Mason's tenure in this Parliament he has voted against some of these things without anyone making the claim of hypocrisy or without anyone suggesting to him that he was in breach of his statutory declaration or his principles, or whatever it is that moves him so substantially. The only thing that is different about the 1981 Sales Tax Amendment Bills is that this time there is a chance that our vote will actually mean something.

I assure the Senate that for all the various reasons I have mentioned the ALP certainly will vote, on the merits, against these Bills at the second reading stage. What action we take thereafter in the Committee stage of the Bills remains, as Senator Walsh said, to be determined in the light of further discussions among all the relevant parties and interests concerned. Whatever we do in this respect will be designed to reduce as far as humanly possible the impact on the community of these notoriously inhuman taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating today a number of Bills relating to increasing or introducing sales taxes on a variety of items, to a variety of degrees of imposition. I remind the Senate that yesterday Senator Harradine questioned the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) on the reason behind the Sales Tax Amendment Bills being put forward in the particular way they have been presented. Specifically, he asked whether she was aware that the Bills had been drafted in a form entirely different from any other form in which similar Bills have come before the Senate in the past 50 years; in other words, on this sole occasion machinery provisions along with provisions imposing taxation have been included in the one Bill. He further asked her what was the purpose of that unique step. I remind the Senate also that he had to put that question to the Minister twice before he got even half an answer. Although the Minister talked around the issue, under pressure from Senator Harradine, she seemed reluctant, despite the comments in this morning's Australian Financial Review, actually to confirm or deny Senator Harradine's suggestion that the form of the Bills was a matter of tactics; in other words, that the declaration not to block Supply or money Bills made by the Australian Democrats in the weeks prior to the election last October-I remind both Senator Walsh and Senator Evans that those declarations were signed in the weeks prior to that election and not any earlier than that--
—So you have changed your principles, have you?

—No; indeed, we have not. As I was saying, it was suggested that that declaration caused the Government to frame the Bills in such a way that they would be clearly seen as money Bills and unamendable by the Senate. Despite the Minister's reticence, it is highly likely that the pledge did have something to do with the way the Sales Tax Amendment Bills have been drafted. If this is the case, it is unfortunate, if not actually reprehensible. Despite this, for the benefit of Senator Evans and others, I must reiterate that not one of us regrets the spirit, at least, which prompted us to make that pledge when we did. On the other hand, I acknowledge that it has got us into a certain amount of difficulty in that the Australian Labor Party and others seem to be unable to understand why we did it. I am not questioning Senator Evans's principles. We all know he is a man of principle although, as he has pointed out to the Senate, he is not the only man of principle in the ALP. I accept that, too.
—Bless you.
—I am sure the honourable senator appreciates my generosity. I do not know how long it will last.
—I have not experienced much of it before.

—That probably is also true. Despite the sophistry indulged in by Senator Evans and the disclaimers by Senator Walsh last night, I am afraid, that as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, both the events of 1974, with regard to the Medibank levy, and of 1975, with regard to the blocking of Supply, became relevant factors for us in making the decisions we have made.
—They were relevant to your leader; he supported them in both years.
—That just goes to show that there are occasions when honourable men can change their minds.
—It happened every day, in your case.

—No, that is not so. I take the opportunity to engage in some backchat with Senator Button because he insists that we change our minds daily. I understand his leader changed his mind within the 10 minutes it took to go from one radio station to another. I suppose that makes the Australian Labor Party one up on us. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, the actions of Malcolm Fraser and others in 1974 and 1975 were nothing short of a disgraceful abuse of parliamentary power. That the Australian electorate subsequently appeared to endorse those actions at the polling booth does not make right the wrong perpetrated by the Liberal Party of Australia. It is therefore of no credit to the ALP, although I am sure that its members are acting within their principles as they see them, that it is hell-bent on taking or manufacturing the first opportunity which presents itself to get even. Even worse is the point scoring exercise undertaken by some members of that party in their actions on a matter over which they had control when they were in Government but did nothing about. If, when the ALP was in office, it had taken any steps to lower sales taxes generally it would be possible to take the present huffing and puffing of its members far more seriously than we are able to do. Senator Evans mentioned the sales tax on cars. I remind him that in 1975 it was the ALP which increased this tax, and it did the same thing in 1973 in relation to non-alcoholic beverages. Furthermore, if in all the debate in the Press lately any member of the Labor Party had pledged to remove or lower sales taxes in the highly likely event of that party winning the next election, his integrity would not now be called into question. In the equally likely event that we of the Democrats are in the same position during the reign of a Labor government as we are in with this Liberal Government, our actions on its budgetary initiatives will be the same.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, if the ALP had elected to be selective in its opposition to the sales taxes, one could assume that it had taken the time to think the issue through. That has not occurred. This must puzzle any thinking member of the public. I can assure the Labor Party that there are a great many thinking members of the public. In fact, I would like to assure the Press, too, that that is the case. The public will be puzzled because the Labor Party is agonising-I unashamedly take Senator Evans's word that he used earlier about us-over the imposition of a higher sales tax on such things as furs, gold-plated cutlery, jewellery, cosmetics, artificial flowers and fruits and the machinery used by multinational mining companies. This hardly fits the Labor Party image of being a party for the working man.

The Australian Democrats do not intend to compete with the ALP for the title of the new Australian conservatives. We have no wish to win the Toorak vote by bribing the Toorak voters by preventing an increase in the proposed tax on furs and other luxuries used by them to flaunt their wealth. If members of the ALP wish to do that, so be it. The decision is theirs. But I suspect it is a useless attempt on their part to capture an exceedingly elusive market.
The Democrats' policy on sales tax is clearly defined although people like Laurie Oakes do not seem to be able to read further than they wish.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did eventually.

—I have not seen any evidence of that yet. Our Party states quite clearly in its policy that it supports the imposition of indirect taxation, provided it is in conjunction with certain income tax concessions. But we do not under any circumstances support the increase in tax rates on the necessities of life. I remind the Senate that what the present Government is doing is directly contrary to Articles 25 and 26 of the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. For the benefit of honourable senators who are not familiar with those Articles-I suspect there is an extremely large number of them who have never heard of them-I will read them to the Senate. Item 1 of Article 25 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care . . .

As Senator Evans pointed out, the Liberal Government has not as yet got around to putting a tax on food and medical care. But, one presumes, it is only a matter of time before that occurs. Item 2 of Article 25 states:
Motherhood and childhood are entitled to special care and assistance . . .
Item 1 of Article 26 states:
Everyone has the right to education . . .
But I contend that one cannot be educated if one does not have access to information. Item 2 of Article 26 states:

Education shall be directed to the full development of the human personality and to the strengthening of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It shall promote understanding, tolerance and friendship among all nations, racial or religious groups, and shall further the activities of the United Nations for the maintenance of peace.

None of those things is possible if adequate information is not available to all people and if it is not available to them at a reasonable price. I would therefore, of course, have to endorse-quite willingly-Senator Evans's condemnation of the new tax on information and on the other things that we define as the necessities of life. Senator Harradine, I understand, is in a similar position. We gather that he intends to move amendments in order to make sure that those sorts of things are not hit by a new tax. Senator Button has described Senator Harradine's amendments as ingenious. I prefer to think of them as being rather exotic. There is certainly nothing the matter with them. We support his intention. We find, however, that it is unnecessarily complicated. Nevertheless, we commend him for what he is planning to do, but believe that in the first instance at least there is an easier way to achieve the results that Senator Harradine is aiming for.

The Senate, as we all know-constitutional arguments aside-has a legitimate piece of machinery available to it other than simply blocking the legislation in the first instance. It can, and has in the past, and will in the future, refer parts of legislation back to the House of Representatives requesting that it amend anomalous or objectionable sections. We signal quite clearly our distaste-indeed, our contempt-for the new sales tax impositions. We have also indicated our proposed actions. The Australian Democrats indicating proposed actions on anything has proven in the past to be somewhat disastrous. The ALP has a tendency to sweep our initiatives out from under us. I think that on those grounds alone people can see why we are loth to signal our intentions too early. We have, of course, been given no reason to change our minds about the legislation. We will refer certain sections of certain of the sales tax Bills back to the House of Representatives and if they are sent back--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do when they come back?

—I ask Senator Evans to wait just a little. I understand from him that his voice is failing. I ask that he let it fail completely for a little while longer. We intend to refer certain sections of certain of the sales tax Bills back to the House of Representatives. If they are sent back to this place with undue haste, they will go back again. Our decision was taken on the proviso that sufficient time be given for public protest and debate, a factor I might add which only the Australian managed to pick up at the time. I commend Russell Schneider for his ability to see the subtlety of the tactic.
—Most perceptive.

—He is a most perceptive journalist, although I am sure it was accidental. We intend, at the appropriate time-and it will be a time that the Senate decides upon-to seek the co-operation of so-called Liberal rebels in the other place in rejecting the taxes imposed on previously exempt items. I dare say that there are some rebel Liberal members in this place who may be persuaded to support the view that we take. Certainly Senator Jessop, in his speech earlier today, expressed disquiet. The problem, of course, is to persuade enough Liberals to put their votes where their mouths are and do something about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats intend to request the House of Representatives to amend the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) by deleting a number of items on which these Bills impose a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax, and which were previously exempt under the Sales Tax (Classifications and Exemptions) Act. The amendments requested will delete certain goods from the amendments, thus leaving them exempt. They are covered by various items in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 and include No. 51, books; No. 54, newspapers-and those of course mean the dissemination of information- Nos 82-90F inclusive, covering building materials, specifically those building materials for use in private dwellings; No. 96, wrapping materials; and No. 120, clothing and footwear but not drapery, et cetera. It is our intention, therefore, to support the second reading of these Bills in order to be able to put those amendments during the Committee stage of the debate on the Bills.

I remind the Senate that the taxes to which I have referred do not come into effect until 1 January, unlike those which increase taxes on luxuries or close loopholes in the sales tax law. There is, therefore, no need for haste. There is no need for the indecent hurry exhibited by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to force these Bills through the Parliament. We all know that there are many Liberals with principles. Senator Evans is not the only member of this chamber with principles. The ALP is not the only party with principles, nor are we making any assertions to that effect. There are members of the Liberal party with principles. It is simply a matter of persuading them to exhibit those principles in public. Therefore, we are aiming to get these decent Liberals to object in the party room and on the floor of the House to the tax imposition on clothing, building supplies and other things which we regard as essentials, things which, unlike furs, artificial flowers, gold-plated cutlery and so on affect the average working man or woman and his or her family. Referring those clauses back to the other House will give those Liberals with a conscience-and I am assured by the Liberal party that there are one or two Liberals with consciences--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not enough, is it?

—Let us hope there are several dozen Liberals with consciences. Let us give them, however many there are in the lower House, the chance to press their case in the party room. In addition, the referral back to the other House will give members of the public the opportunity to put their case to their parliamentary representatives. That process indeed makes Parliament receptive and accessible to the general public. Most importantly, however, the referral of those clauses back to the other House will prevent the Government from precipitating this country into a state of confusion by giving the Labor Opposition the opportunity to block the sales tax Bills in their entirety. I contend that stability of government is a vitally important element of democracy, whether the ALP wants it or believes it at the moment.
—You can understand why the Democrats do not want an election now.

—I remind Senator Evans that our percentage of the vote as shown in today's Age, has rocketed up since the Budget. Not only has the Labor Party's gone up but so has ours. I think there is a lesson to be learnt from that.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it incredible that a political party which asserts a belief in the principle of a four-year fixed term parliament and an end to the Senate's powers should want, through the Senate, to cause a situation which allows for an early election. I know that Senator Evans has been a proponent of a four-year fixed term and of curtailing severely the Senate's powers. I would have used the word 'emasculate' if it were not for the fact that we happen to have a record number of women in the Senate. Therefore, the term is probably not appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hysterectomate?

—I am not so sure about that. I point out to the Senate, the public and the Press that it is very easy to court popularity. It is not so easy to be seen as being responsible. If, in opting for the latter, the Australian Democrats suffered, that would be a most unfortunate occurrence. However, it was our decision not to reject all the Bills but only those imposing a new tax on the necessities of life. It was not an easy decision. However, we stick to it. The ALP can ridicule us. The Press can paint us as an odd lot. None of that matters. What does matter is that this Government does not proceed with an action which runs completely contrary to the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights without the public being given the opportunity to debate the issue fully and to pressure their local members of parliament on both sides of the House fully and without the country as a whole being given the opportunity to look at the issue and make its decisions and feelings known to the people who have ultimate responsibility-the Liberal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I wish to support the sales tax amendment Bills. Today we are cognately debating three groups of Bills. The first group increases by 2 1/2 per cent the existing rates of sales tax. The new rates of sales tax will be operative from the date of the Budget. It is necessary for these rates to operate from the date of the Budget as otherwise not only would the Government lose revenue but also the more wealthy section of the community would have an opportunity to stock up to the disadvantage of those who are less well off. The next group seeks to correct certain anomalies and inconsistencies in the present sales tax laws. I will give one example. Is it right that alarm clocks should attract a lower rate when compared with ordinary clocks and watches?

SPEECH.PARA: The third Bill imposes 2 1/2 per cent tax on a number of items which were not subject to sales tax. These items include clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers, packaging, wrapping, hand tools et cetera. A number of items were previously exempt. I will give a couple of examples. Traditionally, saddlery and harnesses were associated with primary production. This was the case when the Act was introduced in the 1930s. In recent years their use has changed substantially and these items are now used predominantly for recreational and sporting purposes. Therefore, it is appropriate that sales tax be applied to these sorts of items which were previously tax free.

Let us move now to the mining industry. There were certain types of motor vehicles and trucks which could have been used on ordinary roads but which were exempt from taxation if used in the mining industry. Our Government believed that in this day and age it was no longer appropriate that the mining industry should be entitled to exemptions on these sorts of ordinary vehicles when such exemptions were not open to other sectors of industry. There was another case where, for example, forklift trucks used by stevedores were exempt. This was in line with the fact that this type of equipment was exempt when used on board ships. But with changes in stevedoring and the like, forklift trucks are now an integral part of the stevedoring and transport industry and they should attract a tax rather than be exempt.

I think the community has come to recognise that there is a need for a change in the tax mix, that is, a change in the ratio of indirect to direct taxation. For example, in 1975 the Asprey Taxation Review Committee made a comprehensive review of the taxation system. It came to the general conclusion that the taxation system should place a far greater reliance on taxes of goods and services by the inclusion of a broad based tax. Our Government believed that a broad based tax was not appropriate. It believed that some extensions of the sales tax system was appropriate in line with that sort of thinking.

We have not extended sales tax to services in line with the recommendations of the Asprey Committee. We have not extended it to food. I think it is important to recognise that wholesalers pay the sales tax on an ad valorem basis and, therefore, with inflation there is some adjustment to changing prices. What have we actually seen? The actual share of wholesale taxes as compared with total revenue has actually declined, particularly since 1953-54, largely because of the rapid escalation in the collection of personal income taxes. What has this led to? It has led also to a situation where many wage earners in the community do not have an incentive to work overtime because of the high penalty taxes that are imposed. It has led to a situation of a high level of tax avoidance practices. We are seeking as part of this legislation to change the sales tax mix.

The other factor is that over the years there has also been what we refer to as a narrowing of the tax base itself. This has been achieved over the years because exemptions and reclassifications have effectively reduced that base. These pieces of legislation seek to widen that base to give recognition to the findings of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee in regard to widening the impact of taxation. I remind honourable senators that while we in Australia are exempting food, apart from confectionery items-that exemption includes biscuits-overseas there is a growing acceptance of this sort of tax, even on food. The Government has been accused of being inhuman and that sort of thing. But look at most of the European countries. In the main they tax food; we do not. Admittedly some of them tax the items at a concessional rate. Look at the United States of America. The majority of its States uniformly tax food items at the retail level, but this is not the case here.

The Government regards these packages of Bills as fundamental to its overall Budget strategy. I think this must be regarded as important. It would be very dangerous if this Senate were to determine for itself those money Bills which it, but not the Government, regards as important or significant; that is, the Senate selects those Bills which the Government needs for its very survival and those which this Senate believes are not necessary for its absolute survival. This could be an inappropriate and dangerous precedent for this Senate to take upon itself the responsibility of saying which Bills are essential and of whittling away a lot of the Budget provisions it feels are not absolutely necessary. We must look at a Budget as a whole package and not as a series of unrelated items. Every item is related to the whole. Therefore we have to recognise that the Budget is a package in itself.

I know that the Opposition would very much like to see inflation rise at the expense of the Government presently in office. The Opposition could achieve this by whittling away these sales tax Bills because the effect would be to reduce the domestic surplus. That cannot be denied. Whittling away this domestic surplus would bring money supply problems and consequently affect inflation. That cannot be denied; they would be the consequences. I ask honourable senators to look at the consequences of their actions and not to look at the Budget in a piecemeal fashion.

I think we should also look at the consequences of this Senate selecting and separating a machinery section which is a component of a taxing Bill. It is well recognised that this Senate does not have the power to amend taxing legislation, but a technique which is going to be devised is that we in this Senate will attempt to pull out certain sections of a taxing Bill and call them machinery sections. I submit that inevitably in every Bill that passes through this Senate there must be some machinery sections. If those machinery sections are of a major nature the government puts them through as a separate Bill, as a machinery piece of legislation. But does this Senate have the constitutional authority to decide arbitrarily which machinery sections are appropriate to be pulled out of a taxing Bill and which are not? That leads us to the question: How far can the Senate go? I submit that the whole Budget strategy of any government could be reduced to tatters if we accept this principle whereby a Senate has power to whittle away legislation and to decide: 'Ah! This section, this word, these few lines, can be deleted and we will create another machinery Bill so that we, in our so-called honest interpretation, will not knock back a taxing Bill. We will whittle it away and effectively create another machinery Bill'. That is the actual effect of what is going to be done. The Government has to be judged by its overall Budget strategy. I think everybody, on either side of Government, can always identify a piece of legislation that does not suit his or her particular philosophy or his or her own interests. But what we have to do as a Party is stand by our overall Budget strategy and support it. This is what I am attempting to do today. I therefore believe that there is a need to change the tax mix. France, for example, relies very heavily on indirect taxation-to the extent of about 23 per cent. We have not attempted to extend this tax to the service sector. Our increase is a modest one compared with taxation levels in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries which I have mentioned. We have an increasing reliance on personal income tax which is taking away people's incentive to work. With the anticipated decline in revenue resulting from the crude oil levy we will see a need for some alternative revenue sources in the future. But, as I say, the increase is a modest one; it is not a major shift. The extra income is, I think, something like $553m so it is not large in the Budget context. Sales tax will now account in real terms for only something like 7 per cent of government receipts. A study, carried out by the Australian Taxation Office, showed that approximately 26 per cent of purchases of lower income groups are for food, but food for human consumption is exempt from sales tax. So we will find that this legislation will not have the impact it is alleged it will have by many of honourable senators opposite.

Let me look at a couple of contentious items. For example, although it is the Government's intention that sales tax be payable on books, magazines and newspapers as from 1 January 1982, it has never been the Government's intention that bibles and prayer books be subject to sales tax. I think there is a long established ruling by the Commissioner of Taxation, under item 65 of the first Schedule, which exempts items which are related to religious devotion. I also point out that schools and universities are exempt from paying sales tax on items which would have been subject to tax if they had been bought by other users. I think it is important to remember those facts.

Many honourable senators have said that there has been condemnation across the board of a lot of these sales tax increases, but I refer honourable senators to an article in the Age of 21 August, in which the Chief Executive and Managing Director of G. J. Coles and Co., Mr Bevan Bradbury, is reported as saying:
The 2.5 per cent increase in sales tax in Tuesday's Federal Budget would help build confidence and stabilise the community, . . .

Here is a person who is at the forefront of merchandising in Australia; a person in a position to know. On the other hand, we find that other companies are actually going to agree to absorb the sales tax rises. I think I should mention again that this is a fairly modest increase. It is important to state that the Federal Government alone imposes sales tax. But the tax, being a component of cost, is a deductible expense so far as income tax is concerned. It is-a single turnover commodity tax which is levied in respect of goods produced in Australia, other than exempt goods. It does not apply to secondhand goods which have gone into consumption in Australia. It is also payable on goods other than exempt goods which have been imported into Australia. I believe that it is appropriate for the Government to legislate in this area. We have to recognise that our ratio of indirect taxes compared with those levied by other countries is quite low and that it is appropriate for Australia to change its tax mix so that it becomes less reliant on personal income tax. I commend the Bills in their present form to the Senate.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Earlier today during Question Time Senator Sibraa asked me whether it was a fact that horse meat which had been discovered in Profreeze cartons carried traces of methyl violet. I answered that question on the basis of the information I then had. I have been advised in the last 10 minutes by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) that he has received further advice on this matter. He was asked a question on this matter today and recently he made a clarifying statement in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Sibraa's question today I replied that the information that is available to the Government is that the allegation is not correct, that traces of methyl violet have not been found in cartons examined so far, and that as a result that matter has not been referred to the police. Mr Nixon has told me that he received advice at half past three this afternoon from the Australian Bureau of Animal Health that the Deputy Director of Agriculture in Victoria had advised that his department had found no traces of any dyed beef in the 140C cartons which are currently impounded and being species tested. However, the Victorian department has found some small traces of dyed horse meat in these cartons and this matter is part of the current police investigations. I regret, therefore, having misled the honourable senator and the Senate in that reply. I gave the reply on the basis of the information I then had. I will seek further clarification and give a more detailed response tomorrow if that appears necessary.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1-9) 1981SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1A-9A)1981SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the package of three sales tax Bills which have been introduced into this place by the Government. It is the intention of the Opposition to oppose all three Bills outright at the second reading stage. My colleague Senator Evans has already made this clear. The taxes are iniquitous, they will be inflationary and they are not justified in any economic or social way. The range of people who will be badly affected by them is enormous. I do not propose at this stage to refer to all of them. What I would like to do is draw attention to a particularly iniquitous and inegalitarian effect of the taxes, and that is the effect on the book publishing and magazine industry of this country. I think it must be fairly clear to all Australians now that the Fraser Government is the most anti-intellectual and anti-cultural government this country has seen. I remind honourable senators of the cuts in arts funding, which have meant that by now most major theatre companies, for example, are in financial crisis, that smaller companies are going out of business or will go out of business, and that people in rural areas, such as those whom Senator Coleman represents, have less and less access to cultural activities. I remind honourable senators of the cuts in education, which have particularly affected the innovative arts education steps that were being taken during the period of Government and for a little time after the Whitlam Government. I remind honourable senators of the drastic deterioration in the output of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which again has had a most deleterious effect on intellectual and cultural life in this country and on the access of Australians living outside the metropolitan areas to the sorts of things that the ABC once could provide.

SPEECH.PARA: We really do have a very anti-intellectual government. In fact, the only serious attempt the Fraser Government has made to assist creative activity in this country has been a major botch up. I am referring, of course, to the concessions for investment in the film industry. I will not waste the time of the Senate at this point in reminding honourable senators of the incompetence, the bungling and the changes of direction that accompanied that measure. Suffice it to say at this point that the scheme is not operating; that the industry, instead of being assisted and supported by this scheme, is in chaos; and that people who depend on the industry for their livelihood are facing unemployment or erratic employment. The whole thing has been totally disastrous. The only people who have been assisted by this measure have not been the creative people-the performers, the actors and the writers-but have been the tax evaders, the brokers and so on. That scheme, chaotic as it is, really involves the sum total of what the Fraser Government has been prepared to do for the creative arts and for intellectual activity in this country. Of course, there have been cuts in research budgets and cuts in university budgets as well.

Now we have this new and particularly iniquitous tax on books and magazines. I want to make a point in line with the claimed ideology or alleged philosophy of this Government. The Government often likes to present itself as a friend of small business or as a friend of Australian business which, of course, is mostly small business. Most Australian publishing is small business. Most producers of small magazines are small business people. Yet they are the people who are going to be put out of business by this new tax on knowledge, this new tax on books and magazines. They are the people who have been in a very low profit area, usually because of commitment to a particular idea, commitment to Australian publishing, and commitment to an independent Australian intellectual life. They are the people who will be put out of business. Of course, as usual, the multinationals will move in, take up their customers and take up their operations. The multinationals will increase their monopolies. That is the sort of thing that happens again and again under the Fraser Government while it pretends to be a friend of small business. I have had many representations from small publishing houses. Clearly these tax measures will be the last straw for a lot of the small independent Australian publishing houses. I think that is a tragedy for our country.

In the history of Australia no government has ever taxed or dutied books because, as Al Knight, the President of Hyland House Publishing Pty Ltd pointed out to me in recent representations, it has been realised that such taxes are an affront to civilised society. In the early 1930s the Commonwealth Government initiated a primage duty on books. However, it was forced to withdraw this tax in the face of a widespread protest. The point has been made several times in recent weeks that no other democratic country-the kind of country with which we like to compare ourselves-taxes knowledge, taxes books. I think that point was made very colourfully by the British author, Lord Ted Willis, when he spoke recently at the National Press Club. Lord Ted pointed out that about 150 to 200 years ago riots took place in England when a stamp duty was proposed on newspapers. At that stage the British people accepted the principle that there should be no tax on knowledge. We have a government that seems so keen on the British connection and so keen on maintaining British institutions in this country, but it is a very selective keenness and it is a very selective enthusiasm for British traditions. It seems that very fine democratic principles, such as the British principle of no tax on knowledge, can be abandoned.

One of the serious things, of course, is the effect that this tax will have on employment. It is very clear that the downgrading of the whole book publishing and magazine printing industry which will result from these tax measures will result in a loss of employment in the printing area. As we all know, printers and people working in the industry have been facing increasingly high levels of unemployment because of the effect of new technologies on the printing industry. Now we have a further attack on employment not only in the printing area but also in small publishing houses and businesses concerned with the production and circulation of magazines and so on. There is also an attack on employment in all sorts of art and community activities that depend for support on being able to inform people about their activities through small magazines. We are also concerned that the tax will hit small newspapers, particularly those of the ethnic Press. Such publications also face, as a result of the Fraser Government policies, increases in general postage rates, increases in category B postage rates and increases in telephone and telecommunications charges. It is a great and unexplained irony that the Fraser Government is prepared to spend millions of dollars on ethnic television and yet is about to penalise the ethnic Press in this way.

I think the case can still be argued that the ethnic Press serves a community quite different from and much more extensive than the community that can take advantage of ethnic television because, of course, ethnic television exists only in Sydney and Melbourne whereas ethnic newspapers have been long established in this country and have given very fine service to a whole diversity of ethnic people living in Australia. I think in many cases this Press will have its existence jeopardised by this tax.

While most libraries are exempt from sales tax and from the effect of the tax on the buying of books, the effect on the purchase of newspapers and periodicals by the Australian public and non-exempt libraries will be significant and will cause a serious decline in the book publishing industry. Despite the fact that the cost of books and magazines in this country is very high Australians have a tradition, or have until now, of buying books at a very high rate. If that is to stop, which it will because of these tax measures, then the book industry will be very badly affected. I point out, in reminding the Government of the fact that Australia is isolated from the principal sources of published material in English, that the prices of books in Australia are already much higher than elsewhere. This is a matter I have raised on other occasions and will raise again in this place on many future occasions. To buy books in Australia is already a very expensive business. But to add an additional tax is, of course, totally unacceptable.

I point out that although the Government is talking about a tax of only 2.5 per cent many people who speak for the book industry have already pointed out that the effect will be more like an increase of 10 per cent. I quote Mr Richard Walsh the Managing Director of Angus and Robertson Publishers who said:
The price of books could increase by up to 10 per cent because of administrative costs associated with the Federal Government's 2.5 per cent sales tax.

I am persuaded that that will be the case. It will also be the case because many small wholesalers and retailers of books are in great confusion about what the tax will mean to them; there is a whole range of complicated procedures because schools, universities and libraries will be exempt and that will affect the wholesale buying program and so on. It is a very confusing area. Wherever there is confusion, as has been the experience in this country and elsewhere, prices go up. If people, whose livelihoods are fairly tenuous anyway, feel faced with a whole lot of increasing costs they will certainly put prices up for consumers. In fact we are dealing with something much bigger than the 2.5 per cent sales tax legislated for in the Bills before us this evening.

Perhaps the most serious point of opposition that the Australian Labor Party has for the tax on knowledge is its concern for a diversity and availability of information and access to information which is absolutely essential if democracy is to function. What will happen as a result of these measures if they are proceeded with is that there will be financial barriers in the way of citizens seeking information. By making information more expensive the Government is creating a situation where those with limited resources will be unable to obtain it. Of course this is in line with the general thrust of Fraser Government policies which is to hit hardest those with least resources.

I speak particularly about the access to learning and to text books which is something that poor families are already having enormous difficulty with. That is a situation which will deteriorate very badly. It is all very well for the rich to say, 'we can afford to pay a bit more for books' but we have a situation where the cost of education to the ordinary Australian family is being increased virtually with every government decision. We have had university fees re-established, student loans schemes coming in to replace proper support for students, and in every government school in my own electorate here in the Australian Capital Territory almost compulsory fees are charged to provide essential text books, chalk and things of that kind. We now have families hard hit with increases to the cost of books that they might like to buy to assist in their children's education. So it is a very anti-democratic measure.

I believe too that in the tax's anti-social and anti-cultural effects at least the spirit of the legislation is in breach of the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organisation convention on the free flow of educational and cultural materials. As I said, small magazines and newsletters will be put out of business. Subscriptions will decline and proprietors will be required to undertake time-consuming exercises preparing sales tax returns. Subscriptions to small magazines and newsletters contain a major component to cover postage. Will this also be taxed? Many subscribers to such magazines pay several years in advance. Is sales tax to be paid on subscriptions received before the sales tax was announced? It is clear that the sales tax will cause immense problems for small magazines and will wipe many of them out. To reiterate my point about information in a democracy, this of course will reduce the diversity of views and information and will be Australia's loss.

The time allowed for this debate I know is rather tight but I want to place on record the names of some of the organisations which have made very urgent representations to me on this matter because I feel that all their representations are serious, are to the point and ought to be responded to by the Government. I have had representations from the Bibliographical Society of Australia and New Zealand which is concerned about the effects of the tax on research material and by Forward, the New South Wales newspaper of the Uniting Church in Australia. That representation was signed by Paul Lynch, Vice-President of the Australian Religious Press Association. I have had other representations from other people concerned about the effect on religious newspapers. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has made it clear that Bibles and prayer books will continue to be exempt. That is not enough. People who are involved in organised religion are concerned with ideas that change and adapt to changes in society. Religious organisations need the opportunity to make their views known on certain political matters, for example, land rights for Aboriginals. It is not just a matter of saying to people who are members of organised religions, 'you don't have to pay tax on your Bibles and prayer books'. It is a whole range of other publishing activities about which I have had representations.

The Australian Magazine Publishers Association is taking action to resist the sales tax. Hyland House Publishing Pty Ltd has also made representations. Lloyd O'Neil Pty Ltd, another small Australian publishing house, is of the kind whose survival I believe will be seriously jeopardised by this measure. I have had a number of representations from ethnic newspapers including the Europa Kurier Publishing Group which publishes the Maltese Herald which is a weekly publication based in Bankstown and which also has a Melbourne office. The Overseas Periodicals (Aust.) Pty Ltd also has drawn to our attention the deleterious effects on the ethnic Press of these proposals. The Australian Advisory Council on Bibliographical Services has made representations.

I have had very detailed representations from the publisher of a small and very unusual magazine called Cantrills Filmnotes. That is the kind of alternative information about independent film in Australia which is of great importance to the independent Australian film industry. I am informed by the editors of this magazine that they will not be able to survive the imposition of the tax. The Library Association of Australia has condemned the proposed imposition in the Federal Budget of the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers as it places a tax on access to information. I could go on but time is short. I reiterate very simply the point that in a democracy access to knowledge should be something that all governments have as one of their primary concerns. In this country we already have too great a monopoly in the area of telecommunications. We have too little diversity in television and radio. We already have too many difficulties in the way of people seeking access to a diversity of views and knowledge.

The democratic fabric of our society has been greatly strengthened by the activities of small publishing houses-by people who bring out magazines, be they on matters of concern to ethnic communities, religious communities, political parties or relating to cultural events. We do not want a society in which there are only a very few sources of information, ideas and activities, and most of those overseas controlled. We do want in Australia an independent cultural life, an independent, strong democratic intellectual life and tradition. If we want those things, we should not place financial obstacles in the way of people's access to knowledge, or in the way of those who are in the business of providing such diversity of information and cultural activities through publishing and other means. For that particular reason, as well as for all the other reasons that my colleagues will present to the Senate during the course of this debate, I express the strongest possible opposition to the sales tax Bills, and in particular their effects on books, magazines and publishing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a senator elected by the people of Queensland, and one who wishes to represent their best interests, I must say that I am not very happy at the proposed increases in sales tax contained in these Bills. However, I feel that the Australian Labor Party is hypocritical in setting itself up in a self-righteous way to complain about sales tax. Let nobody imagine that a Labor or socialist government would be a source of lower taxes. In one year, Mr Whitlam increased the take from personal income tax by 40 per cent. The platform of the Australian Labor Party includes the re-introduction of death duties, capital gains tax and wealth tax-and no doubt, as we heard in Question Time today, also a resource rental tax. If one sells a home and makes a profit, that profit falls under the capital gains tax. In regard to a wealth tax, the value on one's property is assessed and, as it appreciates in value, one pays a certain percentage of tax. That is similar to the tax imposed in Sweden. Indeed, it is a frightening tax and I am sure that if Labor came to power it would increase taxes, certainly not lower them.

SPEECH.PARA: This is probably the first time in almost a decade that a Federal Government has shown the country something akin to a balanced Budget. It is quite an enviable example of tight, even austere housekeeping in undeniably tight times and in that respect is to be commended. Another matter for commendation is that this Government has reduced income tax from a seven-tiered to a three-tiered system. Over the years, as incomes have increased, this has no doubt meant quite a saving in tax. However, I do question the means by which our Government is achieving a balanced Budget. The increases in sales tax will lead in this country to a greater, and in many cases unbearable, burden of taxes on Australians now and in the future. Doubtless the Government is building up its surplus so that income tax cuts can be offered, probably next year. In what I believe is a wrong means of obtaining a surplus, the Government is burdening consumers with the task of providing an additional $553m through sales tax in the remainder of 1981-82, and $892m in 1982-83. What is even more disturbing is that the hoped-for income tax cuts may be mythical because total Federal taxes will not fall. We will all be paying the same amount but in a different mix of higher indirect taxes to offset lower direct taxes. The Commonwealth Government will probably then tell the States: 'What a pity that income tax has been reduced and your share along with it'. The Government will tell the States that if they want the revenue for their schools, roads, hospitals and other essential community works, they will have to impose their own income tax. That means that we will have additional income tax imposed on us at the State level. That, in my opinion, is not honest.

We have been promised tax reform by every government since that of Sir Robert Menzies. What we see is inflation pushing Australians of all income levels into higher and higher tax brackets. We see Governments, both Labor and non-Labor, obsessed with bigger and better government spending, more and more bureaucracy and more regulation. Unfortunately, we see less and less incentive for private enterprise and worker alike to be more productive. Why bother when the Federal Treasurer(Mr Howard) simply steps in and confiscates the fruits of one's labour.

We now see this further tax impost of 2 1/2 per cent, and in many cases 17 1/2 per cent, putting further pressures on low income families, reducing their buying power and crippling small businesses throughout the country. One need only look at the explanatory notes to see how many items will now be subject to sales tax at varying rates from 2 1/2 per cent to 30 per cent.

I am well aware that family allowances are to be raised by increasing by 50 per cent the rates of assistance for the third and subsequent children; also that assistance to children in institutions is to be increased. However, in my opinion, it is really a case of giving with one hand to the few and taking with the other from the many. I believe that every family, regardless of the number of its children, deserve and is entitled to the family allowance. I have said, and still say, that a mother who stays at home with her family should be given a realistic tax allowance and also receive a tax rebate for each child. Despite the Treasurer's assurances, via television, current affairs programs and the like, that he is aware of the difficulties facing Australian families today, his wife admitted that he really has no idea at all, and I am inclined to agree with his wife.

I wonder whether the Government realises the responsibility and cost involved in parenthood for the average Australian family. Society demands that parents accept the financial and emotional responsibilities of parenthood and pay the costs, yet governments continue to make those parental responsibilities harder and harder to meet. In many cases parents simply cannot cope. Mr Deputy President, I put it to you and to honourable senators that these increases mean that further pressures will be placed on our already over-burdened social security system. The 2 1/2 per cent increase in sales tax brought down by the Treasurer in his Budget has probably been the last straw for many people who want to set up home and for families who simply want to keep house. Recent interest rate hikes dealt a heavy blow to many Australian households. In fact, a letter I received from Forest Products Marketing Pty Ltd states:
We are writing to voice our utter dismay at the Federal Government's Budget as it affects our industry.
That is the building industry. The letter continues:
As a result of the 2.5 per cent Sales Tax on building material, home buyers will have to save at least an additional $500 to enable the purchase of a modest new home.
The letter goes on to state:

Not only should the Government be removing the application of a 2.5 per cent Sales Tax on building material, it should take progressive measures. For example, a 4 per cent subsidy on interest rates would assist in the order of 20,000 Australian families to purchase a home at a cost of $20 million in the first year.

I feel that it would be a very good idea if the Treasurer gave consideration to a tax deduction for interest payments on a person's first home. A news release by the Master Builders' Federation was headed:
NO TO HOME SEEKERS' TAX

The Federation feels that it was not justified and would impose further burdens on those less able to afford home ownership. It maintains that the increased costs of the tax itself and of the administrative burden it will impose will have to be built into the final price. The news release continued:
It must result in a further fall in the number of houses built.
It will increase the cost of houses, hospitals, schools as the increased costs cannot be absorbed and will have to be passed on to consumers.

Now, with less disposable income and with the higher interest rates, the added burden of sales tax on essential day-to-day items like household appliances, building materials, soft furnishings, clothing, footwear and manchester, to name but a few, will really affect the family, particularly the low income earners. I actually got a letter from the Queensland Sugar Board which states that the Board feels the sales tax increase will harm the sugar industry. I am sure all honourable senators will know, as I do, the important part that the sugar industry plays not only in Queensland but also right throughout Australia. It plays a real part in maintaining Australia's overseas credit rating. The Board feels the sugar industry will be affected because of the increased sales tax on soft drinks and confectionary. Even more alarming and not as well publicised is the 17 1/2 per cent tax now imposed on items which previously were exempt.

One thing I was very amazed about was the fact that sales tax is to be levied on newsletters issued by charitable and social organisations as a result of the proposed changes. I suppose that is why members of parliament are receiving quite a lot of mail from clubs and organisations throughout Australia such as Lions and Apex complaining very much about the sales tax. I certainly feel the tax in this regard is not necessary. Like the previous speaker, Senator Ryan, I also have had many letters regarding the imposition of sales tax on books.

The sales tax will apply to items such as manufactured pet foods. It will be levied at a rate of 17 1/2 per cent. I am sure that all honourable senators will agree that many pensioners and elderly folk keep pets. Even I have a couple of dogs at home that I have to feed. I know exactly what the increased price for manufactured pet foods will mean. The changes to the sales tax provisions also apply to the motor vehicles used in the mining and grain industries. Many people in Queensland will be affected by these changes. The tax will also apply to motor vehicle seat belts and household insecticides. It is disappointing that a government, of which I am a part, has increased the burden of the financially disadvantaged Australian.

I read a report on the comments of the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce in which he drew attention to the fact that sales tax receipts would rise by a massive 38.6 per cent at the same time as receipts from personal income taxes would rise by 18.9 per cent. Mr Wills was reported to have said that the Government had earlier stated that it would not proceed with a broad based indirect tax because of its inflationary consequences. He said that in the present Budget it had opted for a broad based tax with acknowledged inflationary consequences but without the benefit of any trade-off in the form of reduced personal income taxation. He said the Government merely stated that it had enhanced the potential for further personal income tax relief in future years. At least that is something for which we can be very grateful. The Emerald Chamber of Commerce wrote to me and said that its members felt that the sales tax would do little to stay inflation and in fact it would have the reverse effect. The Chamber considered that much of the sales tax on items was unjust. It said that sales tax was introduced as a revenue raiser for war purposes and has never been lifted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When they put it on they never take it off.
—I would say that would apply as far as the Labor Party is concerned too because it was one of the best governments that I know for imposing taxes.
—We are opposed to sales taxes. We hope you will cross the floor.

—Actually, as I said at the beginning of my speech, it is all very well for Labor supporters to talk about opposing sales tax because the Labor Party puts on higher and higher taxes all the time; that is obvious. I mentioned that when Mr Whitlam was in power in one year the increased take from personal income tax was 40 per cent. So, I do not think Senator Gietzelt should interject in that way. In the Senate yesterday the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) stated that these sales tax Bills were part of the Budget before the Senate. Through them the Government is seeking to raise additional Budget revenue. I acknowledge this, and as a supporter of the Government of course it is necessary for me to support it. But I am not at all happy with the additional sales tax on so many items many of which affect the one income family, families in the lower income groups and the pensioners. I hope that the Government and the Treasurer will take another look at clauses of the sales tax Bills to ascertain whether it is possible to amend them in some way and perhaps to exclude from sales tax the basic family needs such as footwear and clothing and particularly building materials.

That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was previously debating the Budget Papers for 1981-82 I was making the point that we were faced with a mean and miserable Budget; we were faced with a Budget that was contemptible to the extent that it was transferring wealth from the poor to the wealthy and that it was showing a callous disregard for the rights of the ordinary people in our community. Since that time we have been inundated, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen has said, with a great number of protests from a great variety of people in our community who are beginning to see how they will be affected by the economic considerations of this Budget. I was making reference to the complete dishonesty of this Government which has broken a great number of other promises in respect of economic relief for the Australian people. I was drawing attention to the comments that were being made in the daily newspapers about the double talk of the Treasurer, Mr Howard, and the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. I was dealing with the effects that the Government's Budget would have upon consumers. I said we should therefore ask Mr Howard how he sees the householder being affected by the sales tax proposals and by the increased revenue resulting from the great increase in the pay-as-you-earn taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Householders, of course, will be paying out a good deal more for a wide variety of things which now are to attract a new sales tax rate. Pet food, as has been said, will cost an extra $1 a week. Clothing prices will rise. The cost of shoes will rise. The price of books, newspapers and magazines will rise. Many of those people who work in the publishing and associated industries will be forced out of work in the rush to save costs, as has been suggested by one of our main publishing organisations. Despite the claim that food costs will not rise they cannot possibly escape the flow on of associated rises as a result of this Budget, particularly the new 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on packaging and wrapping materials. Home owners and builders will be stung by the increased cost of building materials. These increases alone will add at least $700 to the price of an average new home, according to the New South Wales Master Builders Association. The cost of modestly furnishing such a home will rise by another $300. All this on top of the interest rate hikes will soon make home buying an impossibility for more and more Australians. That is the strategy of this Budget-to make it impossible for the average person to maintain his current standard of living.

According to the latest survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics into household expenditure, total household expenditure on food averaged 19.5 per cent. Housing costs averaged 13.7 per cent; household equipment, 10 per cent; clothing and footwear, 8.3 per cent and; recreation and education, 9.2 per cent. In addition, families on the poorer end of the income scale pay out a greater percentage of their income on essential items, such as food and housing, than their more wealthy counterparts. Furthermore, these poorer households more often than not spend more per week on basic household items from their total weekly income. These figures underline the fact that indirect taxes, such as those contained in this Budget, are inequitable, hitting those who can least afford to meet such increases. That is the bottom line for this Government. I inform Senator Bjelke-Petersen that the inequity of the taxation strategy of this Government is further underlined by the fact that between 1975-76-the last Labor Budget-and the 1981-82 Budget indirect taxation as a proportion of total tax revenue has risen from 28.9 per cent to 30.3 per cent, an increase of 1.4 per cent. In the same period pay-as-you-earn tax as a proportion of total tax revenue will rise by nearly 4 per cent-from 41.7 per cent to 45.1 per cent. That is the highest level of PAYE taxation in Australia's history. While this is coming out of the pockets of ordinary people, company income tax as a proportion of total revenue will fall by 1.4 per cent. At the same time the Treasury notes that the profit share of the economy is increasing. In fact, since 1974-75 the profit share of gross domestic product has increased by more than one percentage point while the wages share has come down by 3 per cent. This indicates that living standards have been reduced and will be further reduced, as has been said by honourable senators in this debate, as a result of the decisions of this Budget. There is no doubt, therefore, that the rich and powerful friends and backers of the Government are gaining in this redistribution of wealth.

The redistribution is evident also in the ruthless cutbacks in the public sector, the sector which services ordinary people with their daily needs, such as health, housing, welfare, and urban and regional development. All of these areas have been slashed considerably under the Liberal-National Country Party Government over the years and once again in this Budget. They have been reduced almost to a small proportion of Government outlays. Time will not permit me to mention many of these cuts into the social wage, but they underline again the philosophy of redistribution advancing the cause of the wealthy whilst leaving the average individual to fend for himself. The attitude of this Government to the health needs of the community is one of the blatant examples which I would like to emphasise. Total health spending for 1981-82 is to increase by just below the expected rate of inflation. I suggest that this is an effective cut. But this bland figure does not reveal the real extent of the confidence trick being played. I ask honourable senators to consider the extra $2 to $11 a week that most families are being forced to pay to private health funds as a result of the most recent changes to the health insurance system, the increased charges that the sick will face for medical services in hospitals and by general practitioners, and the increased pharmaceutical costs. It will cost an extra 45c to have a prescription dispensed. All this was provided for in this Budget.

Let us consider also the fact that, in shifting specific health grants to the States from the health heading to general revenue grants, these grants will show an actual cut of 19.7 per cent, forcing additional burdens upon the States. The States will be forced to raise health charges to users of the facilities. Again that indicates how the social wage is being affected. In plain terms this means that health costs will now be passed on to the States in such a way that they will have to raise their own revenue, their own charges, to provide health services. This government has set up a system whereby community health is no longer a community responsibility. The user-more often the poor, the sick and the disadvantaged-will pay for himself or herself. There we have the Fraser philosophy in a nutshell. It is a case of cut the expenditure, palm off the responsibilities to the States, let individuals fend for themselves, forget compassion, ignore social needs and hang the consequences. That is evident in every area of the public sector as provided for in this Budget.

In recent times Opposition members and those involved in community welfare work have spoken about the horrendous decision made by Mr Howard in this Budget to abolish the Community Youth Support Scheme and about the neglect that his Government is showing for the unemployed. Let me say that a number of measures have been introduced in the Budget that will not fail to produce further unemployment in this country. The cost increases forced by the tax increases have already been mentioned. The resources investment boom is not job productive. The Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, has said that. The further dampening of the public sector will mean that no new jobs will be available in the Public Service and government sectors. But less than zero is proposed by this Government to cope with this problem.

We do not need to invoke the situation which currently exists in the United Kingdom to appreciate the devastating social effects that mass employment has upon communities. We need only to look at our back yard, our own cities, to see the problems of alienation, growing anti-social attitudes and increasing cynicism amongst our unemployed young people who are left on their own without the assistance which CYSS provided. The Community Youth Support Scheme provided one small element of assistance for unemployed young people. But Mr Howard callously announced the end of this scheme with a quick turn of phrase and a stroke of the pen on Budget night. Under the heading of 'Social Security Programs', unemployment relief was dropped in this Budget by a staggering 65 per cent. The Government has claimed-honourable senators have said this in the debate on the Community Youth Support Scheme which was held a couple of weeks ago-that money is being spent on retraining schemes. The Government has said that for the future these education and training schemes are to be given a higher priority than supportive activities. This sounds fine until one realises that much of this money goes on handouts to employers predominantly to employ labour for short terms and at lower costs. The Government may be cutting its costs but it is hardly providing a real solution to the unemployment crisis.

The long term solution to the problems of unemployment can come only with the development of a strong, diverse Australian-based manufacturing service sector and export economy. Immediately we need relief and job creation schemes to cope with the present realities of 400,000 people being unemployed. This Budget does not seek to provide either of those alternatives. Of course, we are aware that in real terms this Government has passed still further on to the States the responsibility of providing some relief in the various areas of the public sector. We have only to look at what has been said. The New South Wales Premier has made it clear that he regards the Budget as disastrous. South Australia's Liberal Premier, Mr Tonkin, accused the Government of economic double standards. The Queensland Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, called it a jumble sale operation and predicted that it could bring down the Fraser Government. The Victorian Minister of Housing, Mr Kennett, said plainly: 'I think the Federal Government is going to have to be judged very harshly indeed'. The Minister for Employment and Training in that State, Mr Dixon, said that his Government was being forced to pick up the social costs of Federal economic policies. So the Liberal-National Country Party Government is condemned out of the mouth of its own people in its own States.

As we are aware, in respect of housing and health, this Government has failed dismally to provide any incentive for the States. This Government has failed to provide any financial encouragement for the States to increase their funds for the development of a decent health system or scheme or for a picking up of public and welfare housing. Consequently, one has to say that this Budget is no longer to be seen in the context of providing relief to the citizens of this country. To the contrary, it will worsen the economic outlook for each and every citizen in our country. It is no wonder, therefore, that the opinion polls show this Government's public support to be at its lowest ebb ever. In recent weeks, two public opinion polls have shown that this Government would receive less than one vote in three-less than 33 per cent of the Australian people have any faith in the credibility of this Government. Honourable senators must be aware, as are all of us on this side of the chamber, that various groups in the Australian community-academics and students at the universities, people in the education system, people in the health system, the unemployed and people in the social welfare areas-are protesting in one way or another, as indeed are the people who are affected by the sales tax increases that have been referred to in this debate. Included are those involved in manufacturing soft drinks, in publishing organisations, master builders, home owners and the Housing Industry Association. They have all made stridently critical statements about this Government.

Of course, it is on the basis of this Government's failure to accept its responsibility to provide economic direction for this country that this Budget will seem to be, as it is, pursuing a path that will depress further the living standards of the Australian people. We make no apology for the fact that we will oppose by every means available to us the sales tax propositions, because they will affect the consumer movement and the average citizen in our society. We will oppose also the Budget because we believe it will bring ruin to our citizens, to the small business sector, to the farmers and to the various other groups in our community which have expressed dismay and dissatisfaction with the 1981-82 Budget of the Fraser-Howard-Anthony Administration.
