TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Hill, I remind the Senate that this is the first speech by the honourable senator in this place, known as the maiden speech. I ask that honourable senators extend to him the usual courtesies. I call Senator Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: — Thank you, Mr President. I rise with pride but yet some trepidation to address the Senate for the first time. Pride-I am pleased to be here as a Liberal elected by the people of South Australia. Trepidation-I am taking the place of two South Australian Liberals who contributed so much to this place for many years. Sir Condor Laucke has set a tremendous example to follow. I particularly recognise his humility, the high standard of personal integrity he maintained and his sense of fair play. Gordon Davidson likewise brought to the Senate a commitment of service to the public and a deep concern for people. They are qualities that the community has a right to expect of its elected representatives and to be remembered for such qualities is, I believe, high praise. But apart from their personal qualities, they both sought to enhance the high standards of the Senate; in the case of Sir Condor particularly through his role as President and in the case of Gordon Davidson, through his commitment to what can be achieved through the Senate committee system. If I could emulate both the personal qualities they brought as well as their commitment and contribution to the standing of this chamber I would be pleased.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, with the retirement of Sir Condor the Senate lost a highly regarded President. I am pleased to see him succeeded by another South Australian of not dissimilar qualities, and I congratulate you, Mr President, upon your appointment.

I am speaking to the Budget and I want to concentrate on the mix and levels of particular taxes that are being utilised to raise necessary Government revenue. I understand, however, that I have on this occasion certain liberties, and for a few minutes I wish to make reference to the State I represent. In an article appearing in the Australian of 22 August 1981, columnist Max Harris claimed:
South Australia is probably more politically volatile than any other State, because it is dying. The process is inevitable for obvious geographic and demographic reasons.

That, Mr President, is incorrect. It is true that South Australia is not blessed with abundant surface water. It has, however, vast and largely untapped underground resevoirs. It is true that it is located away from its major markets. However, with modern transport the nation is shrinking. An international airport and completion of the Stuart Highway will dramatically open new outlets. It was thought that it was poorly served with mineral resources. What is now apparent is rather that their discovery has been slow. Roxby Downs presents a potential as one of the world's great mines and our supplies of liquid and gaseous hydrocarbons are appearing more impressive practically by the day. It is true that times are currently difficult for South Australia. It has this century developed an industrial base in white goods and vehicle manufacture, employment within which has been severely hit by automation and the technological revolution. Government support through tax and other incentives has been largely lost and the protectionist policies, upon which the industry was established and its survival arguably depends, are now challenged. But with the Government it now has, which is both enthusiastic and positive, and given time and patience of the Federal Government and the other States, South Australia will find new directions, readjust and expand.
It was stated by Charles Fenner in a history produced by the Royal Geographical Society for the South Australian centenary nearly 50 years ago:

There is probably much justice in the claim that the people attracted to South Australia by the Wakefield scheme of colonisation were an unusual and peculiar people, who had chosen to carry out a novel experiment in a remote land.

That, I think, is true today. We are an unusual and peculiar people who have overcome adversity before and will do so again. Look briefly at our early history as the most non-conformist and radical of the Australian colonies. We were the first State to introduce a motion for the ballot. Open voting was however causing some trauma. Take for example the election for the seat of West Adelaide in 1855 when Forster opposed Fisher. A fight took place in the booth soon after it was opened. Sixty police were requisitioned to keep order. When, from a hotel balcony, Forster was declared elected, Fisher supporters rushed forward, pulled down the Forster flags and descended on the crowd with sticks, stones and chairlegs. Down went the foot police before the attack. The Commissioner of Police thereupon threw in his mounted men, who as was reported in the Register of 21 September 1855:

Galloped with drawn swords into the thickest of the fight, and the admirable and determined movements of this body had a very salutary effect upon the infuriated partisans, several of whom were captured.

It cannot be said that we do not take our politics seriously! But the most liberal of the first constitutions led the colonies also with manhood suffrage, single voting and triennial parliaments. There followed the first full adult suffrage for the lower House and the extension of the right to vote to properly qualified women for the Legislative Council, notwithstanding that shocked legislators contemplated that the proposal would disrupt marriages and society by unsettling women from their place in the home.

Earlier, the first elective Legislative Council had abolished State aid to religious bodies-a debate which indirectly has never ended. Then came the great experiment of the Torrens land system. It was implemented, although leading legal figures warned of its impracticability, which they are still doing in some places. The reformer, Charles Cameron Kingston, sponsored the first compulsory arbitration legislation of any colony, which was later to become a model for this Commonwealth. He recognised that strikes did not settle disputes, only prolonged them, that the public had a right to be protected and that the victors in an industrial conflict did not necessarily have right on their side. The answer was that the matter should go to a court for decision, just like any other civil dispute. Now this unique industrial system is under challenge. Kingston was of course a great character. Before becoming Premier and subsequently a Minister in the first national Parliament, it is reported that he had been arrested in Victoria Square when, armed with a pistol, he proposed to fight a duel with Legislative Councillor, Richard Chaffey Baker, who later became the first President of the Senate. Both were instrumental in the strong support given by South Australia to the new Federal Parliament, which it was hoped would solve many problems such as control over the River Murray, and for which we are still waiting.

Finally, might I remind the Senate that in 1887 we saw the wisdom of paying salaries to back bench members of parliament. Ministers had of course earlier been paid. Mr President, we were the most non-conformist and radical of the Australian colonies and in that heritage Mr Harris will find a determination which will again lift South Australia to among the forefront of Australian States. But we share with all Australians an interest in our taxation system upon which, as I indicated, I wish to speak briefly. It was in 1884 that South Australian Legislative Councillors had to yield to a direct tax on the unimproved value of real estate, imposed because urban reformers and discontented farmers believed, and I quote from the South Australian parliamentary debates, 1883 page 1439:
. . . that owners of property and wealthy men had escaped taxation long enough.

It may be argued that such is still the case. Certainly it is a debate which has been rekindled by the Budget decision to broaden the sales tax base. It is generally difficult to find academics in agreement. But in the area of the Australian taxation system there is near unanimity that reform is long overdue. This is not principally a debate on the lowering or increasing or real taxation which is a different subject. Tax reform is concerned with the rearrangement and redistribution of taxes to achieve stated policy objectives. Thus the role of the tax reformer, given the objectives to be achieved, relates primarily to the critical assessment of the correct mix of taxation. It is a field in which there is always inertia against change. The mass of letters of protest being received by honourable senators in relation to the extended sales tax bears witness to this fact. Any new tax will always act to someone's detriment.
Thus taxation reform requires a certain courage on the part of government, a reassessment of objectives and a re-examination of the correct tax mix to meet those objectives.

The report of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee brought down in 1975 saw equity, simplicity and efficiency as the primary objectives of any worthwhile tax system, and this is rarely challenged. By equity it meant not only horizontal equity, that is, that the person in the same situation should be equally treated, but also vertical equity: Those who are more favourably placed should be required to pay more. Both concepts reflect the principle of ability to pay. Vertical equity, however, encompasses the more controversial subject of the extent to which the taxation vehicle should be used to control or limit inequality. At a time when the gap between the 'haves' and the 'have-nots' of our society appears to be widening this objective and the social, political and ethical judgments for which it calls may well be assuming a new importance.

It is stated that simplicity also points to a complex of ideas. However, if the assessor and the assessed can each establish with certainty what is due in tax, one canon of simplicity will be attained. Efficiency was explained to require, on a narrow plane, that the tax dollar suffers from minimal waste in its transfer from the private sector to the public sector. On a broader plane, taxation considerations should not interfere with the otherwise most efficient economic decisions. Asprey recognised also that for the purpose of successful economic management a taxation system needs to be flexible enough to change and vary according to economic circumstances. A proper tax mix demands the inclusion of some taxes which can be increased or decreased with a minimum of administrative difficulty while at the same time having the potential to exert as large an impact on economic activity as possible.

On our side of politics where we see the disadvantaged best served by a strong and growing economy, we would accept also that the objective of economic growth should be pursued through the instrument of taxation policy. This objective may call for lower rates but not necessarily so. A more equitable, efficient and simple taxation mix may provide as much encouragement to increased levels of saving and investment as a general tax cut. How does our taxation system meet those objectives? The consensus of the major investigations and of the academics is to argue that we have fared poorly. It can be argued that our taxation system is inequitable, complex and inefficient and does not have sufficient flexibility. In many ways it discourages economic growth. Professor Russell Mathews of the Australian National University states that the taxation system 'has been thoroughly discredited as a policy instrument for achieving the redistribution of wealth'. It is inequitable in that it taxes some wealth increments and not others. It taxes income to the extent that it increases wealth but not capital gains or windfall gains and results in a heavy bias towards the taxation of income. In 1978, 43.7 per cent of our total tax revenue was raised through personal income tax compared with an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 38.5 per cent. Thus those whose wealth is increased by capital gains rather than by income do not share in the taxation burden. No other highly developed country has our almost complete absence from some form of taxation of capital gains, net wealth taxes or death duties.

The taxation system is inequitable in that a taxation of income has largely become a taxation of wages and salaries. Those whose income has been derived from property or business have been afforded opportunities for avoidance through income splitting and the like not available to the recipients of wages and salaries. Thus in the year 1980-81 net pay-as-you-earn instalment payments represented 80.49 per cent of the total income tax on individuals. A more vivid example was given by Professor Mathews in an address to the Australian Institute of Political Science in January 1980 when he pointed out that, although the proportion of wages and salary incomes to total household income had remained roughly constant at two-thirds over the previous 15 years, the share of the taxation burden had increased from the original two-thirds to approximately four-fifths. Thus it can be argued that some $2,715m would appear to have been lost through schemes of avoidance and evasion in the year 1978-79 alone.

The taxation system is inequitable when, in the absence of tax indexation, inflation alone and not any increase in real income lifts taxpayers into a higher tax bracket. No one could argue that the system is not complicated. When the Honourable W. B. Rounsevell introduced the 1884 taxation Bill in South Australia he said:
The Bill has been so drafted that honourable members who were not of a legal turn of mind would be able to clearly understand it.

Honourable senators could reflect upon recent tax avoidance legislation and ask how such amendments would stand the test of simplicity. On the criteria of efficiency the system again fares poorly. Income tax tends to discourage growth and company income tax discriminates between companies and other business vehicles such as partnerships and trusts. When considering the object of flexibility, the lack of a broad based consumption tax and the continuing emphasis on personal income tax have considerably limited the flexibility open to government. As was stated by Professor Groenewegen, Professor of Economics at the University of Sydney, in a Taxation Institute of Australia research and education trust newsletter in June of this year:

. . . there was so much dissatisfaction with many aspects of the current tax system, and especially with its increasing reliance on the taxation of wages and salaries, that further increases in that reliance will just not produce the required revenue to meet government expenditure needs of the 1980's on even modest growth forecasts of that expenditure.

The failure of any attempt at redistribution of wealth is seen in the abolition of death duties on the one hand and the regressive nature of petrol taxes and excise taxes on such items as beer and tobacco on the other hand. Such taxes hit the not so well off to a greater extent than the wealthy. Added to a progressive income tax rate which bears little relationship to the nominal progression, Professor Mathews has in fact gone so far as to assert:
. . . it is plausible to argue that the taxation system has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes and wealth in favour of the rich.

On the objective of economic growth one need look only at the double taxation of dividends and earnings which is an obvious disincentive for savings and investment. The failure to meet reasonable objectives derives from the hotchpotch way in which the system has developed. It has been a system of grafting new on to old, resolving short term problems with long term amendments. It has not developed as a deliberately conceived and structured system. In fact, as the Asprey report states, the word 'system' is a euphemism when discussing the Australian taxation structure.

If the case for tax reform has been made out, how should the tax mix be altered? To find the answer it is unnecessary to undertake further major investigations. Works and reports on the subject abound. In fact, it is worth noting that the significant United Kingdom reforms of 1971 did not follow a major report. Reforms were announced, discussion papers were published and public debate followed. Overseas reports of recent times have tended to approach reform from a clean slate and, therefore, offer more radical alternatives. The Meade Committee of the United Kingdom which reported in 1978 favoured transforming the personal income tax into a personal expenditure tax, arguing that it was simpler, more equitable and more neutral to tax people on what they take out of the common pool rather than what they put in. This would be accompanied by a flow of funds revenue base for corporate taxation, a progressive wealth tax and major changes in the social security system. The United States Treasury 'Blueprints for Basic Tax Reform' study of 1977 looked at a comprehensive income tax which would integrate corporate and personal income taxes.

The Australian studies have rather been concerned with making the existing system work more effectively. The Asprey report recommendations included a simplified personal income tax, a tax on capital gains as an increment of wealth to improve equity, and a more neutral broad based value added tax in lieu of the narrow based sales tax. The Mathews Committee of Inquiry into Inflation and Taxation also of 1975 called for tax indexation and valuation of stock on a current cost basis. Together, they made up a package for conservative, although worthwhile, reform.
The Government has tended to follow the latter path. Edmund Burke said:
All virtue which is impracticable is spurious.

In tax reform the ideal may not be possible. Virtue which is practical should be admired. Thus it is necessary to view reform in a spirit of realism and with an acceptance of necessary political restraints. Clearly in that spirit, the Government has reduced the progressive steps in income tax, making a contribution to the objectives of simplicity and economic growth. In addition the tax threshold has been lifted and the spouse rebate increased thereby contributing to equity. Similarly the desire for greater equity has led the Government to provide the most comprehensive avoidance and evasion legislation of any government, I believe, in Australian history. Finally the Government has by this Budget extended the narrow sales tax into a more broad based consumption tax, although without the neutrality or flexibility of a value added tax.

The Government should be given credit for the steps it has taken but the major inequities remain. The bias against the taxation of income remains, high marginal rates still act as a disincentive to economic growth as does double taxation on dividends and earnings to investment. Wage and salary income earners are still prejudiced as against business and property income earners, inflation is again drawing taxpayers into higher tax brackets. These inequities, yet to be overcome by governments of either persuasion, call for action.

Options abound within the more moderate package. We cannot forever remain the only highly developed nation without some form of capital or equivalent taxation at the Federal level. Linear income tax being advocated by some academics can combine vertical equity with incentive. A switch from a wholesale sales tax to a retail tax or value added tax remains available.

As was found by the Asprey committee, the exact mix of a restructured taxation system requires a value judgment by the Government as to the best balance of objectives. Attempts at taxation reform in Australia have generally occurred at times of economic difficulty. Distortions in the economy have brought changes in the taxation system in the hope of solving particular problems. Yet the overall deficiency of the system has remained. But now in the early 1980s we have a strong and growing economy with prospects that Australia will be a growth leader of the industrialised world during the next 10 years. What better time is there for us to grasp the nettle and restructure the taxation system to a fairer and more equitable basis. I thank honourable senators for their courtesy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Bolkus I remind the Senate that this is Senator Bolkus's maiden speech and I ask that the same courtesies be extended to him. I call Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. It is with both pleasure and a certain degree of excitement that I make my first speech in the Senate. The pleasure comes from standing here with colleagues as a member of the Australian Labor Party, the only party which represents truly the hopes and aspirations of the Australian people. The excitement comes from being here at what is a watershed for the conservative forces in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians are presently watching the last of three conservative governments, and it is a government in its death throes. It has conned the Australian electorate with a succession of three-card tricks for long enough. Already the public is seeing that indeed the emperor has no clothes. The sight of this particular emperor without his clothes is not a pretty one. It is a sight which, at the next election, the public will pronounce as extremely obscene. So it is perhaps timely to ask a question, and that question is: How will history judge these three conservative governments? When the dust from the present settles, how will the historical profile of the last six years appear? Who will be the winners and who will be the losers?

In any political game there are winners and losers; of that there is no question. But what we have watched during the past six years of conservative oligarchy is a cold, calculated reduction in the number of winners and an equally deliberate and viciously cruel expansion in the number of losers. Nowhere was this fact exposed more blatantly than in a recent major series of articles in the Sydney Morning Herald. This series examined poverty in Australia and confronted its readers with depressing fact after depressing fact. One in seven Australians are struggling for survival, it said. And I would suggest that is a conservative figure. The Australian Council of Social Service adds up the real losers in our society and arrives at the figure of 1.9 million people living in poverty. I would suggest that on top of that figure there are close to another 1.5 million living so close to poverty that to them each day is also a depressing and demeaning struggle; a struggle just to live.

It is a disgrace, Mr President. It is a disgrace to all those who have served as members of the three conservative governments which are responsible for this social tragedy. But it is this type of Australia which has been created by this succession of conservative governments. This is how they will be judged by history. This is how the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will be judged by history. He will be recorded as the man who, when rejected as Prime Minister, left the country with more than two million of his fellow country people living in poverty. He will be remembered as the man who created two Australias and shattered our egalitarian image by entrenching wealth on the one hand and poverty on the other.

This Prime Minister has presided over a theatre of deception. He went to the people three times and conned them into believing he was going to maintain the Australian way of life. He did not. He presided over the destruction of the traditional way of Australian life, and he did it by deliberate policy initiatives

These policies ensured that unemployment would become an entrenched part of the Australian way of life. The official figures show that there are about 410,000 Australians unemployed. On top of that there are the hidden unemployed-those people who, for one reason or another, have either not registered as unemployed or have simply dropped out of the work force. Only last week the Australian Bureau of Statistics, estimated this number to be 607,900. That means that there are more than one million Australians unemployed. It is this unemployment figure which will hang heavily around the necks of the members and senators sitting on the conservative benches. That is one way in which the conservative governments have changed the Australian way of life.

Before moving on to the next example of how these people have changed society, I am reminded of a suggestion I once saw for a solution to unemployment. Mr Ted Wheelwright, a Sydney economist, suggested a new index for unemployment. He said that every time unemployment rose by one percentage point, five Treasury staff should be sacked, starting from the top down. I think such a plan would soon put a halt to the monetarist voodoo worship which is practised in that institution.

So, to the next example of how the conservatives have changed society. The policy of keeping interest rates high has perhaps done more than anything else to alter the way Australians approach life. It has demolished the great Australian dream of owning a home. The Housing Industry Association, hardly a radical body, estimates that every time interest rates rise by point five of one per cent in the home loan sector, 4,000 Australians are excluded from the housing market. Therefore in the past 2 1/2 years at least 24,000 Australians have been excluded from the home buying market. That is another measure of how history will judge this conservative Government. It was the Government which shattered the Australian dream of home ownership for thousands of Australians in just 2 1/2 years.

By destroying for many the basic aspirations which lead to a full life, the conservatives have re-shaped the social profile of this country. Using the approaches of financial oppression, through a cruel reduction in real wages and the social wage and an abdication of funding responsibilities by the Commonwealth, these governments have hit hard. These economic policies have meant that women are still denied an equal place in society. That in 1981 women still do not have real economic, social and political equality is an indictment of this Government. The same story can be told for the other socially and culturally impoverished: The migrants, those in the ethnic minorities, the Aboriginals, and the poor, and especially the children of the poor.

The fourth and final measure historians will use in judgment of this Government is the one with perhaps the most far reaching ramifications. This is the question of foreign investment and the intrusion of transnational corporations into the Australian economy. Where is the money going? We are told by the puppets on the conservative benches that it is funding the resources 'boom'. But now economists and business leaders say either that the boom has boomed or that it did not exist at all. They say that the economy is running out of steam and that from here on it is downhill. But the conservatives cannot cope with serious economic analysis. This confusion about whether the boom has boomed, or even whether there was a boom to boom about, is causing great problems in the Government parties.

In January of this year, in his New Year address, the Prime Minister said that we were in an 'energy and resources rush'. During last October's election campaign, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) said: 'Australia's coming resources boom could turn into a bust under a Hayden Labor government'. It has turned into a bust but it has done so under another Liberal-National Country Party Government. But this confusion about when is a boom not a boom continues. In the Budget Speech the Treasurer (Mr Howard), a man who one would hope would know a boom when he saw one, said that the 'resources investment boom' was 'proceeding apace'. But now the Acting Prime Minister, as he is at the moment, tells us that he does not like the word 'boom'; it is 'an unfortunate term'. So in just a few weeks we have a boom which is moving apace, which is a mirage and which the Acting Prime Minister does not really like. But, despite this, the money keeps coming in at levels higher than those in the corresponding periods of last year.

Where is the money going? The record level of $6,500m worth of overseas capital which flowed into Australia in the last financial year did not go into any resource boom in any substantial way. A great deal of this money was hot money. It was here for short term speculation. It was here to buy up our internationally cheap real estate, urban and rural. It was here in anticipation of a revaluation of the Australian dollar. It was here, in short, to make a killing: A killing at the expense of the Australian people, their hopes, desires and aspirations. It was here at the expense of Australia's future, and that is the most damning pronouncement historians will make of these conservative governments. In just six years these governments have sold Australia's future to the big time amoral, international gamblers. All of this has done something quite horrible to Australians today. It has taken from our daily lives two vital ingredients for a full life which can make some kind of contribution to society. These are hope and imagination. What hope is there for the young people today with no job and no chance of owning a home and with the distinct possibility that, if they are lucky enough to have a job or a home, they will have a foreign boss and a foreign landlord? What room is there for imagination in today's Australia? There is none. People are being bludgeoned into a dull, grey, pedestrian life pre-determined by the economic thugs who are in collusion with this Government.

It is fair to ask now what lies behind this perversion of the Australian way of life. I believe we can only come to the conclusion that behind it all is the hand of the Prime Minister, a man born to riches and closeted by them ever since. He and his application of his party's conservative philosophies are the main forces behind this change to the Australian way of life. The Prime Minister parades on the international stage as the champion of monetarism or the trendier supply-sided economics. He has raised control of the money supply and its use as a panacea for all economic ills to the level of devil worship. Let us analyse this philosophy. If it were real monetarism, if it were the gospel according to the Chicago economists led by Milton Friedman, we would see the amount of money in the economy being reduced year by year. But that is not happening; it is going up. If it were real monetarism we would have seen inflation drop away to something quite small. We have not. It is again climbing. If it were real supply-sided economics, as practised by the Reagan Administration's resident guru, David Stockman, we would see tax cuts. We do not. We just see taxes rise year after year. If the Prime Minister were fair dinkum about boosting the supply side of the economy, we would see consumer spending leaping ahead. We do not. We just see real spending power reduced again and again. I would suggest that this Prime Minister has no economic theory. He is indeed an emperor without clothes in every sense.

Without a credible or workable economic policy, Australians have, for the past six years, been subjected to a series of economic gambles which have not paid off. They have not paid off and the Australian people are the ones who have had to cash in their chips. First we had tax indexation. Never has a government sold so much rhetoric on an issue and given so little in return. After being promised full tax indexation, Australians received half tax indexation and now we have the last few dribbles of a discounted form of half indexation. So, from promising full tax indexation, the Government has now done a 180-degree turn and instituted a secret inflation tax which will this year see pay-as-you-earn income tax rise about 80 per cent faster than incomes. Then we had the famous prices and incomes freeze. It must have seemed like a good idea at the time. But it was so ill-thought out and unplanned that it was soon denounced not only by the trade union movement but also by leaders of commerce, employer groups and most State governments. It very soon collapsed.

What of the tax cuts we are so often promised? All this talk has proven to be just that, because year after year taxes rise at a rate much faster than wages. As I said this year it is expected that taxes will rise about 80 per cent faster than wages. Every time this Government has announced a tax cut it is possible to prove that more income earners will be worse off than will benefit. Those who are worse off are the low income earners and the ones who really benefit are the rich, the masters of capital, those who are in fact represented in this Parliament by people like the Prime Minister and his Cabinet colleagues.

I have already mentioned interest rates and it is here that this Government has lain down and let itself be run over by the real manipulators of the economy-the transnational corporations. These corporations are the ones which, through their unbridled pumping of money into this country, have necessitated restrictive economic measures within Australia. Government inactivity, either by design or because it does now know what it is doing, has led it to make Australians pay for the profits from foreign investment-profits which go overseas.

This leads into another economic gamble which has not paid off for the Australian people; that is, the huge loans which have been necessary for resource development and the capital works needed to get it moving. I am not saying that resource development is a bad thing, but it is obvious that the way it has been handled by this Government has not helped the Australian economy. In fact, it has done the opposite. The way this inept Government has handled resource development has led to monetary target after monetary target being over-shot, and it has fed inflationary expectations by keeping interest rates much higher than inflation rates. In his book Exit Full Employment, Dr Barry Hughes say this of the 1977 prices-wages freeze:
It was a piece of political theatre that with the aid of illusionists the country mistook for serious economic policy.

I would suggest that Dr Hughes has hit the nail on the head. Indeed, his words can apply to the whole charade of economic policy which the Australian public has had to swallow for six years. They have now had enough and I am sure they will say so demonstrably at the next election.

What then is needed for Australia? I think this is obvious. What is needed is real democracy of, by and for the people. Democratic socialism as promised by the Australian Labor Party is Australia's only hope for survival in the 1980s. The Australian Labor Party stands for many things but I believe there are five basics which have been denied to the Australian people under these three conservative governments and which the Australian Labor Party alone can deliver. These are liberty, democracy, social equality, co-operation and reason. Put together these principles represent an expression of freedom and participation in society, something Australia merely glimpsed during the three years of the Whitlam Labor Government.

The people of Australia are now realising just what benefits there were under the Whitlam Labor Government. If Medibank had continued we would not now be in this terrible mess about health insurance which is hurting those least able to pay. If spending on housing had not been cut back so savagely we would not now have the crisis we have in trying to house the poor and the lower income earners. If Clyde Cameron's imaginative policies in the field of industrial relations had been allowed to continue we would not have the mas- sive division between employers and employees that we have today, or the economic oppression of workers. If the late Rex Connor had been allowed to put into practice his ideas for resource development we would not be running around like headless chooks wondering what this 'boom' is all about.

Where has this Government, led by this Prime Minister, provided any real participation for the Australian people? In six years of conservative rule Australia has moved closer and closer towards being the most unequal society in the world. Let us examine just one aspect of what is being denied to the Australian people. The notion of reason is one which encompasses good and compassionate management and social interaction. It is possible only under a Labor Government because the record shows the conservative forces to be totally unreasonable. How can they explain the following manoeuvres? They put more people out of work in their efforts to solve unemployment. They raise interest rates in an effort to make money more accessible to home buyers. They propose to take away protection and jobs in order to rationalise the manufacturing sector and somehow to create more jobs. They take away any notion of universal health cover in order to create a health scheme which will benefit the consumer, but make consumers, the poor, the sick and the needy pay most. They invoke Draconian anti-labour legislation in order to protect the free market for capital. How members of this Government can sleep at night with this series of bewildering paradoxes swirling around in their heads is amazing. Against this record it makes me feel proud to stand here as a senator representing the Australian Labor Party and representing the aspirations of the majority of Australians.

The Australian Labor Party is the oldest political party this country has and every other political party has been a reaction to it. All members in this chamber who are not in the Australian Labor Party are here because the ruling class became frightened of real democracy and set up one political party or another to protect the interests of capital. Since our party was formed in the 1890s every social, political, economic and legal achievement of any consequence in Australia can be traced back to action by the Labor Party or the broader labour movement. Some examples are: The 40 hour week, the basic wage, the operation of the arbitration system, aged pensions, child endowment, maternity allowances, the principles of full employment, recognition of the rights of migrants and women, movements toward equality for women, the Commonwealth Bank, the Australian Navy, the Snowy Mountains Scheme, Qantas Airways Ltd, post war immigration, Medibank, Aboriginal land rights, a fairer electoral system and the list can go on and on. It is the Australian Labor Party which has provided the real benefits of being Australian and living in Australia. It is the Australian Labor Party which has consistently and without hesitation fought for the rights and aspirations of Australians. It is the only political party which has the interests of Australians at heart.

My predecessors in this chamber, Senator Bishop and Senator Cavanagh pursued these interests and ideals, and did so effectively. They, together with amongst others, Clyde Cameron, the former Member for Hindmarsh, and ex-Senators Jim Toohey and Don Cameron, provided strong and effective representation for Australians generally and South Australians in particular. I pay tribute to them for their efforts and in doing so thank them and Senator Elstob for their advice and assistance. I have worked with them all, whether officially or unofficially, and know I have learnt much from all of them.

Australia is at the crossroads. It has to choose between democratic socialism, through the Australian Labor Party, or barbarism. The last time we saw this scenerio played out was in the 1930s. By this I am not saying the economic models are the same but the recipe for disaster has all the same ingredients being added by like-minded chefs. Then we saw financial disaster followed by economic collapse. This spurred the rise of fascism, unchecked in some parts, and an unparalleled world war. This is barbarism and it is the road down which this Government is taking all Australians. It is a form of barbarism-the barbarism of social jungle warfare-which is being introduced into Australia in the guise of economic rationality. Faced with this choice-democratic socialism or barbarism-I am confident the Australian people will make the right choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to two former and well respected senators at present in the President's Gallery. I refer to Mr Jim Toohey and Mr Don Cameron. I extend to both of them a very warm welcome back to this chamber and back to Canberra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset may I be the first to congratulate Senator Hill and Senator Bolkus for their maiden speeches both of which I think we have been impressed with in one way or another. I am sure we will hear very spirited speeches from both of them at times when we can interject. Tonight I will say a few things about some different matters. First of all I want to say something about the sales tax legislation. At the outset I say that I believe that a sales tax is one of the things we should be aiming for. I think that a user pays tax is something that could benefit the whole of this country. I feel that any increase in sales tax has to be associated with a decrease in personal income tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said before that I believe the top rate of income tax should never exceed 50c in the dollar because obviously that leads to people trying to avoid income tax. Actually, I am one of those people sometimes called a flat-earther. I believe in a flat rate of tax that rewards those who work harder in a day in a fair way and in a system which does not have the disincentive I believe our present system has. I do not really believe those who say it cannot be done because excises and a lot of other taxes are indeed flat rate taxes. Anyone with an ounce of sense can see that a similar system can easily be applied to income tax. Actually it is already done in some countries; a couple that come to mind are Hong Kong and Switzerland. Both are very successful and yet quite different in structure but each with the advantage to their residents of low rates of flat tax.

I also believe that a flat rate of tax should be our aim in sales tax. That is something we should strive for. Whenever indirect taxes go up personal income tax must come down with the eventual aim of having a flat tax rate for personal income tax and sales tax. I also believe that if we ever have any savings in government expenditure that that should result in reduced personal income tax. I believe that is what the people of this country want. They want reduced taxes so that they can decide how they spend their money. They do not want to see it spent in ways over which they have no control-as I believe is the case in some ways now. I will mention a few of those cases in a moment.

Recently I saw a newspaper article that pointed out that if the savings of the so-called razor gang had been passed on we could have had a tax cut of some $560m. That could have been applied as a 2 per cent reduction for the bottom marginal rate and 5 per cent reduction on the top rate gradually getting it down towards a flat rate. It is my belief that we must gradually aim for that flat rate of taxation and that also we should gradually shift the weight of our taxation from personal income tax to indirect taxation such as sales tax. But with each shift I believe that personal income tax should come down.

Having said that I will look for a moment at some of the expenditure on things like social security and welfare. This Government believes in protecting those in need in our community. If honourable senators look at pages 100 and 101 of the Budget statements for 1981-82 they will see that age pensions and allowances will increase by $600m this year; service pensioners will receive an additional $136m; assistance to the handicapped in invalid pensions and allowances has gone up by over $100m; supporting parents' benefits and allowances have gone up by nearly $200m; we all know that assistance to families by way of family allowances has gone up by about $90m and assistance to the unemployed by unemployment benefits has gone up an additional $94m. I have rounded those figures off. None of them are to the nearest decimal point. If we look at the total for social security and welfare payments we see that there has been an increase in the Budget of nearly $1,500m from nearly $10,000m. That is a sizable part of our Budget. We have to remember of course that there are 27 pay days in this financial year. But even then we are spending a very great deal of the Government's income on this important area. I think it comes to nearly 28 per cent of all outlays. The actual expansion in effect is only 12 per cent during the present year.

If we are looking for savings there are some areas where I feel some cutbacks should be made. As the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) well knows I have been very much against sending Australian pensions overseas. By that I do not mean that we should not send pensions to somebody who makes a holiday trip overseas but I mean to those people who choose to live in other countries. Some of those countries have a much lower cost of living than does Australia so a person can live quite well on our pension. Also a pensioner living here is subject, first of all, to income tax if that person is earning more than a certain amount. Secondly, we have to be sure that that pensioner is alive. How on earth can we ascertain we should be taking income tax out of a pension if we do not have a ghost of a chance of checking whether the person is working. I have no doubt that there have been many payments to persons overseas well after they have died. I think we are quite crazy to be sending good Australian money overseas to pensioners when we cannot check for that type of thing. I think it is time we stopped such payments. I know a great number of people who work long hours, and hard, to earn their income, some of which goes in government taxes. For example, I can think of some farmers I know who work hard growing and delivering vegetables. They contribute to government coffers, but some of that contribution goes towards the payment of pensions overseas. The Government should review that practice.

Another aspect is that if a pension is spent in Australia, it contributes to Australia's economy. If it is spent overseas, it does not. I hope that the Government will reconsider the whole question of pension reciprocity. If it decides to continue such reciprocity-I hope it will not-it should deduct from pensions paid overseas an amount to compensate for loss of income tax and the loss to the Australian economy as a result of the pensions not being spent in this country. I wish to make it quite clear that I oppose money being sent to people who live permanently overseas. It should be given only to those who live in Australia, but if it must be paid abroad, let us at least retain enough to compensate for loss of income tax and loss of benefit to the economy because the pension is not spent in Australia.

Another area of social security payment in respect of which people keep telling me that this country is crazy concerns the method of payment of the unemployment benefit to people from New Zealand. Upon their arrival in Australia, if they have been receiving unemployment benefit in their own country, they immediately become eligible for our higher unemployment benefit payment. In contrast, an Australian citizen who seeks the unemployment benefit must go through a qualifying period. Obviously, that situation should be changed immediately.

Also, it is high time that this country had a system of social security numbering. From advice that I have received I cannot believe that some people are not receiving more than one payment for unemployment benefit. I understand that, provided they keep their trap shut, it is not easy to catch them. A system of social security numbering would help to avoid such practices and to identify illegal immigrants. I realise that some people are against being given a number of any kind but invariably my response is that if a person has nothing to hide, why should he complain?

I turn now to the expenditure upon ethnic radio and television services, a subject on which one or two questions have been asked in the Senate today. I repeat that I do not like the idea of the Government spending money on such services, which I feel should be absorbed by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. At page 133 of the Budget documents reference is made to the fact that this year some $6m is to be provided for ethnic radio services. That sum is $1.2m greater than the expenditure in the last financial year. Also, $20m is to be provided to meet the estimated cost of the first full year of operating the new ethnic television services in Sydney and Melbourne. Obviously, that too represents an increase in expenditure over the previous year. I am strongly opposed to the idea of providing special television and radio services for people who come to live in this country. I believe equally strongly that they should be prepared to live in the way that other Australians live and watch Australian television-bad as it is at certain times.

It is good to note the Government's support for the youth, sport and recreation program, expenditure upon which has been substantially increased to $20m, an increase of 87 per cent over the provision for last year. I would be quite happy if all of the money that is now devoted to ethnic television and radio were to be devoted to sport and recreation, and particularly for capital works in that regard.

I wish to discuss now the way in which this Budget affects Tasmania. Let us be clear that it has been very good to my State. Over the years Tasmania has had a great deal of assistance from the Federal Government in the form of freight equalisation payments. This year the provision for that purpose will amount to almost $33m. The assistance given air travellers by way of passenger subsidy and the subsidy paid in respect of the Empress of Australia total almost $40m a year. Freight equalisation helps to encourage people to set up in Tasmania businesses that employ people. The air subsidy is designed to encourage travel to and from Tasmania and, until other matters are attended to, it does represent an appropriate response to the problem of the considerable cost of travel to and from the island State. The subsidy in respect of the Empress of Australia also helps tourists travelling to and from Tasmania.

I have mentioned a few of the special payments which Tasmania receives but one or two other items are also worthy of special mention. They demonstrate this Government's concern for the people of Tasmania and its determination that that State will not become an economic backwater with second-class citizens. One must not forget that the Federal Government is funding the entire cost of providing a second bridge across the Derwent River. The total cost of that project, based on present prices, will be about $43m. Of that sum, about $17.5m will be made available during this financial year. The bridge is expected to be completed in 1984 and I only hope that the Tasman Bridge is not knocked down again before that date. I hope that there is no immediate need, once the second bridge has been completed, to replace the other bridge on the connecting link between Hobart and Launceston, just south of Bridgewater.

In Hobart some $6m is to be spent to upgrade the airport. One reason for the expenditure is to permit the larger Boeing 727 aircraft to bring in tourists and take out Tasmanian travellers. There are, of course, other ways in which Tasmania is being looked after by this Government, but the few that I have mentioned remind us that the Government does worry about, and look after, Tasmania.

I wish now to touch on three other matters. The first concerns housing, a subject which has been mentioned previously today. Housing is still the most urgent need of many thousands of Australians and should be accorded a very high priority by the Government. There is a need for government houses to be made available at the lowest possible rates of interest for people of little means. There is a need to survey lands that are suitable for housing developments.

Such land should be purchased and the provision of services such as transport, drainage, and roads should be arranged. At the moment the prospective home buyer is faced with high interest rates because of competition for available money. It is to be hoped that before long it will be possible to reduce the rates that are presently charged. I believe that it is better to have money available, even at high interest rates, than to have none available at all. Unless Australia's interest rates are comparable with those in other parts of the world, money will leave Australia; none will be available here. The Government must always regard the provision of a sufficient number of houses, for young people in particular, as one of its highest priorities. I have raised the matter before and I hope that the Government will continue to consider it.

I must agree with the earlier remarks of Senator Jessop and Senator Bjelke-Petersen concerning the proposed sales taxes. I said earlier that I agree with the imposition of sales taxes and with the widening of the application of those taxes, but I believe that the imposition of a 2 1/2 per cent tax on building materials might well have been deferred until interest rates came down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to vote against it, Senator, and support the Labor Party? Of course you are not. They are pious words, like those of Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Jessop.
—If the honourable senator-'Feathers'-listened for a moment and did not flap around, he would be able to hear my position.
—You oppose it yet you will vote for it, just as did your colleagues in regard to brandy excise.
—Order! Senator Townley has the call.

—I believe it is extremely difficult for most young people to rake up the deposit for a house and the higher the cost of a house becomes the harder it will be to get together a deposit. Another matter with regard to housing that should be recognised is that home building is essential. When houses are built the fittings and furnishings that are required have to be bought, so not only the building industry but also in many ways the entire economy are stimulated. I am sure the Government recognises the importance of what I am saying. The Government has looked after housing in the past. I can only request the Government to continue its support for housing as strongly as it can and, when possible, to re-examine the cost to housing as a result of the sales tax changes.

SPEECH.PARA: As an engineer and as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment I want to make some personal comments regarding the Kakadu National Park which is in the Northern Territory. As background may I say as an engineer that I believe the technical problems of atomic power plants will be solved and that these plants are preferable to coal burning plants. I well recognise the problems of these plants. I visited one in the making and I have seen the excellence of the engineering designs and the operation controls. I feel they are desirable because they are less polluting than coal burning furnaces. The fall-out of acid from coal burning plants is well documented and the extreme health risk in winning the coal for the use of those plants, I believe, makes the atomic power plants the lesser of two evils. Of course there are some dangers in the conversion of material to energy, whatever it may be, but my judgment is that the atomic plants have less total danger to the community than the coal burning plants. Having said that, it obviously flows that I believe in uranium mining. I do not believe we should stop such mining provided it is done with care. The Northern Territory has about 80 per cent of Australia's known uranium ore reserves. They have been found in a very small area. There is about a 400 kilometre strip of possible mineralisation in the area known as Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park and to date only about 15 kilometres of that 400 kilometres has been adequately examined for mineralisation. So we have some 385 kilometres to drill and test. I do not believe companies will do that if an area that they wish to test is likely to be declared as a national park.

The area of the Territory where the uranium ore is likely to be found should, I believe, be thoroughly examined. As a first stage I believe the Federal Government should remove itself from control of the Kakadu National Park. As a Tasmanian senator, I take very strong exception to the Federal Government trying to control a national park in Tasmania. So I feel the Federal Government should abandon its control of the Kakadu National Park to the Northern Territory and let the people in control of that Territory decide what should be done there.

I now want to say something about South Africa. Much has been said about it in the news over the last few weeks. We should, I believe, remember that South Africa was one of our allies in the last war. We should remember that it is strategically important both from a location point of view and as a source of minerals. It is my belief that the Soviets are behind the attempts to take over South Africa. If they get control of that country they will have control of several very important minerals including chromium and a couple of other strategically important minerals. Their availability in the world will be controlled almost totally by the Soviets if they get control of South Africa.

South Africa is important from a defence point of view. It is quite clear that any country which controls the Cape by which a ship goes every 30 seconds will have a very important area under its control. I believe we should be recognising that South Africa is gradually changing and gradually doing more for all of its people. If things are so bad for the blacks in South Africa why are so many blacks trying to get into the country from other African countries? The answer is obvious: Blacks in South Africa obviously are better off than are the blacks in many other countries near South Africa. I believe it is time we looked again at our attitude to that country. I believe it is time we sent Qantas flying into that country--

TALK.START.PARA: —What will they think of this at CHOGM?

—At least nine of the Commonwealth countries that are coming to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting fly their aircraft into South Africa right now. I believe the United States is now adopting a sensible attitude and we should follow suit.

SPEECH.PARA: We should keep the situation of South Africa in a sensible perspective. An article I read in Notes on the News dated 30 June documents the situation well, I think. I have shown the article to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). To save the time of the Senate I seek leave to have that article by Mr Ian Hancock, Senior Lecturer in History at the Australian National University, incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Nigerian Foreign Minister is reported to have said in Nairobi, where he was attending a summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity, that New Zealand would not be missed from the Commonwealth. After all, it only had a population of 2 1/2 million people. He almost sounded like those Australians who so irritate New Zealanders by their haughty disdain. The Foreign Minister however, had his own reasons for such a display of arrogance. Nigeria is probably the most self-confident country in Africa, the second richest after South Africa on the continent, an exporter of oil wooed by the West and notably by Britain and the United States. Nigeria also seems to have assumed Tanzania's role as the conscience of Africa, as the State which admonishes the West for racism and neo-colonialism and insists on tougher action over South Africa. And like all self-confident States, Nigeria is not greatly troubled by double standards. Although it still holds the record within Africa for killing more of its own citizens, although two of its largest growth industries are corruption and violent crime, Nigeria does not hesitate in commenting on moral lapses, domestic misconduct and the violation of human rights whether they occur in Africa or abroad. So New Zealanders must learn to live with a high moral purpose and uncompromising principles of a distinctly unprincipled giant of the Commonwealth. Yet they could complain that the Foreign Minister did overlook New Zealand's outstanding contribution to Black Africa. For Mr Muldoon has achieved for Africa what Africa finds so hard to do for itself. He has forged an impressive unity, at least in relation to the proposed Springbok rugby tour of New Zealand. Nothing brings Africa's political leaders together quite so readily as a small country thousands of miles away whose Government will not forbid a sporting organization sharing the national religion with a few hefty South Africans. The New Zealand Government is plainly puzzled and annoyed by the African attitude. Notwithstanding the remarks of the Australian Foreign Minister, it has conformed to the Gleneagles Agreement. More important, New Zealanders, with a better race relations record than say Australia, find it peculiar that they should be singled out for attention. Perhaps one reason is that their country is small and isolated. Even then, why get worked up over a game of rugby which Africans to their credit don't play anyway, and ignore the flagrant breaches by African States of supposed embargoes on contact with South Africa. Robert Mugabe, the Prime Minister of Zimbabwe, an avowed socialist and current revolutionary hero in Africa, is open and unashamed about it all.

Arriving in Nairobi for the Summit Meeting, he said Zimbabwe had to continue trading with South Africa. He supported a liberation movement and he hoped that the Organisation of African Unity would take steps to advance the cause. But Zimbabwe's economic survival depended on buying and selling in South Africa. Ninety per cent of Zimbabwe's trade went through the Republic. Current relations between Zimbabwe and South Africa are deteriorating but this is no time for brave words let alone suicidal action by the Zimbabwe Prime Minister. Nor is Zimbabwe alone in Southern Africa in its dependence on the South African connection. What is perhaps more significant is the number of African Commonwealth States to say nothing of the rest, who trade openly or under cover when they have no desperate need to do so. And on this point, the Nigerian Foreign Minister might well look at his own country's besmirched record, for the moralists are so often pragmatists in the region around the pocket. The bitter hatred of apartheid is genuine and deep but it competes with what is sometimes called realism. If New Zealanders are understandably upset by what they see as double standards and are hurt about being singled out for attack, Mr Muldoon has indicated a willingness to hit back. He wants to raise the issue of human rights at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne in September. Already, he has been preempted by the Commonwealth Secretariat which has pointed out that this issue is at present under investigation. Such an investigation need not look very far. The most recently published African Research Bulletin, which assembles political material on a monthly basis, mainly from the press, suggests that Africa as a whole had another disturbed month in May. There was a report of 600 tribesmen being killed in Ghana, renewed fighting in the north eastern border area of Kenya where Somalis wish to establish their right to self determination, continuing fighting in Uganda as opposition groups try to upset last year's election result, a result incidentally, pronounced fair and reasonable by a Commonwealth observer group which must have been looking the other way at the time, a border clash between Nigeria and Cameroon, a pending treason trial in Zambia. Among the non-Commonwealth countries we learn of continued attempts to persuade Colonel Gaddafi to vacate occupied Chad and the Summit Meeting in Nairobi now proposes to replace the Libyans with a peace keeping force. The continuing war in the Western Sahara, which the Nairobi Summit hoped to end by overseeing a referendum whereby the people themselves will actually be asked who they want as governors, the dissolution of the equivalent of the ACTU in the Central African Republic which has also postponed elections, the arrest of plotters in Equatorial Guinea and 6 men sentenced to death in Angola for opposition to the Government. On the other hand, there's a prettier side to the picture. Two men in Kenya were actually found not guilty at a treason trial. The former Egyptian Vice President was released 10 years after he attempted a coup against Mr Sudat. Members of the exiled opposition party in Lesotho have been given an amnesty and political prisoners in Liberia and Sierra Leone have been released. So the story is not one of unrelieved gloom but the month of May was nonetheless a typical one, typical that is, of an Africa which is politically unstable and uncertain, where much is said about human rights and where violations seem endemic whether initiated by Government or by opposition. Mr Muldoon in that no nonsense way of his; may be tempted to make some of these points in Melbourne. Whether this would achieve anything is another question. Few countries are restrained by the presence of motes in their own eyes, they merely point out that such considerations are irrelevant, that the overriding issue in this case is the persistence of apartheid in South Africa and that the overwhelming need is to isolate South Africa by means which don't greatly hurt the Black States themselves. Two principles stand in total opposition. New Zealand's belief in the right of sportsmen not to be subjected to political control, Africa's conviction that Pretoria is so much of an enemy that other considerations are secondary. The one hope is that the Commonwealth performs another of its healing miracles, that the prophets of doom have overlooked the remarkable track record of snatching reconciliation from the jaws of confrontation.
