SPEECH.PARA: I would like to commence my remarks by expressing my appreciation to the members of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union and the Australian Labor Party who have been so encouraging to me all my life. I am grateful to the many friends I have made in the Labor movement over 25 years, and I am grateful for their generous support. I will do my best to reflect the aspirations of the Labor Party in giving voice to the needs and hopes of the citizens of New South Wales and Australia. It is ironic that as a young apprentice I spoke for the first time in public at a meeting of apprentices convened by the printing trades union. At that meeting I moved a motion condemning the Budget of the then Treasurer, Sir Arthur Fadden, in the Menzies Government. The Budget was known as the horror Budget of 1951. That Budget's salient features were a 10 per cent surcharge on income tax, increased sales tax and the restriction of credit for home builders and small business. It has a familiar ring, has it not? I was able to persuade my fellow apprentices and the motion was carried. I wish it was as easy tonight. Subsequently, I was elected an organiser of the printers union and eventually State secretary. On many occasions I led delegations to this place protesting at the Budgets of Liberal-Country Party governments.

In 1971 I was elected Assistant General Secretary of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales and I had the satisfaction of participating in the election of the Whitlam Labor Governments of 1972 and 1974. I was proud to see the Labor Government return Australia to the world scene as a strong, independent nation. This was in sharp contrast to the subservient mentality of Liberal Country Party governments of the previous 23 years. This mentality led to a profound neglect of the true needs of the Australian people. The Whitlam Labor Government, with its fundamentally different priorities, raised the standards of health, housing, education and social services to a decent level. The Labor Government, had, in a three-year period, a wealth of achievements. Three that I regard as particularly significant were the fostering and development of Australian national identity and culture, the recognition of the needs of non-British speaking citizens and equal pay for women. History records that in 1975 the Establishment could not tolerate the reforms of the Whitlam Labor Government and it was sacked. We learned the bitter lesson of the difference between being in government and being in power. The Fraser regime commenced. In August 1977 the National Times said of the Fraser Government's second Budget:

He has set himself a target of sharply changing the balance of power in our society by diminishing the power of the unions and setting out to redistribute the national wealth up the salary scale to those whom he believes are the productive members of our society.

The National Times described the Budget as one that could 'endanger the stability of the country'. The National Times then went on to say that the Budget was a 'declaration of class war'. The Budget we are discussing tonight can be understood only within the context of the Fraser Government's economic strategy from when it came to power until now. The Government's strategy is a class war, the class war which the National Times prophesied. The Fraser Government, of course, makes the Menzies-Fadden Government look amateurish in what it has done to the Australian people. This Government is waging this class war by using all its resources to boost the profits of the foreign dominated corporate sector at the expense of the Australian people, particularly the wage and salary earners. This Government has attacked the working people by its opposition to wage indexation. It has also amended the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to the detriment of the economic interests of wage and salary earners. At the same time, this Government has cut back savagely on expenditure on the essential needs of the Australian people in health, housing, welfare and education-what could be called the social wage.

Even worse, this Government has abandoned the actual provision of many of these essential services to the jungle of so-called private enterprise. For example, whilst the funds for public health have been slashed, the Government in this Budget has given an enormous increase in subsidies to private surgical hospitals. Perhaps the most blatant example of the Government's inhumanity to the casualties of this society is its total withdrawal of the provision of funds to women's refuges-refuges which protect the lives of some of the most vulnerable people in our society. This Government is practising class discrimination because it is using the money it has taken from the Australian people to give massive subsidies to the corporate sector, particularly the multinational companies. This Government's strategy is to encourage an uncontrolled spread of the foreign controlled resource sector of our economy. In doing so, this Government has locked Australia into a pathologically one-sided development path. The Fraser Government is fulfilling the role of a comprador in that it is facilitating the takeover of Australia's resources and industry by multinational companies. So this Government is causing Australia increasingly to resemble those Latin American countries which have lost every vestige of independence.

The two key sections of the Australian Bureau of Statistics that covered foreign investment and capital flows-the foreign participation section and the import orders section-have been closed down. When they were established by the Labor Government they had a total staff of 60. Now there is one person left in the import section. This is the answer in part to the question which my colleague Senator Bolkus asked this afternoon and which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) could not answer. This means that we do not have anywhere near enough information to make an intelligent decision on how to deal with the rapidly increasing foreign presence in our industry. In contrast, let us look at my own industry, the printing and packaging industry. It is part of the vital manufacturing industry base of the New South Wales economy. The printing industry is only 10 per cent foreign owned and is characteristically the industry of small and medium sized factories. My industry, in common with all manufacturing industries, is being damaged by this Government's economic strategy.

It is my belief that this comprador Government has coldly and deliberately implemented the will of the multinational companies by squeezing the domestic economy, dismantling the established industrial base, particularly in manufacturing and home building, shifting the labour and capital out of it, cutting back the public sector's demand for funds, making room for foreign investment and transferring Australian investment to other sectors, promoting exports and removing the barriers that prevent a flood of imports into this country. Thanks to the cringe mentality of conservative governments, half of our industry is subject to foreign ownership and control, and that proportion is rising. Three of every four dollars in foreign investment in this country is designed to take over existing Australian businesses and remove their profits from Australian hands. Two of every three dollars of total company income is being paid overseas.

Let us look at some detailed figures which support my argument that the Government favours the corporate sector at the expense of wage and salary earners. What has happened to individual taxpayers since this Government began its strategy in 1975? Looking at individual taxation alone, we find that while wages and salaries have gone up by only 71 per cent, tax paid by those workers has risen by 101 per cent. On the other hand, while wealthy non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers' income from rent, interest, dividends, et cetera, has risen by over 80 per cent over the period, tax paid rose by only 55 per cent. As an example, let us take two workers at opposite ends of the scale. In 1975 one worker earned $3,700 and the other $30,000. How have these two taxpayers fared under this Government? The first is now earning $6,000 a year and has had his after tax income cut by $113 in 1981 terms. Twenty-eight per cent of our citizens are receiving salaries of $6,000 or less.

Let us take the person at the upper end of the scale. That person is now receiving $50,000 and has had his or her after-tax income lifted by $2,400 a year, nearly $50 a week. A person in the middle of the range on, say, $10,000 a year, with a spouse and two children, is, even taking the family allowance and the spouse rebate into account, still $266 worse off, compared with 1975. Looking at total tax collections, personal income tax has risen from 41 per cent to 45 per cent of the total. Company tax, however, has declined as a source of revenue from 15 per cent to 13.7 per cent of tax revenue. This year alone personal tax receipts will rise by 22 per cent while wages will rise, at the most, by 13.5 per cent. Company tax receipts will rise by only 10 per cent as against a jump in profits of 18 per cent.

Two industries have been selected by the Government for special attack. One is the printing industry and the other is the home building industry. They are both threatened to be slugged by a ruinous sales tax. Tomorrow I will present another petition signed by officers, executive members and delegates of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That petition opposes sales tax increases on printed goods and paper products and suggests that the loss of revenue be made up by a resource rental tax. The trade union leaders know what a threat to the cost of living these sales tax increases are. That is why they are supporting this petition against the sales tax increases.

I want to illustrate what this new sales tax threatens in the printing industry. In spite of our ocker image, Australia is a nation of readers. Australians, with an annual book expenditure of $530m, are second only to New Zealand as book buyers in the world. That is only books. It is therefore all the more pernicious for an Australian government to put a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers. In effect, it is a tax on knowledge. It is likely that the retail price of books will rise by 10 per cent and the impact of this on struggling publishers will be a burden they cannot stand. How hypocritical the Government is. Last month the Prime Minister, at the anniversary of Quadrant magazine, said that Quadrant was to be congratulated for struggling against all odds and surviving. The next day the Government introduced a sales tax on magazines. I am not concerned about the wealthy Quadrant but I am concerned about the social, sporting and community publications as well as local papers, newsletters and club magazines, all of which are the very heart of our democracy. They are an essential part of the printing industry. They make our democracy strong. This Government has the thin end of the wedge with this tax because there is no stopping any of these increases, except by defeating the Government itself.

The cost of learning to students will rise, our culture will suffer and students will have to pay more for their books. It is typical of how out of touch this Government is with young people and their problems. I started by speaking about my youth but I know how hard it is now for young people to survive, how difficult it is for them to exist in this society at present. What do we have from this Government? We have a kangaroo strategy. It has removed a program of proven quality-the Community Youth Support Scheme-and has substituted an inferior product, in this case the School to Work Transition Program. It is kangaroo strategy all the time.

Just as serious as the sales tax is the complementary problem of escalating interest rates. This is best illustrated in human terms by the increased mortgage payments which already are causing Australian families to worry about the forced sale of their homes. It is incredible, but people are actually having it posed to them that they should sell their houses and go to districts that they can afford. Escalating interest rates also threaten small and medium size business. It is my belief that the main cause of this serious threat is the imbalance in the Australian economy resulting from the activity of multinational companies. The multinational companies are buying up Australia at an alarming rate. They are doing this by using Australian money to finance their operations and make their profits. Even when multinational companies use overseas money their investment puts pressure on interest rates because of the Government's fanatical obsession with containing the money supply. Last year Australia had $6 billion in foreign investment and because of this Government's policies, interest rates rose. If money comes in one way and the Government drains it off to elsewhere at the expense of small business and housing, we have problems. The Government has sat back and allowed foreign companies to ship out of Australia from 1975 to 1980 $1.5 billion more than they have invested. The Vernon report, commissioned by the Menzies Government in 1965, prophesied this development. It said:

Once an economy has a substantial body of overseas investment, it is in a sense 'on the tiger's back' unless the trade balance is improving sufficiently to meet the additional income payable overseas.
The continuation of capital inflow becomes seemingly more and more desirable as a means of offsetting the increasing payments on the latter account.

As the annual amounts become larger, the immediate consequences for the economy of an interruption of the capital inflow, either contrived or occurring by reason of external circumstances, become more and more serious.

This Government is riding that tiger. Last year, for the first time in seven years, Australia received a lot more investment than the amount of profits shipped out, but the money has to be repaid in profit and dividends again and again. Nobody knows whether the inflow of foreign money will be halved or doubled in the future. The effect of such unpredictable changes in capital inflow on the ownership and viability of Australian industry could be devastating.

The general theme of my comments has been the danger of reliance on foreign investment. I strongly criticise the lack of balance in the development of our economy and the lack of planning in the allocation of resources. I question the biased direction of what little planning does occur. The vital questions-who will benefit and who will lose-are not being faced by this Government. The Australian Labor Party is facing these questions; that is the difference between it and the Government. We have proposed stringent measures designed to establish majority Australian equity in all projects, as well as the careful monitoring of foreign companies and especially their transfer pricing practices. Labor would organise a greater mobilisation of Australian capital, including public sector equity holdings through the Australian Industry Development Corporation, to ensure greater Australian participation and control in the development of our resources and industry. As a great British democratic socialist, Aneurin Bevan, said, 'Not even the apparently enlightened principle of the greatest good for the greatest number can excuse indifference to individual suffering'. A conscripted army of two million unemployed or underemployed Australians is living in or on the edge of poverty. Big business has enough friends in this Government. I hope my voice on behalf of the Australian Labor Party will improve the odds for those people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my congratulations on the excellent maiden speeches delivered to the Senate this evening. This is a debate on the 1981-82 Budget and I intend now to direct my remarks to that infamous document. The 1981-82 Budget shows that the Government is determined to take Australia down the same grim monetarist path as Thatcher's Britain. In budgeting for a domestic surplus of $1,542m the Government has used almost every trick in the book to take money out of the economy. For example, this Government will be the first in Australia to tax the free flow of information, with a tax on books, magazines and newspapers, and the first to tax the basic necessities of life, such as clothing, footwear, shelter, education and wrapping materials for food and medicine. One hopes it will be the last.

SPEECH.PARA: The increases in sales tax, whilst reprehensible, are not the most powerful sting in the Budget. The greatest hit will be in personal income tax. This Government will take $3,300m more than it took last year-an increase of 19 per cent in one year. Someone receiving average weekly earnings of $295 a week now pays $68 a week in tax. The Government predicts that this same person will be earning $334 by the end of June next year and, because this Government has abandoned tax indexation, that person will be paying $81 in tax. By June next year people earning only 2 per cent more than average weekly earnings will be paying a marginal tax rate of 46 per cent. Truly, in Mr Fraser's famous words, 'circumstances change'. Three years ago, almost to the day, the Prime Minister said:

. . . we said that we wanted to end for all time the deceit of a tax system which, through the process of inflation, brought larger and larger funds to the coffers of the Government. We said that if governments wanted more funds, they should tax for them openly and plainly . . .

In the Australian Democrats' alternative Budget, we allocated $1,100m for personal income tax indexation and the restructuring of income tax. This was to be paid for by a resource tax and the abolition of the investment allowance. But tax indexation was not the only area in which circumstances changed. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, earlier this year emphatically denied that the Govenment intended to introduce a value added tax. True to his word, he has not introduced it. Instead, he has introduced a broadly based sales tax, with very similar effect.

I turn now to some of the less obvious taxes and imposts that the Government has introduced. Before doing so, let me briefly mention interest rates. In the last seven years, interest rates for new housing loans to individuals have increased from 8 per cent to as high as 14 per cent. Interest repayments on a 20 year loan of $30,000 are now around $40 a week as a result of the Government's policy, which has brought about the highest domestic interest rates in Australia's history. Families are now compelled to insure their health to avoid the risk of bankruptcy. Last year, a person could take the risk of not taking out health insurance, because he received free treatment from a public hospital and paid no more than $20 to visit a doctor. This year the Government has changed the rules for the fifth time, so that that person must pay at least $15 if he obtains treatment at a hospital; and now the Government will not pay that person a cent for visiting a doctor if he does not already have medical insurance. Hospital and medical insurance will cost about an additional $10 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus a tax rebate, Senator. A lesser rebate.
—Indeed.
—On the basic amount.
—Nevertheless, let us get the complete picture.

—I press on with another very important indirect cost, that is the cost of owning a motor car. The failure of this Government to tackle seriously the problems of urban transport forces most families to own at least one motor car. The cost of running a motor car has greatly increased, thanks to the Government's crude oil levy. This year the Government expects to receive more than $3,400m from the crude oil levy. This is money which was not raised eight years ago. It is money which any reasonable person would consider should be made available for spending on housing, roads, education or health. If one aggregates the cost of the tax increases that I have outlined-the real costs and not just the inflated boosted value and the cost of the new health insurance arrangements-one finds that taxpayers will be paying something like $13 a week more under this Budget, just in those tax increases. If one adds in the cost of the crude oil levy, taxpayers are each $22 a week worse off. Together, this adds up to $1,200 a year that the householder is worse off. Sales tax has increased by nearly $600m in real terms, and income tax has increased by $1,400m. Health insurance will cost the community around $1,800m while the crude oil levy is expected to raise more than $3,400m.

SPEECH.PARA: How is the Government proposing to spend this enormous increase in revenue? Sensible people might assume that at least some of the money would have been directed to labour intensive sectors of the economy such as housing and road building. Sensible people might think that the Government ought to be interested in alleviating unemployment by employing people in socially useful projects. Instead, this Government has decided to buy expensive toys such as aeroplanes for the Royal Australian Air Force and ships for the Navy; to withdraw unemployment benefits from the spouses of the people on strike; to decrease the real living standard of the majority of Australians. Funds to the States for welfare housing have been cut by 25 per cent. The States are now paying back more in interest on previous loans than they receive from the Commonwealth.

In the Democrats' alternative Budget, grants and loans for welfare housing to the States would have been increased by $165m. In addition we would have allocated $200m to subsidise interest rates for home buyers. We would have allocated $35m to assist housing co-operatives, cost-rent housing associations and other innovative means of providing shelter. In addition, we would have restructured the housing grants scheme to provide loans of between $1,000 and $5,000 to approximately 15,000 first home buyers to assist them in overcoming the deposit gap. These measures would have cost a total of $400m. Our Budget would have selectively stimulated the economy. Employment, living standards and company profits would have increased, as would income tax receipts, despite indexation, and we budgeted-I stress this-for a domestic surplus of $300m, not $1,500m.

In this Budget spending on roads has been cut to such a degree that municipalities throughout the country can barely afford to maintain existing roads, let alone improve the road network. For example, it has been estimated that capital works costing in the region of $100m need to be undertaken before the year 2000 to provide an adequate road network in Diamond Valley, near Melbourne, the area from which I come. Yet the funds available are likely to amount to no more than 40 per cent of this figure.

Per capita spending on education and health has not increased in this Budget. This Government seems determined to de-educate Australia. During its period of office, participation rates in post-secondary education in Australia have fallen to amongst the lowest in the industrialised world. In Australia, 5.7 per cent of people in the age group from 20 to 24 are attending university. The average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries is 17.3 per cent. That is three times as many. In the United States between 1960 and 1980, 75.8 per cent of people aged from 15 to 19 participated in full time education. In Australia, only 46.2 per cent participated in full time education, and this figure has declined. The difference is dramatic. In the 1980s and the 1990s we will surely reap a tragic harvest of under-education and under-employment, increasing social unrest, violence in the streets and radical political movements committed to the destruction of our society. Nowhere in this Government's mean and short-sighted approach is it more evident than in its attitude to student assistance. Student allowances are still basically the same as they were in 1974, during which time inflation was cut and their real value is now only 50 per cent of what it was. It is no longer possible for tertiary students to survive on payments under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme alone. The Government's refusal to recognise the value to the community of well educated people is tragic. The Democrats, in their alternative Budget, would have increased spending on student allowances by $70m in real terms, enabling an appropriate increase in TEAS and other student allowances.

For many years conservative politicians used the construction of hospitals and dams as crude electoral devices. Obscure corners of Australia are littered with hospitals and dams-it has herds of white elephants. In a sense, this Government is to be congratulated. Porkbarreling in the hospital construction business has ceased. Hospital construction has virtually ceased also. Indeed, with the exception of Victoria and Tasmania, States throughout the Commonwealth will probably have to close some hospitals to meet Commonwealth requirements. The waste of resources is gross. The inefficiencies revealed by the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals are an indictment of health planning. The refusal of the Government to provide adequate services for the elderly, who now comprise up to 50 per cent of the patients in general acute hospitals, is a national scandal.

It is important to realise that the Government's changes to the way hospitals and health care are financed have not reduced the cost to the community. In fact, the cost will probably increase. But the Government is not returning its saving to the community. In the true spirit of its so-called new federalism the Government has thrust responsibility for the community health centre and school dental programs onto the States and has then refused to fund them directly. The Democrats would have increased real spending on health by about 7 per cent and funded community health centres and women's refuges. We would have also introduced a concessional card for pharmaceuticals for children under 10 years, elderly people 70 years and over and the chronically ill. The estimated cost of this initiative was $30m.

I now turn briefly to social security. This Government has not increased unemployment benefits to unemployed people under 18 years of age since 1975. If they had risen with the consumer price index they would now be about $64 a week. Instead, they are still only $36. The Government is very proud of having increased from $3 to $8 a week supplementary assistance payable to pensioners who pay rent. However, in future, pensioners who receive assistance as public housing tenants will not receive a supplementary grant, so many of them will not be better off. The Government has also decided to amend the Social Services Act 1947 to prevent payment of unemployment benefits to the spouse of persons engaged in industrial action. In our view this is inhumane and confrontationist, and we will oppose the amendment.

To have in one Budget such a massive increase in the tax take and, at the same time, a massive squeeze on the essentials of life is in our view, reprehensible. Not even the most right wing, conservative President in the United States since the Herbert Hoover has increased taxes while slashing spending. At least he has substantially reduced taxation. This Government has done the exact opposite. It has had the temerity to hit the ordinary man both ways. It has taken from him and reduced what it is giving back to him. No Government should be allowed to get away with this approach. The Democrats will not stand by and allow it to happen without taking some action. We have given undertakings to the Australian people not to block Supply and we will honour those undertakings. We will also not interfere with government revenue raising because it can be argued that to stop government revenue raising is tantamount to stopping the Government spending it. The Democrats are not prepared to act in the same disgusting manner in which the conservatives brought about elections in 1974 and 1975.

The Senate does, however, have the power to amend Appropriation Bill (No. 2), although it may not increase the total amount the Government plans to spend. For example, the allocation to the States for public housing could be increased at the expense of the new Parliament House or the capital program for the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The Democrats have no intention of abrogating their rights as senators to amend this Bill and other Bills with which they fundamentally disagree. Our undertaking not to block Supply can in no way be construed as affecting our freedom to act as we see fit in moving amendments to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) and other Bills. We believe, however, that the first step the Senate should take is to request the House of Representatives to alter its Budget strategy to spend more on housing by reducing the size of the $1.5m surplus. If the Government takes no heed of such a request from the Senate we will make it clear that we intend to move to amend Appropriation Bill (No. 2).

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Foreman I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech in this chamber. I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would first like to congratulate you on being elected as President of the Senate and I also extend congratulations to the Deputy President who has recently left the chamber. I say, firstly, that I am deeply honoured to take my place in the Senate and to speak in this debate on behalf of the Opposition and my party. The debate on the Budget gives members the chance to range broadly in their treatment of individual issues. I intend to take full advantage of this privilege but in commencing my remarks I will make some general philosophical comments about my own presence in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I say at the outset that I regard it as a great honour to represent in this Parliament the Australian Labor Party and the people of South Australia who selected me as their member to follow in the footsteps of my friend and colleague, Reg Bishop. As a newly elected member one has to look very seriously at the privileges and the obligations of parliamentary life. Some argue that the Parliament is no longer relevant and that the answers to political problems lie outside the institution of parliament. It is my firm belief that with all the faults the parliamentary system has served the Australian people well. I see no substitute for it if the Labor Party is to achieve its great goal of social equality.

I have served my apprenticeship in a number of occupations. This is only the beginning, I hope, of the apprenticeship I will serve in this Parliament. Before looking in some detail at the broader issues I would like to take the Senate back to my apprenticeship in the car industry and afterwards to the time when I worked as a representative of those workers in that industry as a trade union official. That is an experience which many members of the Labor Party have had before me. A number of my colleagues who have since retired served their industrial training and received their early grounding in politics in the vehicle industry. I refer to Mr Fred Birrell, who was the member for Port Adelaide, and two former senators, Clem Ridley and Jim Toohey. But for the dedication to hard union politics stimulated by car industry life I am sure I would have never made my way to this chamber.

At this point I would like to indicate that besides spending most of my working life in the automobile industry, I was born in the mid-north country town of Clare in South Australia where my parents had a vineyard and later a business. Before I go any further I wish to express appreciation to my children, Luke and Lindy and to Shirley Lewis and her daughter Tracey, who are all present tonight, as well as to other members of my family for their assistance and understanding over many years. I also indicate that three former members of parliament have travelled from Adelaide to be with us this evening. They are Mr Clyde Cameron, the former member for Hindmarsh, his brother the former Senator Donald Cameron and former Senator Jim Toohey. To those loyal and dedicated members of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia I extend my sincere thanks for their support and assistance.

I turn now to the car industry. I believe that massive industry unemployment would follow if the Industries Assistance Commission proposals to rationalise the industry were put into action. Once again the IAC had lived up to its nickname of the Industries Assassination Commission. Some of the recommendations of the report are: An end to the industry's manufacturing plan from 1985; an end to the 80 per cent share of the market reserved for locally produced vehicles; an end to quota restrictions which presently stand at 20,000 units; tariffs to be wound down from 57 1/2 per cent to 35 per cent between 1985 and 1990; components to suffer a similar reduction in duty; export facilitation to be increased by an additional 10 per cent, on top of the 7 per cent, due to come into operation by the end of 1985 as already announced; passenger vehicles derivatives to be reduced from 45 per cent to 35 per cent by the end of 1988; CKD components to be treated as components; and component producers to be granted 20 per cent credit for imports. These recommendations will leave the industry wide open to a flood of imports which would have a devastating effect on employment. Even the IAC's own figures show that employment in the whole of the industry has been slashed in the past five years by 25,000 jobs. The removal of quotas will accelerate this trend. As we have seen already over the past 12 months, imports have increased dramatically, aided by the appreciation of the Australian dollar.

In the whitegoods industry, where quotas do not exist, the market share held by Australian produced washing machines has fallen by 11 per cent over the last 12 months. This was due to appreciation of the dollar and dumping of goods by Japan. The same thing will happen to the motor vehicle industry if quotas are abolished. Of course, importers point out that prices of cars would come down-but for how long? Only until overseas companies had achieved a satisfactory market share. The cost to those Australian families whose livelihood depends on this industry would be enormous. In my State alone between 15,000 and 20,000 jobs directly involved in motor vehicle or component manufacture would be threatened, increasing the State's unemployment rate to over 11 per cent.

The South Australian economy is highly dependent on the motor vehicle industry. Nearly 20 per cent of the State's manufacturing work force is dependent on motor vehicle assembly or component manufacture. Even the study by Professor Parry of the University of New South Wales, commissioned by the importers group, admits that Adelaide will be a major problem when it comes to coping with job losses caused by IAC recommendations. The demise of motor vehicle manufacture in South Australia will have repercussions for the rest of the State's economy and through multiplier effects thousands more jobs would be threatened. Indeed, the South Australian Liberal Government's Minister of Industrial Affairs stated that a further 80,000 jobs would be lost in South Australia through these multiplier effects. This would be disastrous for the people of South Australia. I believe we should resist to the bitter end any attack on employment in the industry through the proposed restructuring.

The people aspect of this industry has not been considered at all by the IAC. This is despite the fact that the employees' representatives in the industry, the unions, have appeared before the Commission on numerous occasions and put that point of view. Neither the IAC nor the Liberal Government is interested in what happens to people. I believe it will now have to be up to the Labor Party and the unions to demonstrate that the people are the most important part of the industry's wealth and of the country's resources. The IAC is content to put the profits of the multinationals first. But what it does not take into account is the cost in human terms. It is not only a question of the cost to the economy of an additional 30,000 people on the dole queue, but also a question of the loss of skills within the community and a loss of manufacturing capacity and design and technical skills which are vital in the maintenance of a strong manufacturing base and for essential defence industries.

I believe the Government should be called upon to initiate a national inquiry into the effects on employment of the proposed changes announced by the Government. The IAC's proposed changes make earlier proposals look like chicken- feed. The time for a national inquiry is ripe. There is no family which has not been affected in some way by Fraserism. Apart from the IAC proposals, Australian workers will suffer greatly from the combined effects of the razor gang, the decision to reduce Federal grants to the States, interest rate jumps and increases in taxation. The Fraser Government claims it is fighting inflation, but something is drastically wrong with its formula. As it slashes away at Government spending, inflation is not falling but rising. The consumer price index rose by 7.6 per cent in 1979-80 and 8.8 per cent in 1980-81 and is predicted to increase by more than 11 per cent in the next 12 months. Of course, the figure which the Government uses to measure inflation, excludes petrol and hospital and medical costs. The best measure of inflation across the economy is the gross non-farm product deflator which rose by 10.7 per cent in 1980-81, considerably higher than the 8.8 per cent claimed by the Government. One-fifth of all inflation which has occurred since 1975-and this was before the latest change in health insurance-has been caused by Government decisions. Goods which cost $1 in June 1976 had inflated to $1.63 by June 1981. Twelve cents of this increase has been deliberately added by Government decisions, such as the petrol pricing policy, which has helped to depress the car industry.

The Government's oil parity pricing policy under which petrol prices have risen by more than 74 per cent in the last three years, has made a major contribution to the rate of inflation. The average Australian family is now paying $5.60 a week more to use its car than it paid a year ago. This policy has added more than $11 billion to Government tax revenue since it was introduced and this year alone it will add a further $3.4 billion. This Government has been deliberately using world oil prices to tax Australians for oil which comes mostly from Bass Strait. Of course, what it does not tell us, is that the price of petrol in Canada, which like Australia produces a significant proportion of its oil needs, is considerably lower than in Australia.

I turn now to health. The change in the health insurance system has brought this country back to the situation which existed in 1971 before the Whitlam Labor Government introduced Medibank. Workers will now be paying up to $11 a week for basic family health cover to provide the minimum security for their families in the event of sickness or injury and this includes those families which are just a few dollars above the cut-off line for free health care. This money is going to an array of inefficient privately-owned health insurance funds which are making profits out of people's health. A single more efficient government-owned health scheme could provide the same service at a much lower cost to the public. Australians have been deliberately misled by this Government's propaganda machine. They are paying a fortune just to choose between a variety of inefficient health funds which essentially provide the same service. The West German health system makes ours look like a backyard operation.

On the subject of health, industry is under threat much more from an overall decline in workers' health than from unions or strikes. The figures show clearly that more people lose time at work through sickness and injury than through strikes. For every day lost because of strikes, one or two days were lost through industrial accidents, three due to alcoholism and seven due to other sickness. Workers and families need protection through a universal and cost efficient insurance scheme, which Medibank was before Fraser and his gang dismantled it. Also, I believe that the scaling down of Government-owned enterprises not only would further prove a false economy but also would cause great distress among workers employed by such operations as the Australian Government Clothing Factory in Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo which have been listed for cut backs and closure.

On the question of wages, while resisting worker demands for higher wages on the ground that they cannot afford them, the bosses continue to give themselves generous increases. The latest figures show that chief executives' wages increased by 14.8 per cent during the last 12 months-exactly double the indexation rise paid to the workers. These figures were contained in a six-monthly survey by Chandler and McLeod Consultants Pty Ltd, which reports on salaries and executive remuneration. The survey, across a range of managers from foremen to managing directors, showed that all of them had greater pay rises in 1980 than in 1979. The range of salary increases to the bosses was 52.7 per cent greater than the indexation increases to the workers in more than half the cases. The companies even had the cheek to say that the indexation decision had been a major factor in the fixing of their own increases. They clearly used indexation as the starting figure and built on that. Indeed, if the Government had got its own way, and real wages had not increased in the last 12 months, retail sales and economic growth would have suffered. Clearly, the increase in real wages contributed substantially to economic growth in 1980-81-about 70 per cent of gross domestic product growth.

I now turn to the question of employment and I particularly refer to the unskilled young. Continuing unemployment could form a new underclass of have-nots. Such a class could be a destabilising element in society, producing problems like those now being experienced in Britain. What some believe is happening is the formation of a new underclass of people who are permanently out of the mainstream of society. They will not have the education or skills to get a foot on the ladder. The new underclass which some people thought would emerge could easily be a group of disspirited young people not able to get work at the beginning of their careers and possibly no longer suited to work after a few years of unemployment. We may find a high proportion of the young at the most energetic period of their lives aimless and without anything to do. The abandonment of the Community Youth Support Scheme will only exacerbate the situation.

Recent statements made by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) show that he has a total lack of understanding of the problems facing young unemployed people. Unless there is something more concrete done, we face the prospect of their being sufficient numbers of young unemployed people to act as a destabilising element in society. If we want very vivid evidence of how quickly this can become a problem, we have only to look at Britain. Jobs have to be generated, not just an array of dressed up training schemes which are designed only to give handouts to employers. The National Employment and Training scheme is a prime example. It has been exploited by employers seeking to make a fast buck and get cheap labour, while the training aspect has often been neglected. Other schemes seek to equip young people with more skills, but they still do not give them jobs.

Not only are young people out of work, but also the number of jobs available to them has been declining steadily. Over the last 15 years, the number of full time jobs for young people in the 15 to 19 age group has declined by nearly 100,000. At the same time, there has been an increase of about 250,000 in the number of youngsters in that group. The decline has been particularly severe for females with 24 per cent of their jobs disappearing as against 6 per cent for males. I, along with a lot of other people, have visited schools and spoken to students who say things like: 'I won't have any trouble getting a job, it's a matter of trying hard' and 'kids who don't get jobs and have gone on the dole are bludgers. I'm not going to be one of those. I'm going to be one who really goes out and finds a job.' One cannot help but be a little sad at seeing this tremendous optimism the kids have about to be crushed by the realities of the job market.

Not only has there been a decline in the number of jobs available to young people but also the nature of the jobs has changed. Between 1966 and 1980 the number of full time jobs for young males declined from 319,000 to 299,000 whereas part time jobs increased from 19,000 to 62,000. For girls, the number of full time jobs has declined from just under 300,000 to 228,000, and part time jobs have increased from 17,000 to about 83,000. Youth unemployment had existed for some time, but until the mid-1970s it had been offset by an increase in the number of students retained in schools. It was only after the mid-1970s, when the retention rates in schools began to level out, that the full impact of the loss of jobs became obvious. Despite the Government's claims about growth in employment, it remains a fact that unemployment among young people has grown. It now stands at about 15 per cent for males and about 19 per cent for females. Unemployment rates tend to decline with age. Of those who leave school at 15 years of age, 27 per cent are unemployed; at 17 years of age the rate is 18.9 per cent; and at 19 years of age the rate is 12 per cent. At 24 years of age the rate is 5 per cent. A person is very vulnerable if he leaves school at age 15 from year 9 or 10. His chances of being unemployed are more than one in four. They are even higher for a girl.

Technological change also seems to be increasing the disparity between the haves and the have-nots. The middle jobs are the ones which have been turned over to automation-word processors, for example. There has also been a decline in the number of people working as labourers. Unskilled and semi-skilled workers are the first to go when new technology is introduced. If this trend continues, the labour market will be increasingly biased against low achievers, particularly the young and the less highly motivated. There is no doubt that increasing technology will have an even greater impact in the next few years. Production levels can be increased without the need to increase employment levels. The Government has totally ignored this problem and urgent action is required. Under the Fraser Government's policies, the prospects are for increased youth unemployment, not decreased. The alternative is a coherent, workable youth policy. Even so, we will have difficulties which will require the community, employers, unions and government working together towards finding a solution.

I turn now to this year's Budget. The 1981 Howard Budget will do absolutely nothing to solve the nation's problems. It will only lower people's aspirations, cause greater unemployment and poverty in the community and create increasing industrial chaos. The gap between the rich and poor will become even greater. The ordinary people of this country are paying for the so-called resources boom through higher interest rates, higher income tax, increases in indirect taxes and increases in State charges brought about by the reduction in Federal grants to the States.

The Government has deliberately increased interest rates to restrict the growth in money supply which was largely brought about by the massive inflow of speculative money from overseas. The tax increases are also part of this strategy and have created a $1,500m Budget surplus which could be used to provide jobs for the young and unskilled and reduce the burden of increasing mortgage repayments on Australian families. It is interesting to note that while personal income tax collections are expected to increase by 22 per cent in 1981-82, company tax collections will increase by only 10 per cent. These tax increases can only serve to depress an already faltering economy. Growth of gross non farm product fell from 6.1 per cent in the first half of 1980-81 to 1.6 per cent in the second half of the year. Unemployment between June and July 1981 increased by 25,000, while it decreased over the same period in 1980. Also, the number of people receiving unemployment benefits increased by 3,060 or one per cent between June 1980 and June 1981. This clearly indicates that unemployment is increasing once again. The trend has not been reversed as the Government would have us believe.

Increasing sales taxes in the current environment of rising interest rates and State charges will only reduce people's ability to spend and will cause even more hardship for pensioners. It will result in a massive slow down of industry causing unemployment to increase further in the next 12 months. The sales tax on building materials combined with interest rate increases will put home buying out of reach of thousands of Australians. It will severely hit the already depressed building industry in my home State and no doubt will also be felt in other parts of Australia. This Government is deliberately slowing down the economy to bring down inflation but it admits that the inflation rate will actually increase in the next 12 months. Clearly its policies are not working.

In 1980 Mr Fraser won government by promising tax cuts while running a fear campaign against Labor's alternative taxation policies. He has clearly broken that promise. This Government has alienated itself from the community and has totally neglected the needs of the average Australian. We as Australians should be looking to the future with pride and confidence. But under the current regime we are destined for increasing confrontation within the community, higher unemployment and a wider gap between the rich and poor. It is high time that the Fraser Government realised that this country's greatest resource is not its mineral wealth, but its people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I at the outset congratulate you on your election to your high office. I am sure you will have a distinguished period of duty and will have the respect and confidence of both sides of this chamber. I also congratulate Senator Foreman on his maiden speech. He too, I am sure, will have a distinguished career here. It was good to see his maiden speech witnessed by three former South Australian members of the Federal Parliament; two senators and one Minister from the House of Representatives. I do not think the Honourable Clyde Cameron will find the Senate as lively as the House of Representatives was when he was in full spate there.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now turn to the subject of the Budget and in particular the aspect of interest rates. It is time we got away from some of the cant and hypocrisy talked about in relation to interest rates and got down to serious thought about the problem. It is a problem particularly for home owners with large mortgages and small equity. I will come back to that problem in a moment though it is worth pointing out right away that not everyone loses from high interest rates; lenders gain from high interest rates and many lenders are small people, much more so than many of the borrowers. A reduction in interest rates would result in a drop in the value of the insurance, superannuation and savings of many small people.

Without in any way trying to minimise the difficulties that high interest rates have created for many home buyers we must not pretend that there are no advantages on the other side to offset the difficulties and sometimes hardship being caused by high interest rates. Of course, it is not only housing that is affected by high interest rates. For instance high interest rates cause inventory run-down as businesses cut overdrafts by carrying less in the warehouse. This of course has a chain reaction throughout supplies and so on. Two things must be said, and said again and again, about interest rates. Firstly, interest rates are the price of money. Short term interest rates are governed by the ordinary laws of supply and demand; the commodity in this case being the available money. Secondly, interest rates cannot be separated from other parts of the economy. Interest rates are inextricably related, for instance, to money supply and to government Budget policy.

Why are interest rates so high? Can government action bring them down? If they cannot be brought down generally, can and should they be brought down selectively-on housing loans for instance? Let us look at each in turn. Why are interest rates so high? In many ways our present economic situation is the envy of many other countries. Real economic growth last year was 3 per cent. According to the Budget Papers growth is expected to be 3 1/2 per cent this year though the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development predicts a rate of 4 per cent as compared with one per cent for the OECD area as a whole. Real wages grew by 4 per cent last year though this is too high to be sustained. The strengthening in our economy is expected by the OECD to be broadly based but private investment spent on resource industries is regarded as a particular source of strength. This impressive growth comes at a time when most OECD countries are having no growth or even negative growth. Of course, out of growth comes more to share.

In the modern democracy it is very difficult to make a no growth economy work. This is the so-called zero sum society. In a zero sum society if we want to give more to a deserving group we have to take it away from another group which usually resists successfully. The result of the successful resistance is endemic inflation. The only way this Government, or any government, can achieve desirable social objectives is through sustained economic growth. This is being achieved by this Government. It would be destroyed by Australian Labor Party policies. The second favourable economic indicator is inflation. Last year inflation was 8.8 per cent, well below the OECD average and below the average rate for our trading partners. The third favourable economic indicator is unemployment which is coming down sharply. Employment has risen by 2.3 per cent in each of the last two years. Business confidence is up. We have enormous opportunities.

Of course there are problems. We must not let the so-called boom get out of control. Inflation is edging up. We must not try to distribute now the proceeds of investments which will not yield anything for 10 years or so. If we tried to do this wage demands could explode as they did during the Whitlam years. Of course, interest rates are much higher than we would like. In this Budget the Government has firmly faced these problems and used the budgetry weapons at its disposal to head off the dangers. The key weapon in controlling inflation is limiting the growth in the money supply. Of course, a Labor Party government would let the money supply blow out as it did in the Whitlam years when it hit an annual rate of increase of 27 per cent. This sort of thing might bring a temporary dip in interest rates but of course before long inflation would soar and interest rates would follow. This government, of course, is more responsible.

To head off the dangers of increased inflation and a wage explosion the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is aiming for an increase in the money supply of not more than 10 per cent to 11 per cent. Money supply growth is determined by the size of the domestic borrowing requirement of the central government, private sector foreign exchange transactions and a net increase in bank lending less net sales of government securities for the non-bank public. All these either are, or are potentially, under government or Reserve Bank control, though the relevant statistics and controls are perhaps somewhat slow acting. So much for the supply side of the supply-demand balance which determines short term interest rates.

What about demand? The Government has taken two very significant actions to ease the demand for money. The Budget strategy is designed to dampen down just a little the so-called resource boom atmosphere in favour of more controlled, steady growth. Of course, this will ease the pressures on the money supply and interest rates. Even more importantly, we are moving to reduce government demands for money market funds. These demands include those of State and local governments, as well as our Commonwealth Government demand. In fact, last year their share of the public sector borrowing requirement was almost twice as large as ours. This year the Government has budgeted for a domestic surplus of $1,500m and has contained new loan programs to a level which is 4 per cent lower, in real terms, than that of last year. This will mean a sharp reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement and, again, will reduce pressure on interest rates. On the other hand, the Australian Labor Party, by its attempt to prevent the collecting of $500m in sales tax, would increase the public sector borrowing requirement and therefore increase interest rates. The crocodile tears that its supporters are shedding about interest rates are the purest hypocrisy. I suggest that it would be irresponsible, and probably impossible, for the Government to do more than it is doing in regard to interest rates.

A Labor Government in Britain tried to put a strait-jacket on interest rates by saying that they must not exceed a certain level, which, of course, was below the market rate. The obvious thing happened. Various substitutes for money arose outside the market and other liquid assets took the place of money. In fact, the British did not manage to reduce the effective interest rates for the benefit of those most in need, who had to use other sources of borrowing and finished up paying much higher interest rates than they would have paid if the Government had not interfered in the first place.

It should be obvious to everyone that a government cannot control both the money supply and interest rates. It can control one or the other but not both. This Government is committed to controlling the money supply as a vital weapon in the battle against inflation. Therefore, we cannot control interest rates generally, although we can help to keep them down by reducing the Government's demand on the money market. That we are doing. But, I repeat, Governments cannot control both the money supply and interest rates. They try to do so only at their peril and at great economic cost to the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you cannot control interest rates why did you promise to reduce them?

—No, the suggestion was that they would be reduced, but as a reflection-not an action by the Government. If governments cannot control interest rates generally, what about doing it selectively? Can it be done? The answer is yes, but probably at great cost to everyone else and quite possibly to the harm of the people whom a government is intended to help. The trouble is that if you hold interest rates down artificially in particular areas, such as housing, people will put their money somewhere else. If banks and building societies cannot get the money in, they will not be able to lend to home buyers. Would-be borrowers will then have to go elsewhere for their money and will probably pay exorbitant interest rates in so doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem was well summed up by Mr R. B. Cameron, Director of the Australian Bankers Association, when he stated:
Savings bank deposits showed little growth, in real terms, during 1980-81.
He continued:

Low deposit growth means a low level of lending for housing. Savings banks will be able to provide a strong flow of housing finance only if they are able to set rates of interest in line with those applying in the market-place. Savings banks still do not have sufficient competitive freedom. In fact, due to official controls, savings bank housing loan interest rates have risen over the past three years by much less than have other interest rates.

The problem has also been clearly recognised by the New South Wales Housing Minister, Mr Sheahan, who, when approving an interest rate rise on permanent building society home loans, quite rightly said that building society interest rates on housing loans had to go up, because, unless building societies were competitive and able to attract their share of investments, home loans would dry up.

We saw proof of this, both last year with savings banks and this year with building societies, when interest rates charged by these two institutions were too far below other rates. In the six months to June 1981, savings bank deposits, excluding interest, fell by $112m compared with an average increase of nearly $150m in the corresponding periods of the two preceding years. For building societies, the total sum deposited between December 1980 and June 1981 was $165m. This can be compared with a corresponding intake in the previous year of $855m-a drop from $855m in one year to $165m in the next. The drop in home loan approvals was even more dramatic.

A study done recently for the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System pointed out that trying to hold down interest rates on housing loans did not just fail to help low-income earners get housing loans. It also resulted in their being the very group which suffered financially. I do not want to underrate the burden of extra costs that high interest rates impose on home buyers. However, we should not completely lose perspective about the impact of these costs. A person on average weekly earnings who took out a mortgage of $30,000 three years ago at an interest rate of 10 per cent would have seen his mortgage payments rise by about $54 a month over the three-year period. However, his after-tax income would have risen over the same period by about $226 a month.

Of course not everyone can afford adequate accommodation unless assistance is provided by the Government. I make it clear that at the moment I am not talking about welfare housing for people who cannot otherwise afford housing. Some State housing Ministers are demanding several hundred million dollars more for welfare housing, apparently primarily in order to help the house building industry. Unfortunately, it is most unlikely that it would actually help them. The Government would have to raise the necessary funds on the money market and the competition would push up the interest rates for intending home buyers. The housing industry might well find that it had lost as much or more on the roundabouts as it had gained on the swings. In any case, welfare housing is a separate issue. I am talking of assistance to ease the financial strain on people who can afford, or nearly afford, to buy a house. What about direct assistance for them? Is it needed, and what sort of assistance would be effective?

During the last three years the number of houses completed has been rising steadily-117,000, 129,000 and 135,500 in successive years. It appears that this year the figure will drop to not more than 125,000. That is certainly well below the capacity of the industry, but is it below the needs of the community? The Housing Industry Indicative Planning Council calculates that we need at least 146,000 new houses a year. Its calculations are detailed and persuasive, though they rest on the critical assumption that the proportion of the community which owns a home should remain as it is. Most of us would agree with that assumption because of the great importance that is attached to home ownership as a crucial factor in our social structure. What, then, is the best way to give the housing industry the nudge that it needs to push its output of houses built and sold from 125,000 to 146,000 a year? We do not need massive support, of hundreds of millions of dollars, to do this. But, I do think some support is justified, although I do not want to sound like the United States senator who said: 'A billion here, and a billion there; why, it soon adds up to real money'. If we want to encourage the construction and sale of 20,000 more houses a year, the obvious group to be helped is first home buyers with modest family incomes. I see no need to help those who are 'trading up' to larger or more ostentatious houses. I think over the years people have developed rather grandiose ideas of what sort of houses they need and what is often being demanded may well be beyond the ability of the individual, or the community, to afford. The other thing we must do in any scheme to help home buyers is to avoid imposing any additional demand on the money market, because that would almost certainly be counter-productive.

I think the best solution is to take the $74m we now spend each year on the Homes Savings Grant Scheme and give it as an interest subsidy-by my calculations we could give up to 6 per cent-to first home buyers for the first two years or so of their loan. The subsidy would be subject to means testing of family incomes and apply only to the purchase of modest homes. The Homes Savings Grant Scheme does little to encourage house purchase. It comes along nine months too late, and tends to be used for furnishing rather than purchasing the house.

I think a case could be made for referring the problem to the Industries Assistance Commission. After all, we are looking for a scheme to help an industry-the housing industry-and the IAC is set up to advise the Government on just that subject. The aim should be a very modest one: How to help the housing industry increase its output by between 10 per cent and 15 per cent. But that is not what many people are proposing. What is suggested is that there should be massive direct assistance to housing borrowers. All sorts of questions have to be answered about this. Why housing, and not, say, cars or business inventories, for that matter? Bearing in mind that some people would be lenders as well as borrowers, surely to qualify for interest assistance account would have to be taken of their net borrowing-lending position. If we were to adopt the proposal that has been widely canvassed-making housing interest payments tax deductible-how would we cope with the criticism that this would be very regressive, of much more value to people with expensive homes and high incomes? Such a scheme was tried by the Whitlam Government and it failed hopelessly. For all these reasons I am not persuaded that any general subsidy on housing loans is justified.

But it must be admitted that although we are taking action by macroeconomic policy which will reduce interest rates, they may never come back to the levels of ten years or so ago, even if inflation is reduced to the level it was then. This is because, for many years, low real interest rates on home loans were made possible only by low real returns on savings. The growing competition for savings and the increasing financial sophistication of the community now make such a situation most unlikely to recur. Insurance offices cannot depend any longer on tax privileges to compensate them for near zero real interest rates on insurance savings. The funds have now become aggressively return-oriented. What is more, 10 years of inflation have taught savers to look to high interest rates to protect the real value of their savings. So quite apart from the temporary pressures imposed on interest rates by the present restrictive monetary policy, long run factors are operating to raise the real cost of borrowing for home purchase. It is only too easy to demand lower interest rates and be damned to the consequences. The consequences are clear enough. Taxation would have to be increased by about $600m a year to offset the shortfall caused by a tax concession for mortgage payments. The diversion of an increased proportion of the available funds to the housing sector would mean that all other borrowers-businesses, hire purchasers and so on-would have to pay higher interest rates than they otherwise would have to pay-the inescapable law of supply and demand at work. The real cost of capital therefore would rise and our economic growth rate would be lower-housing is not a profitable investment. The poor would be worse off; they never benefit from house ownership subsidies. The wealthy would benefit. I do not think these consequences are acceptable, and I believe that bowing to the lower interest rate campaign would do a great deal more harm than good.

Of course, the needs of housing are important, and the problems of some home buyers are very real. I have been trying to put them into perspective. The increased general affluence which will come from economic growth is the best way of keeping good housing within the reach of the widest sector of the community. The Government is working to achieve this growth, and a firm priority on fighting inflation is vital. Our policies will continue to be tailored to that fight.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of a comprehensive double taxation agreement with Denmark which was signed in Canberra on 1 April 1981.
The agreement deals with all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and Denmark and is the second such arrangement that Australia has entered into with a Scandinavian country.
When it is assented to, this Bill will complete the processes needed for the agreement to be given the force of law in Australia. Denmark has already completed the processes necessary there.
Double taxation agreements have two principal functions-the elimination of international double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion.
The first of these involves the apportionment, by one means or another, of the relevant taxation revenue between the contracting countries.
There are various ways of doing this.
For example, some types of income are, by agreement, taxed only in the country of residence and others only in the country in which the income has its source.

The country of source may agree to limit its tax on some items of income and where, under an agreement, income may be taxed in the country of source and also in the country of residence of the recipient, the country of residence agrees to allow relief against its tax in recognition of the payment of tax to the country of source.
The agreement with Denmark accords in all essential respects with the position that Australian governments have taken over the years in relation to double taxation agreements.
It provides for the country of source to limit its tax on dividends, interest and royalties.
Australia and Denmark will each reduce the withholding tax on dividends flowing to the other country from 30 per cent to 15 per cent of the gross amount of the dividends.
The tax of the country of source on interest or royalties flowing to residents of the other country is to be limited to 10 per cent.

Australia's rate of withholding tax on interest is 10 per cent and this will not be affected by the agreement. However, we do not have a withholding tax for royalties paid overseas. These are taxed on the ordinary assessment basis. The limit on the tax on royalties will, therefore, only affect Australian tax on royalties paid to Denmark where tax on the ordinary assessment basis on the profit element in the royalties is greater than 10 per cent of the gross royalties.

The tax limit applying to interest and royalties will not affect income of those kinds derived by residents of Australia from Denmark while, as is the case at present, Denmark does not impose a general tax on interest and royalties paid to non-residents. However, if Denmark should impose tax on such income in the future the limit will, of course, apply.

A significant effect of the agreement concerns Australian resident individual shareholders who are beneficially entitled to dividends from companies resident in Denmark. It is provided that these shareholders are to receive the benefit of a credit from the Danish Government equivalent to one to which individual Danish shareholders are entitled.

Within Denmark it is broadly the situation that part of the tax paid by a Danish company is treated as taxable income of a Danish shareholder who receives dividends from the company and a credit for this amount is then allowed against the tax that the shareholder is liable to pay.

In defined circumstances Australian individual shareholders in Danish companies will, under the agreement, be entitled to a similar credit. This will mean that an Australian shareholder entitled to the credit will receive a payment from the Danish Government.

For Australian tax purposes, the sum of the dividend and the credit will be treated as a dividend and credit will be allowed up to the amount of the Australian tax thereon for the 15 per cent Danish tax.

The agreement contains measures for the formal relief of double taxation of income that may be taxed in both countries. The country of residence of the taxpayer is obliged to provide the necessary relief.

So far as Australian residents in receipt of income from sources in Denmark are concerned, income in respect of which a limit is imposed by the agreement on Danish tax will be taxed here with credit being allowed for the Danish tax. However, dividends received from Denmark by Australian companies, which are effectively tax-free in Australia, will remain tax-free here. Some income that is taxed in full in Denmark will be exempt from tax in Australia.
The agreement also contains provisions for exchange of information and consultation between the tax administrations of the two countries to assist in preventing evasion of tax.
A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of technical aspects of the Bill and of the agreement is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
