DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government has decided to appoint a royal commission to inquire into the Australian meat industry. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) indicated in his statement yesterday, allegations of malpractice have been made into aspects of the meat industry and evidence of malpractice has been produced which give rise to serious concern on the part of the Australian industry and Australian consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government is responsible for the maintenance of standards in the meat export industry, but the problems appear to go wider than this, and into areas of State administration. A Federal royal commission necessarily has powers limited to the area of Commonwealth responsibility-the export of meat. The Government therefore has invited all States to issue the royal commission with concurrent powers which would enable it to examine the meat industry in relation to human consumption and other uses domestically. The Victorian Government has already indicated its intention to take this action, so the royal commission will cover at least the handling of meat for domestic purposes in that State. His Honour, Mr Justice Albert Edward Woodward, O.B.E., will head the royal commission.
The royal commissioner will inquire into the following matters:

(a) Whether administrative arrangements and procedures for the supervision of the handling of meat for export are adequate to ensure that all meat exported from Australia meets the requirements prescribed by law;
(b) whether malpractices are occurring, or have occurred, in the handling of meat for export or the exportation of meat;

(c) allegations made, whether in public or to a Minister, department or authority of the Commonwealth, of malpractices alleged to have occurred during the past 10 years, in the handling of meat for export or in the exportation of meat;
(d) whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective; and
(e) whether in response to such allegations, any illegality or corruption occurred.

The royal commissioner is directed to make such recommendations arising out of his inquiry as he thinks appropriate, including recommendations regarding the legislative or administrative changes, if any, that are necessary or desirable. He is authorised, at his discretion, to defer his inquiry into any matter that is the subject of a police investigation or of criminal proceedings in a court. Further, if the Governor-General so approves, he may conduct his inquiry in combination with any inquiry that he is authorised to make by any commission issued by a State or States.

The royal commission will report not later than 1 September 1982. The Government is fully seized with the urgency of this matter. However, it is also important that the inquiry be thorough and wide-ranging. The royal commission will be authorised to make interim reports as appropriate. The royal commission is separate from the management inquiry announced by the Minister for Primary Industry to review practices and procedures in the documentary and physical control of meat destined for export. Measures have already been taken to tighten control of procedures. The management review by independent consultants will check these procedures and report urgently whether anything further needs to be done in this field. The royal commission is not prevented from commenting also on any aspects of this area that seem to it to require remedy; but because a royal commission is necessarily a longer process, this intermediate step is being taken to verify the effectiveness of the control procedures now in place.

I do not need to emphasise to the Senate the urgency and importance of this matter, concerning as it does an industry vital to the prosperity of the country. It is the Government's wish that this inquiry satisfy the Australian public that all available measures are being taken to protect and preserve the Australian meat industry. I move:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) for pointing a finger at a national problem. The statement just brought down by the Minister in relation to the crisis, if I can so describe it, in the meat export industry is an important one. There are many qualifications which the Opposition has about the matter. I think it is our proper function-indeed, it is of some importance in the context of the future of this industry-to make those qualifications and criticisms quite clear. The beef industry is one of Australia's great national industries and has been for many years. Almost overnight it has lost the reputation which it has built up over many years-since the time of the first settlers in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The value of the beef industry as a whole to Australia last year was in the order of $1.2 billion. The industry is one of our great traditional export industries. It provides the livelihood directly of farmers and of workers in the transport industry, in meat processing, in retailing and in the shipping industry. It is also one of the classic examples of necessary co-operation between public and private enterprise and between government and private industry. Private enterprise is represented by the labours of farmers and public enterprise, one would hope, is represented by the diligence of public servants in supervising the meat trade to see that what is offered to consumers both in Australia and abroad is genuine. In a matter of days the reputation of this great industry has been shattered.

I again emphasise the importance of government responsibility in the regulation of private industries. Government responsibility extends to securing the reputation of a whole industry and to making sure that private entrepreneurs within that industry do not bring discredit upon their fellow producers and private entrepreneurs. It is an important question because so many times in this Parliament we debate absurd ideological assumptions based on government withdrawing from sections of private enterprise activity. It is argued that private enterprise activity by its own virtues will produce a desirable result for this country as a whole. This is a classic example of an industry in which government inadequacies in the last few years-I use the expression 'government' broadly-in providing regulation and supervision of the industry have resulted not in private industry improving the reputation of this country as a meat exporter but in exactly the opposite.

The effects of what has happened can be summed up by a few examples of financial loss which have personally been brought to my attention. For example, exporters holding chilled beef have incurred losses of up to $100 a head for certain types of beef, and those losses will have to be carried. There has been a rapid fall in the demand for manufactured beef. I was informed that in one provincial city in New South Wales a processor who normally produced 10 tonnes of processed meat a day has had his output reduced to 7 tonnes and it is still falling. He now has to look closely at retrenching staff. In Victoria alone, my State, some 2,000 meat workers will lose their jobs for periods of up to a month. I speak with some concern as a Victorian senator. I am sure other Victorian senators are concerned. Victoria is in the eye of the storm of economic disaster in this country because the Victorian meat industry is in a particularly prominent position in the crisis which affects this nation's reputation in export markets.

Overseas the implications of what has happened still have to be borne. Questions that arise include whether Australian beef in future will be singled out by importing countries for more vigorous supervision. That would mean added cost for our exporters and farmers. The questions that arise from a scandal of these proportions are innumerable. The paramount ones are: Has there been any cover-up? Has there been a cover-up of the involvement of Ministers or the inadequacies of Ministers in the administration of their portfolios? Has there been a cover-up of the activities or inactivities of public servants? We on the Opposition side say frankly that there is little that can be retrieved from this mess in a national sense at this stage. It is to be hoped that whatever can be retrieved will be retrieved by diligent and fast government action and also by the appointment of the royal commission. We believe that primary producers and others directly involved will demand forceful action and that the real culprits, those at the top, pay the price for this disaster which has befallen a great industry.

I make those comments at the beginning because they are relevant to the terms of reference of this inquiry which were announced in the statement read by Senator Chaney on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). It is important that the context of this inquiry be properly seen in the terms of the damage which has been done to a great industry, the damage which has been done to this country, and of the individual suffering which has been produced as a result of what has happened. The royal commission must offer a central solution to some of the problems that I have adverted to. Unfortunately, it will be a year before the royal commissioner produces his report. An extraordinary section of the Minister's statement occurs on page 3, where it is stated:
The Government is fully seized with the urgency of this matter. However, it is also important that the inquiry be thorough and wide-ranging.

Of the two elements which are of crucial importance in this statement, the first is urgency-and the matter is urgent. It is urgent for cattle producers throughout Australia, it is urgent for the reputation of this country and it is urgent in respect of our national export earnings. But it is also important, as the statement says, that the inquiry be thorough and wide-ranging. It is not particularly urgent if it is not going to report until September 1982. More importantly, it will not be thorough and wide ranging under the terms of reference that are suggested in the Minister's statement. In the year until the royal commission is asked to report, the beef industry will unfairly face yet another 12 months of trauma. In the last decade the cattlemen of this country have seen their industry climb from the depths of despair to relative prosperity. Survival in the middle to late 1970s was a desperate thing for many cattlemen but, having pulled through that period, the worst recession in the industry's history, the beef producers of this nation are being betrayed now by those who seek, with all the rigour and energy at their disposal, to delay further this matter.

What has been presented to us in the context of the terms of reference suggested tonight is a half baked inquiry which will take a year. I refer briefly to the proposed terms of reference of the inquiry. The royal commissioner will be confined by these terms of reference to inquiring about the meat industry at the point of export. Anyone who knows anything about the meat industry in Australia will have known for a very long time that the problems occur through the vast chain of middlemen between the primary producer and the exporter. The problems are in that long chain of middlemen involved in the various processes, which might be described as almost broking processes, of the meat processing industry. On a proper construction of these terms of reference, the royal commissioner will not be able to inquire into those matters. He will be able to examine only at the point of export. The Government seeks to take comfort from that limited allegation by the reference to the constitutional power of the Commonwealth Government, by the suggestion that the Commonwealth effectively can inquire only under the export power at that time. I draw the attention of the Senate to the capacity which the Commonwealth Government has under the trade and commerce power and under the corporation's power to look at this industry at a much earlier stage.

The second thing I wish to say about the terms of reference is that the royal commissioner is limited to allegations which are made. For example, in paragraph (e) of the terms of reference the royal commissioner is invited to inquire into whether in response to such allegations any illegality or corruption occurred. I am sure Senator Chaney will agree with me when I say that that is an extraordinary sentence by any standard-'whether in response to such allegations, any illegality or corruption occurred'. Quite apart from the language of the proposal, the royal commissioner is required throughout these terms of reference to look at allegations which are made and then to respond to those allegations. Under these terms of reference he is not authorised to call for departmental files in order to engage in his own inquiries about the nature of the industry. He is required under every term of reference to look at allegations that have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about (a)?
—Certainly that is the case in relation to (a), which involves looking at the administrative arrangements.
—What about (b)?
—I take it that in the context of this document one has to have allegations of malpractices.
—That is a most extraordinary reading of it.

—No, if one looks at the whole of the terms of reference, the burden of the terms of reference is whether allegations have been made. The royal commissioner is invited to look at a response to those allegations.
—Not in (a) and (b).

—He is invited to look at the administrative arrangements and procedures at the point of export. That relates to the point I made earlier. He is not, under paragraph (a), invited to examine the chain of processing in the meat industry. He is invited to look at the point of export.
—The handling of meat for export?

—Yes, the handling of meat for export. Mr Anthony made it quite clear in his statement in the House of Representatives that as far as the Federal government is concerned that is the area in respect of which the royal commission will be looking.
—I am sorry, but that is a misreading.

—Perhaps the Minister could get one of his learned senators to reply to me at a later stage. The point I am making is that the Acting Prime Minister refers to the State powers in relation to this matter and the Commonwealth power. He stresses the need for co-operation between State governments and the Commonwealth Government. The Queensland Government has already declined to co-operate. In Queensland that will lead to the Commonealth royal commission floundering around under the export power and nothing else.
—It is a misunderstanding.
—The Minister says it is a misunderstanding. I am looking at the statement. There may be all sorts of interpretations.

SPEECH.PARA: These terms of reference are structured very narrowly. We say that they would not produce satisfaction in the beef industry as a whole and that they are designed narrowly in order that the Government will get a narrow result after an examination which will take some 12 months. We regard the terms of reference as inadequate. We do not regard them as sufficient in terms of examining the industry as a whole. This is not just a crisis in relation to the export market. We argue that the possibility for examining the domestic market is excluded. The inquiry should be much more wide ranging than the terms of reference provide. One should be suspicious of terms of reference as narrow as these. Because of our concern about these matters and the concern of the industry as a whole that the inquiry be as wide ranging as possible I wish to move an amendment to the motion for the Senate to take note of the statement. I move:
At end of motion, add, 'but the Senate is of the opinion that the terms of reference of the proposed Royal Commission should be amended to inquire into-

(a) whether legislative, administrative or other arrangements and procedures for the supervision and control of all relevant stages leading to the export of meat from Australia are adequate to ensure that all meat exported meets legal requirements and protects Australia's export markets;
(b) whether malpractices are occurring, or have occurred in the preparation, processing or handling of meat for export or the exportation of meat;

(c) whether investigations in relation to information which was available or could reasonably have been available in relation to malpractices which occurred or are occurring or which were alleged to have occurred have been diligently pursued;
(d) if the answer to (c) is no, the persons, including ministers, responsible for that lack of diligence;
(e) if there were such persons responsible for lack of diligence whether such lack of diligence constituted illegality, corruption or impropriety.

These wider terms of reference cover, beyond reasonable doubt, the sort of criticisms we have heard about the narrowness of the present terms of reference. In moving the amendment I briefly draw the attention of the Senate to the differences between the terms of reference proposed by the Government and the proposed amended terms of reference. If the Government intends the royal commission to inquire into all stages of the industry leading to the export of meat from Australia, there is no reason why it should not say so in the terms of reference. There is no reason at all why it should not query whether legislative, administrative and other arrangements and procedures in all of those stages are adequate, if that is what it wants the royal commission to do. If that is what the Government wants members of the public who will give evidence to the royal commission to say then it should say so. There is no reason why the royal commission should not examine whether malpractices are occurring or have occurred in the preparation, processing or handling of meat for export. If that is the Government's intention in appointing this royal commission, why should it not state in the terms of reference that that is its intention? There is no reason why the terms of reference should be confined to answering allegations only.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(8) The decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions concerning contracting out work to the private sector do not affect the operations of two of the authorities under my control, namely the Health Insurance Commission and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission. These are trading organisations whose management decisions must always be based on commercial considerations. In relation to the Department of Health and the Capital Territory Health Commission action is in hand to respond to these decisions.

One of the decisions from the Review was for the manufacturing portion of the Department of Health's National Acoustic Laboratories to be carried out by the private sector with Australian firms tendering for the manufacture and assembly of hearing aids. The necessary documents have been prepared and it is anticipated tenders will be invited in the press in August 1981. Areas under consideration include cleaning, repairs and maintenance, printing and computer software. Whether or not work is finally contracted out will depend on the extent and content of responses received to public tenders when they are called.
In the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions concerning contracting out the following considerations were noted-
Contracting out could be considered where:
the private sector can provide the services more economically and/or conveniently;
services are already provided by the private sector and using Commonwealth resources to undertake them would be to compete with suppliers of those services;
performance of a new function or continuance of an old one would involve an unacceptable level of new capital investment or increased expenditure in salaries or services;

there is a need for expertise in a specialised technique or access to specialised equipment which it would be uneconomical for the Commonwealth to acquire particularly for one-off short-term requirements;
use of external services could be expected to bring an objective viewpoint with the prospect of a high level of acceptability of findings;
services might be more appropriately provided by State or local government under contract to the Commonwealth.

These considerations will be borne in mind by the Department and the Capital Territory Health Commission when assessing whether to contract out particular tasks or functions. Naturally, when making such decisions potential savings will need to be offset against any additional or hidden costs. Constraints may also flow from the requirement to ensure engagements meet the principles for fair competition, ability to withstand public scrutiny, effective services and value for money.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The 33rd Annual Meeting of the International Whaling Commission (IWC) was held in Brighton, England, in July 1981. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1884) Senator Gietzelt asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning coverage of preventive medicine by health insurance funds.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Government considers that preventive activities have an important role in a proper, balanced health system. Various programs are directed at encouraging people to adopt a healthier life style, including public education of the effects of smoking, alcohol and drugs.

It is significant that under the health insurance arrangements operative from 1 September 1981, Commonwealth medical benefits are payable to insured persons at the rate of 30 per cent of the Schedule fee for all services, unless otherwise excluded by the Health Insurance Act. This arrangement recognises the importance of primary medical care, in particular, as provided by general practitioners, both as to the ongoing companion function of health care advising and the early detection of possible serious conditions that might otherwise result in more costly curative care.

Health funds are required by legislation to pay basic medical fund benefits in the same circumstances that Commonwealth medical benefits are paid. Therefore, funds cover services provided by doctors regardless of whether such services are of a preventive or a curative nature.

At one stage some health funds had rules that excluded benefits for routine examinations in the absence of disease. The Government considered that such rules may deny benefits for a legitimate medical check-up and could be an inhibiting factor in the practice of preventive medicine. Therefore, such rules were disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2927) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question, without notice, which included whether the Government would permit the Union Steam Ship Co. of New Zealand to compete with the Australian National Line on services to the northern coast of Tasmania.

The Australian National Line (ANL) provides a number of coastal services linking the northern ports of Tasmania with various mainland ports. These trades are not exclusive to the Line.

The Government expects ANL to compete on an equal basis with other ship operators in the coastal trades and has made amendments to the Act in the past to create an equal opportunity environment for all ship operators. The Union Steam Ship Co. of New Zealand is able to compete with ANL in the northern Tasmania trades now.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3193) Senator Elstob asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning Commonwealth grants to non-government schools.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

The per student figures quoted by the President of the South Australian Institute of Teachers refer only to the Commonwealth's direct contributions to government and non-government schools through the programs administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. It is quite misleading to focus solely on the Commonwealth's direct contributions without also taking account of its indirect contributions via the general purpose grants to State Governments. The States receive about half their total income from the Commonwealth and thus the Commonwealth indirectly contributes about half the expenditure by the States on government schools.
In determining the level of its direct spending on government and non-government schools, the Commonwealth takes account of the support being given to each sector by the States.

When the total expenditure by both Commonwealth and State Governments on schools is examined it shows that over twice the amount is being spent on average on each pupil in government schools as is being spent on each pupil in non-government schools: a difference of over $1,000 per pupil.
The Commonwealth Schools Commission has reported that, on average, the great majority of non-government schools have resource levels some 30 per cent below those of government schools.

The underlying objective of Commonwealth programs for schools is to assist in establishing and maintaining high standards in all schools. The programs reflect no greater priority for one sector of schools than for another.
